PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Michael Beahan) took the chair at 9.30 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned expresses the widespread community outrage throughout Australia at the decision of the French Government to resume nuclear testing in the South Pacific.
Your petitioners ask that the Senate note and endorse the concerns expressed in this petition and convey to the French Parliament in the strongest terms Australia's opposition to this decision.

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows that we are;

disturbed by the fact that every month between 600 and 1200 people (most of them civilians) are killed or maimed by landmines, and their health and maintenance costs are being incurred in countries with insufficient resources to meet the most basic needs of all their people,

concerned that the cost of clearing and de-activating of landmines is one hundred times the financial cost of manufacture, and the human cost is being borne by people who have suffered displacement, war, tribulation and hunger,

and we are greatly concerned that there remains between 85 and 100 million unexploded mines scattered over 62 different countries, inhibiting the ordinary movement of civilians and the farming of fields as people return to their former homes as wars cease.
Your Petitioners request that the Senate should:
ensure that the overseas aid budget contains a substantial allocation for de-mining training programs,
ensure that Australian Government delegations to International fora persuade more countries to become party to, and gratify, the Inhumane Weapons Convention

ensure that Australian Government delegations to International fora promote and support an amendment to Article 6 of Protocol II to prohibit the use, development, production, stockpiling and transfer of landmines.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned:
1. Condemns the President of France, Jacques Chirac, and the French Government for deciding to resume nuclear testing at Mururoa Atoll;
2. Joins in world-wide anger over France's decision, which calls into question France's commitment to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty;
3. Urges the Federal Government to urgently inform France in the strongest possible terms of the anger felt by the people of Australia at the decision;
4. Calls on the Federal Government to consider all available diplomatic; economic and cultural measures which may force the French Government to cancel nuclear testing.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Landmines
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows that we citizens of Australia support the Government's efforts to assist nations with the clearing of land mines and also support a world-wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti-personnel mines.

Your Petitioners request that the Senate support our call for a world-wide ban on the production, stockpiling and use of all forms of anti-personnel land mines, give priority to expanding Australia's support for mine clearance in affected countries and use its influence to encourage other countries to give greater support to mine clearance efforts.

PETITION.TITLE: Child Care
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: The Petition of the undersigned shows:

`Observe the United Nations Convention of the Rights of the Child and grant all children social justice and equity in relation to a pre school developmental program which will provide the foundation for a quality education and future employability, by removing the 12 hour (or 1 day) child care assistance restriction for long day care based on parents marital and employment status'
Your Petitioners ask/request that the Senate should:
`remove the 12 hour (or 1 day) child care assistance restriction for long day care children based on parents marital and employment status'

PETITION.TITLE: Freedom of Choice
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The humble Petition of the Citizens of Australia, respectfully showeth:
That we:
(1) Affirm the importance of quality education for all the children of this Commonwealth of Australia irrespective of their religion, nationality or sex;
(2) Support the rights of parents to have freedom of choice of the school for their child;
(3) Support the right of all non-government schools to maintain their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos;
(4) Support the freedom of choice in staffing of all Churches and religious organisations.
(5) Support freedom of religion and the right of all Churches and religious organisations to maintain their distinctive foundational ethos.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Senate oppose any attempts to introduce legislation that would jeopardise these freedoms and rights and which would force Schools, Churches and religious institutions to compromise their distinctive moral values and foundational ethos.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray:
To the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled
This Petition of the undersigned Australian citizens respectfully points out that:

There is an urgent demand from the majority of Australians for immediate Federal Government intervention, to comply with the United Nations Biodiversity Convention to which Australia is a signatory, and protect the remaining high conservation value forest areas which support flora and fauna unique to Australia.
Your petitioners therefore request the Senate to:
immediately implement the moratorium clause in the 1992 National Forest Policy Statement, and cease all logging activities in high conservation value forests;

permanently protect in reserves, all old growth, wilderness, and other high conservation value forest areas, under the custodianship of Australian indigenous peoples, in cooperation with local communities, conservation and scientific organisations;
reap only what is sown by utilising readily available plantation timbers for industry needs;
rapidly implement timber industry transition from native forests to plantations, with provision for retraining, redeployment, and compensation if necessary for affected workers and contractors;
restructure the paper and fibre board industries to use annual fibre crops such as kenaf, hemp, cane etc.

create employment incentives to collect seeds, propagate, establish and manage sustainable permaculture-style mixed species timber plantations, on existing cleared and degraded lands, and encourage investment in the growing and marketing of indigenous forest products, such as native fruits, nuts, berries, seeds, oils, and other nutritional and medicinal resources.
develop educational environmental tourism as a sensitively managed industry, in appropriate forest areas, with full respect for Aboriginal cultural heritage and sacred sites; and
further support the above initiatives by the progressive utilisation of defence personnel, resources and funding, to assist rural communities to implement sustainable plantation forestry practices.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Weapons Testing
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled;

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:
We are greatly concerned that the planned nuclear testing by the French may have detrimental effects on the following aspects of our lives.
(1) Future generations
(2) Marine life
(3) Deformities that may be caused to unborn babies
(4) Contamination of our land
(5) Polar ice caps melting
(6) Effects on crops
Your petitioners request that the Senate should do everything in its power to oppose the proposed nuclear testing at Mururoa Atoll.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Employment, Education and Training References Committee

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 17 October, on motion by Senator Hill:
That the following matter be referred to the Employment, Education and Training References Committee for inquiry and report on or before 23 November 1995:

PROCTEXT.PARA: Whether the sale of Bond University, as one of a very small number of non-Government universities in Australia, to the University of Queensland, a public institution, would be in the national interest and, in particular, whether it would lead to a reduction in diversity and choice in Australian tertiary education.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I was indicating the reasons why I opposed this reference to the Employment, Education and Training References Committee. The motion by Senator Hill relates to the issue of the proposed sale of Bond University to the University of Queensland. The proposition that is being advanced is that there should be a report back to the Senate on this matter by 23 November.

PARA.TAB: I indicated yesterday that this was a proposition that ought not be inquired into on the basis, firstly, that it is not practical. It is not possible to have an adequate inquiry, given the extraordinary workload of this committee at the moment. I also indicated that it is not possible, given the nature of this inquiry, to have an adequate investigation of the proposal in the five-week period that is proposed, on the basis that, if these issues are so important, they do require a much more substantial investigation than a five-week period would allow in the normal course of events.

I indicated that currently this committee has four inquiries running. There is a requirement to report in this period on two of those inquiries. This provides ample evidence that the secretariat is not able to deal with these issues in an adequate way.

I suggest, in terms of the senators concerned, when you consider the workload that is involved with all the other committees they are involved in, given the estimates process is coming up, it is equally not possible for the senators to inquire into this matter in any way that one could describe as reasonable. This is a proposition that will not produce quality work. This is a proposition that flies in the face of good sense.

I have also indicated the government's view and my personal view that Australia has a very, very good record in the provision of quality public sector higher education. It has to be remembered, and I think it has to be emphasised, that the government's record on this matter is very, very good. In the period from 1983 to 1994 there has been a 68 per cent increase in the number of students attending universities. There has been a movement from 348,600 students in 1983 to 585,400 students in 1994.

In terms of funding, there has been an increase of some 64 per cent, from $3.1 billion in 1983 to $5.1 billion in 1994. In this year's budget that funding will increase by a further $16.5 million over the next three years. There is a substantial growth in expenditure.

This proposal comes on the heels of an opposition proposition to oppose a further increase of some $20 million in revenue to higher education through the Higher Education Funding Act. It has to be seen in that context.

It has also to be seen quite clearly that it cannot be done adequately under these arrangements. Therefore, one has to ask: why is it being proposed? Maybe it is the case that you do not need an inquiry. Maybe it is the case that you already have the report in your back pocket. Maybe it is the case that you have already made up your mind that there is a problem and you believe you have the answers to that problem. We have yet to hear it. Then again, we do not get to hear very much about solutions from the opposition on anything.

I draw this matter to the attention of the Senate in so far as this proposition was first advanced to my knowledge through the pages of the Australian. On Wednesday, 6 September it was announced that the Senate standing committee was having an inquiry into this matter. There was no reference to the committee, no discussion within the committee, just a bland announcement that we are going to have an inquiry into this matter. I found out about the work of this committee through the pages of the Australian.

It said that Senator Robert Hill had requested this inquiry. I do not recall his being a member of this committee. It indicated that Senator John Tierney, the chairman of this committee, had said that the proposed inquiry will investigate the full implication of university funding including the suitability of the public-private funding mixes. When the proposition was put to Senator Tierney, `What are you doing prejudging the work of the committee in this way,' he said, `I've been misquoted.'

TALK.START.PARA: —You know that I said it was being put to the committee, not that the committee was doing it. You are a hypocrite. You know the story.

—I am looking forward to your explaining to Matt Robins how you were misquoted by him. Again, last week there were reports in the paper about the work being undertaken by this committee. It was described as a committee hearing when in fact we are having an alleged private briefing. Of course, all of this was reported in the papers beforehand.

PARA.TAB: That raises the whole issue of what is the political intent here. This is why I say this proposed reference is in fact a recipe for yet another dirty little Senate inquiry. It is not about a proper investigation of a serious issue. It is not what is required, which is a proper investigation, of a very serious issue. It would take four or five months of committee work, not four or five weeks at the end of a busy session at a time when all of us are involved in so many other inquiries. At last count, I advised my office that I was on 12 separate inquiries. I have 12 inquiries running at the moment. I would suggest that my position is no different from just about everybody else.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where were you last night? You were supposed to be at a committee meeting.

—Senator Tierney wants to know why I was not at the committee meeting. He wants to call a committee meeting while the Senate is sitting. He wants to call committee meetings where he can try to pull a rort. He wants to call committee hearings at times when he can try to ram through bodgie reports, ill-considered and ill-conceived propositions, in a way which undermines the workings of this committee. As Senator Tierney has had explained to him, a bit of maturity is required here. Senator Tierney has to understand that, in terms of the working of this parliament, some parliamentary maturity is required. That is lacking here.

PARA.TAB: We see yet another politically inspired inquiry designed to provide a political platform in the run up to an election for the perceived interests of the coalition in terms of higher education. It is not about an objective analysis of a serious public policy issue; it is about party political advantage. Yesterday it was indicated there had been no statement from the government on these issues. It was indicated yesterday by Senator Teague, whom I do think does demonstrate parliamentary maturity on these issues, that he felt there had been no statement from the government on these issues.

In the very same article which had prejudged these inquiries and announced this work was going to be undertaken by this committee—and I draw your attention to this—the Australian of Wednesday, 6 September indicated that:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Crean—
the Minister for Employment, Education and Training—
guarantees that public funds would not be used to subvent or subsidise the bids.

That is, the bids of the various public institutions. That article was published on 6 September, and on that basis the proposition that there has been no government statement in terms of its policy position is demonstrated to be untrue.

TALK.START.PARA: —One sentence. That is your policy statement.

—I also draw your attention to this. That is the policy position announced in this small article. In the Financial Review of 11 May 1993, Mr Beazley, a spokesman for the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, indicated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if a publicly funded institution wanted to buy and operate a private campus it would have to meet three conditions. Public funds could not be used for the purchase; there could be no cross-subsidisation of the private campus with public funds; and the operations of the two would have to be kept at arm's length.
In 1993 there was that reference to Bond. Mr Beazley outlined that well-known government policy. That is quite consistent with the position throughout the last five years.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the existing arrangements for publicly-funded universities we have had no calls for inquiries. There were no calls for an inquiry when it came, for instance, to the announcement by Dame Leonie Kramer of Sydney University that she thought that the university ought to be privatised. There were no calls for an inquiry when, according to the Australian of 15 March 1994, Melbourne University Vice-Chancellor Professor David Penington said that he thought that up to 50 per cent of the student load should be privately funded. There were no calls for an inquiry then. Why not?

There were no calls for an inquiry when the proposal to establish the Asian Pacific University in Melbourne was announced in the Australian on 25 August 1995. Why not? There were no calls for an inquiry into any of the something like 10 separate companies associated with Monash University. There were no calls for an inquiry about the number of private companies operating at Melbourne University.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you proposing more inquiries?

—Senator Tierney asks whether I am proposing more inquiries. What I find so infuriating about this is the abuse of the Senate's committee system through this process. Senator Tierney was advised that there could be a proper inquiry into the full interface between the public and private sector, which I acknowledge is a serious issue. He was offered support for that inquiry, but he was not offered support for a five-week quickie or a five-week dirty election stunt, which is what he is proposing.

PARA.TAB: I suggested that we have a proper inquiry into the full implications of public-private funding. Let us have a proper look at the capacity of the Department of Employment, Education and Training to examine the university profiles and the audit procedures to see whether or not there is a proper quarantine between public and private funding and whether or not the government's policy is being implemented by the universities. Let us have a look at that properly.

You are not going to tell me for a moment that, given the enormous workload we all have with the estimates committees and various other inquiries, you will within a couple of hours of hearings—that is all you will ever get under this proposal—late at night be able to properly investigate whether or not the audit processes are adequate. The heart of the issue is whether or not the profile processes are adequate and whether DEET's examination of those profiles is adequate. You will not be able to do that properly. It is a farce. This is a ludicrous political stunt aimed at advancing what you believe to be a very narrow political agenda.

We need to ask ourselves whether we have heard anything about these things from the Liberals. The answer is a resounding no because your policy position in truth is the privatisation of higher education. The crocodile tears we see on the privatisation issue are designed to cover up the fraud that you are proposing to perpetrate on the Senate in terms of your alleged commitment to the public sector. You do not have a commitment to that.

You were saying that the government ought to be involved in what is essentially a contractual dispute. You are asking the Senate to become involved in a contractual dispute. You are essentially asking the government to take sides in a contractual dispute and you are using the Senate in an attempt to pressure one party to back off in a contractual dispute. That is improper. These bids that have been made are commercial-in-confidence. It is a ridiculous proposition to ask a minister to intervene in that process. It is a ridiculous proposition to ask the Senate to be involved in what is essentially a commercial-in-confidence process which is also before the courts.

You are asking us to intervene in support of Bond University Ltd's legal action before the Queensland courts. That is improper. You have made no reference whatsoever to our current policy position. Every single public university in this country has a private corporate arm and you have made no comment about that whatsoever.

However, you said that Commonwealth money is involved. As I understand it, the public money involved in Bond University amounts to two awards: one is a student researcher who is receiving $28,000 for an Australian postgraduate research award; and the other involves a figure of $2,496 for an overseas postgraduate research scholarship. I understand that up to $60,000 might be allocated under the small grants program in 1995. That is the Commonwealth involvement. Massive, isn't it? We will spend more than that on this proposed inquiry!

It needs to be understood that a major shift is occurring in the culture of higher education. The so-called education business is occurring at all levels. That should be the subject of a much more serious investigation than this proposal could possibly involve.

Senator Teague would only be too well aware of the fundamental issue in higher education policy and that is the question of whether or not a university should have autonomy. You are saying that this Senate should intervene to prevent the sale.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am not saying that.

—In effect, you are saying that Queensland university should be prevented from purchasing Bond University Ltd—that a public university should be prevented from purchasing this university. That is a basic and fundamental intrusion into university autonomy which has very serious implications for higher education policy in this country.

PARA.TAB: So I suggest that you think again. This proposal is fundamentally flawed. In higher education under this government there has been a 68 per cent increase in the number of students attending university. Under this government a higher education policy has been introduced where thousands of working class people have been able to go to university for the first time. You are trying to cover up this very strong area of success for the government.

Your proposal is essentially aimed at trying to draw out some grubby political advantage in support of one side in a contractual dispute. You are trying to drag this Senate and this government into an essentially private contractual dispute that is currently before the courts. You know full well that the government's policy is absolutely clear and has been consistently implemented. Yet you are trying to behave in an improper way. It would be an abuse of the Senate committee system to undertake this action.

It is not possible to do this job properly. It is a good thing if you are asking for an inquiry into the broader implications of the public-private interface; but it cannot be done in the short time that you are proposing here. I urge other senators who may well be moved to support this proposition to bear those things in mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I have been misrepresented in two matters and I want to briefly respond to that, as is the right under standing orders. Senator Carr said that I do not respect the autonomy of the University of Queensland in this matter. I want to assure him and the Senate that I do. In my own speech I made it quite clear that I have still an open mind about the outcome of the proposal for purchase on Friday. It is a question to be determined that we just need to clarify.

PARA.TAB: I have really covered the second matter in that I have not got a closed mind. There is no political agenda—I stress that; for me, I mean it. With my colleagues with whom I have had discussion, there is no political agenda. It is the national interest. It is the bona fides of higher education policy that is driving this inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating a motion to refer a matter relating to Bond University to the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee. This motion has two main elements. The first is whether Bond University, one of the small number of non-government universities in this country, should be sold to a public university, the University of Queensland, and whether this sale would be in the national interest. The second element of the reference is whether this sale in particular would lead to a reduction in diversity and choice in the Australian tertiary education sector.

PARA.TAB: What we have before us, and I would like to draw this to the attention of the Senate, is one of the crucial turning points in higher education in this country. The last critical turning point was probably the Dawkins reform of 1987, which brought into the university system in this country the former CAE sector. What we have now is probably a much more revolutionary change in store. Whereas that previous major change in 1987 was probably part of a natural evolution—one that has occurred overseas—this one is not. Therefore, it is a matter of considerable public importance that should be debated most fully.

Senator Carr has indicated that we should have a broader inquiry. I would also welcome such a broader inquiry. The problem is that we have a very specific problem in front of us, and a matter that has not been finally decided. If we do delay this matter, it will be too late for the parliament and for the Senate to put a view on this matter. I would suggest to Senator Carr that perhaps we do a two-part inquiry, of which Senator Hill's reference could form part one; that is, to look specifically at the narrower issue of the sale of Bond University. Part two could then be a broader inquiry dealing with the whole interface between public and private higher education.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why didn't you move that through the committee then; why are you in here doing that?
—I would indicate to Senator Carr that, given the timing in the cycle, unlike open learning where we had a part one and a part two—
—It is an election cycle you are talking about.

—You are quite right. There is an election looming and the parliament could be prorogued in about six weeks time. But with the open learning inquiry one year ago we could do a part one at the end of last year and a part two at the beginning of this year—as, indeed, we did. Whoever wins the election, it is not too late to undertake a part two report later that would handle your concerns, and indeed my concerns, about the whole broader interface of private and public higher education provision.

PARA.TAB: What we have in this country is a very peculiar situation. We do not have a substantial private sector in higher education, and that is peculiar by international comparison. It is also peculiar by internal comparison with the high school systems in this country where we do have substantial private provision. The sum of $1.5 billion is spent by people in this country on the provision of private high school education. I would invite Senator Carr to think about what would happen if, suddenly overnight, all of those private schools disappeared. What would happen is that the government would have to stretch its resources out another $1.5 billion plus to cover that sort of provision. Obviously, that would then drain the state school system of resources. I would ask Senator Carr to reflect on what would happen in higher education if we did not have a substantial, robust and thriving private sector.

What this means is exactly the same thing. We have to stretch public resources over an incredibly wide field and that is why you find classes oversize, libraries run down, insufficient infrastructure and insufficient money for research. It is because the public dollar has to be stretched so far. If you go to a country like the United States you find there is a long tradition of this private provision but I would have to add that the private provision is backed by public money as well. That has enabled the establishment of private universities like Stanford and has also enabled a thriving contribution not only to higher education but, indeed, to the whole American economy.

About a third of the American higher education system is private. It goes back well over 100 years. It has become one of the major engine rooms of innovation and growth in the US economy, which leads the world. We do not have that—and we can only speculate on where our economy would be up to now if we had a hundred year tradition of private education in higher education in our country. We would have a much bigger higher education sector. With a private higher education system, we would have a situation where public provision could be better focused on the people who are now missing out on university and are trying to get in.

I was appalled when I came into the Senate and discovered that there were 50,000 students eligible to go to university who could not get in. The figure has come down to about half that, and that is most welcome; but there is still an enormous waste of the intellectual capital in this country when we turn away very large numbers of students. I put it to the government that one of the major reasons for this is that we do not have a robust private sector in this country.

Let us describe this sector. We have a very tiny private sector compared with the public sector. There are almost half a million students in public education in our universities. Let us look at the private universities in comparison. Bond has 1,500 students; the Australian Catholic University has 8,000; and Notre Dame has a few hundred. The grand total is 10,000 against 500,000. This number is incredibly small. I have alluded to one of the reasons why it so small. We have not had a tradition in higher education of large numbers of people going through. In the high school system we certainly have had that, but not in the university system.

I would like to point out to the Senate another reason, which is particularly important to us because we are legislators. This has not developed and the institutions that have tried have had great difficulty because of a very hostile legislative environment to this sector. It contrasts greatly with the US where there is substantial public assistance to private universities, something like the substantial public assistance we give to our private schools. That puts a base under them that allows them to grow and thrive.

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—I do not want to destroy your train of thought, Senator Tierney, but could I remind you of the topic: whether a reference should be given to the committee. Could I draw your attention to that?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very surprised you intervened, because I am talking about the very broad underpinning of this whole issue. It is something which ministers in question time always do. I am talking about why we do not have a large number of private universities in this country. That is at the crux of this whole issue, as I must point out to the chair, because we have a situation where the only substantial private university is about to be overtaken by a public university. I would have thought that my comments are amazingly relevant, so your interjection surprises me enormously.

PARA.TAB: Let us go back to the point of the hostile legislative environment. It has been pointed out to me that there are great inconsistencies in the way in which the private universities that do exist are treated by the government and this is one reason why we have to start inquiring into this area. It has not been thought through. It really just grows like Topsy. They can gain access to some public money through ARC grants, but in terms of capital infrastructure money, they have no access to that. What is the rationale for doing one and not the other? There is no rationale, and that is why the government should actually shape this whole thing up better, have informed public policy, have considerable debate on it, and let us work out what the way forward is from this particular point.

What is being proposed and what is currently happening—and this is why this matter is so urgent—is that one of the universities, namely Bond, in its current form as a totally private university is about to disappear. The whole argument that I have been putting forward is the great need in this country to help encourage a private sector to flourish. This move, it seems, is in the opposite direction.

The other reason why I believe an inquiry is urgently needed is that there are a whole lot of issues that now arise over the acquiring of a private university by a public university that I do not believe have been fully thought through by the government. I want to refer to a number of these and in particular go back first of all to the speech by Senator Schacht yesterday on this matter. I want to quote from some of the things Senator Schacht said yesterday and then comment on them. He said:

Institutions are prevented under the act from charging fees for undergraduate courses. However, an institution owning Bond University as a commercial venture would not be in breach of the act if Bond maintained a legal separate identity.

SPEECH.PARA: A little later on he goes on to say:
. . . the university to ensure that an effective and demonstrable barrier is built between the university
public and private operations.

The minister is putting to us that this whole thing is going to be quarantined off. If we had some confidence that that would actually be the case, we might be a little happier with it. But I cannot really see how you can do that and I draw to the attention of the Senate the inquiry that the Senate had—

TALK.START.PARA: —So you have made your mind up already, have you?

—Senator Carr was a member of the inquiry into the ABC back in January of this year. We were assured that the ABC, as a public corporation, had set up a number of private ventures, like Broadcast News Australia, Australia Television International, AIM—the pay TV arm. These were commercial ventures and these were going to be totally isolated from public money. Within four months of that assurance to a Senate committee, we had evidence that there had been cross-subsidisation by bail-out because these operations were not working.

PARA.TAB: The difference in this situation is that this is far more serious. With BNA and ATVI, you were looking at operations that were only worth about $5 million against a public budget of half a billion dollars. But here we are talking about whole universities buying other whole universities and there is a substantial amount of money involved—$100 million, if the newspaper reports are to believed. What happens if this venture gets into difficulties? The previous private owner, it is rumoured, lost a quarter of a billion dollars on Bond University. We have a very brave public university now taking over this venture and claiming there is not going to be any cross-subsidisation.

It also raises the question: if a public university can afford, through whatever means—and it could be its commercial arm or whatever—to raise $100 million for the purchase of Bond, why cannot it afford to do this and provide more research grants to its students, provide more places, improve the library, improve the infrastructure of the institution, get more overseas students in? Why cannot it direct its money in this way? Surely the government, which has a $4 billion investment each year in the public education system, should be concerned about that.

The next issue that this sale raises relates to what is going to happen in other universities. The minister assured us that none of them were going to follow suit. Yesterday the minister said that the purchase and operation of the Bond campus would not involve any kind of public money and that it would be quarantined. He went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think too many of them will, because I do not think too many of them are going to be able to raise $100 million on the risk market.

That is strange. If the University of Queensland can do it, Melbourne can do it, Sydney can do it, Adelaide can do it, Monash can do it, New South Wales can do it and, I would say, ANU can do it. If anything, a lot of those universities are in a much stronger position. That argument is an absolute nonsense. The minister goes on to say that he does not think people would be encouraged to risk their money. He said:
. . . but I presume after the Bond University example over the last few years there will not be a long list of investors . . . queuing up.

What I have just said about those other universities would put the lie to that. My guess is that the first one off the mark would be from Senator Carr's own state. Monash University was also a bidder and was quite prepared to do this. Griffith University is another university that was quite prepared to raise this sort of money.

PARA.TAB: Monash is a very entrepreneurial university and has a whole lot of different arrangements. It could use surplus public capital. A possible scenario is that, at Gippsland or Chisholm, Monash University could establish a private institution. Nothing that the minister said yesterday would seem to stop that. He said yesterday:

SPEECH.PARA: Institutions are prevented under the act from charging fees for undergraduate courses. However, an institution owning Bond University as a commercial venture would not be in breach of the act if Bond maintained a legally separate identity.
Therefore, Monash, Melbourne or Sydney could, on one of their many campuses, say that it is a private institution and run it as a separate entity.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can't use public money for that; that's the law.

—That is correct; you cannot use public money for that. Senator Carr might wish to comment on a further aspect. Having set up the institution by some other funding arrangement—and this is the big dam that the purchase by the University of Queensland has breached—for the first time we could have a public university controlling a private campus with Australian students paying full fees for undergraduate courses. That is what will happen with Bond University under the Queensland arrangements. By his speech yesterday, the minister has indicated that there is nothing to stop other universities from following suit.

PARA.TAB: I am surprised that Senator Carr does not believe that this matter is particularly urgent. This is probably the most significant change since the Dawkins reform. Senator Carr quoted one sentence from the minister and said that it was a policy statement on this matter. This is one of the most dramatic changes in higher education that we have seen. We have no green paper. We have no white paper. We have one sentence from the minister and a few vague assurances from the acting minister that everything is going to be all right.

I conclude by referring to some of the reports mentioned by Senator Carr and the workload that is imposed on the committee. I endorse Senator Carr's remarks concerning the very professional way in which this committee works. Brenton Holmes and his team are probably the hardest working and most dedicated professionals that we have in this parliament.

I would just like to correct the impression that Senator Carr left in terms of the number of references. It is true that we have had quite a number of references this year, but I would like to clarify the exact workload at this point. This year we have successfully completed and reported on part two of the open learning reference. We have reported on Commonwealth-state funding and on Austudy. And, by motions moved through the Senate, the reports on prison education and early childhood have been deferred until next year.

TALK.START.PARA: —This morning. This morning that was moved.
—It went through the committee last week, and you know it.
—This morning that was moved in this Senate.

—That went through the committee earlier, and you were aware of it when you spoke. So no work has to be done on those two references. All the inquiries have finished. The writing of the reports can wait until after Christmas. So they will not be working on those from this point on.

PARA.TAB: Then we have before us the long-term unemployment report, which Senator Carr did not turn up for last night. Senator Carr would aid the working and reporting of the committee if he was a little less obstructive and turned up to meetings when they are called. We were to meet originally, as scheduled, for three hours. We made no progress last night. The plan is to finish this report by next Monday. If Senator Carr turns up to the meeting, we might be able to achieve that.

The only other matter before the committee at this stage is the ANTA reference. We have had one hearing and there is one more to go. That is restricted in nature. Compared to our other inquiries, it is relatively minor in size and in the amount of effort it will take to report on it. It is on a fairly narrow reference, and that is the only other one we have to report on before the end of the year. Therefore, there is time to do a narrow focused inquiry into the Bond issue. I believe that is quite feasible. It is quite necessary because of the issues it raises, which I mentioned earlier in my speech.

A very significant change in public policy is about to take place. It is public policy by stealth. It has enormous implications for the students of this country, for the parents of this country and for the future of higher education in this country. It is a matter worthy of wide public debate and scrutiny. It might be embarrassing for the government to do it at this point, but the role of the Senate is to be a watchdog of government. Our role is to lay out, at any time, to full public view and inquiry any matter where we feel the government is not heading in the right direction with public policy.
I welcome the reference from Senator Hill. I think it is very timely. The Senate, I believe, must have a view on this matter. I urge the Senate to support this proposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before the Senate involves the undertaking of an inquiry by the Senate Employment, Education and Training References Committee. We have been reminded several times that the committee is very busy. As a matter of fact, last night while we were in this chamber debating this matter, the committee was supposed to be considering the chairman's draft of another report.

PARA.TAB: We have been informed that there were four inquiries current. We have also been informed that some of those inquiries have to some extent been delayed, postponed or otherwise rearranged. That is a consideration which needs to be taken into account. As a member of the committee, I am concerned, of course, about being given a greater workload. But I have indicated from the beginning that I do not think we can avoid the responsibility to inquire into this matter, which is one of some interest.

By way of compromise, I attempted to encourage the committee to receive evidence in private to enable it to get an understanding of the scope of the situation. Since then, we find that things have moved along a little and that, in fact, the sale has apparently gone ahead. That still leaves many questions unresolved.

Yesterday Minister Schacht made a contribution but I was still left with a great deal of uncertainty about the government's position, the government's consideration of this, what actual policy direction we would end up in or, more importantly, what policy position would apply to universities. We were told by Minister Schacht that a number of other universities around the country—if not all universities—had some sort of private enterprise attachment.

My question there, of course, is: do those private attachments have the capacity to award degrees? That has been a question which has been avoided by the government. We believe that those attachments don't have that capacity, yet de facto we see paths being found to provide qualifications which are then later accepted as being progress towards degrees.

This further step begs the question: what is it that will be conferred by the private university which is owned by the public university? What implications does it have for articulation and recognition of prior learning—a couple of the catch phrases that are used in education at the moment. In higher education there is a welcome movement towards, as I am sure most senators would know, more recognition of the prior learning that has been undertaken by a student for a degree and the articulation of some studies from some institutions into other institutions.

Because there is that movement, we will have to be very careful about what the implications are in the ownership of a private institution by a public institution for cross-subsidisation and for confusion of public money with private. If that path is apparently separate and apparently at arms-length, then we have to pursue this question: what implications are there for the recognition of previous studies in one institution for another and what is it that is finally conferred by the private part of the public university?

The financial implications, of course, we have been assured, will be separate and at arms-length. I am reminded, in the first instance, of the answer to the question from Senator Kernot yesterday about the AIDC and the government's interest there. The government claimed, through Minister Cook, to not have any capacity to be involved in this apparently private enterprise arrangement. Even though the government had agency ownership, there was no capacity to intervene.

If there are matters of concern to the public which are occurring in the private part of the Queensland University, does the government have the capacity to intervene? Should it intervene? If what is occurring is not in accordance with government policy, where does the responsibility start and stop? This is another key question in this whole clever arrangement that we see emerging in so much of the corporatisation and privatisation debate. Accountability seems to disappear. We have very little capacity in this chamber to question ministers about the things which are publicly owned but are `private'.

These are the sorts of questions which, I think, should arise in the inquiry and deserve to be investigated further by the inquiry. It is the implications for the way this country is going and what the public gets for its taxpayers' dollar. Who is actually funding this purchase? Will there be any further cost to the government or the public? What guarantees do we have that it will remain in private ownership? What is private ownership? There are so many blurred edges around these questions that I think we really do need to be supporting the inquiry.

Senator Carr was keen to interject while the previous speaker was making a contribution that Bond University had lost several hundred million dollars. What guarantees do we have that under the ownership of the Queensland university similar losses will not continue? If so, what are the implications for the public of such losses? We had a guarantee not so long ago regarding a private enterprise undertaking by a publicly owned organisation. The ABC's venture into ATI was supposed to be at arm's-length and not involve any additional expenses to the public. I cannot remember the exact amount but millions of dollars found its way through some path or other from the core funding of the ABC over to ATI, and that had implications. I think we are seeing it now with the closure of the 7.30 Report. I am sure that those senators who represent regional Australia would be most concerned about that.

You have to wonder whether the money—good money following bad—which went over to ATI brought on the closure of the 7.30 Report. These are the sorts of things that we have a track record of in this country—promises made that things will be at arm's-length and then the taxpayer getting left to carry the can at the end of the day. So I see a trail. We should inquire what means and measures have been taken to prevent that trail being repeated. We have been told that it is quarantined, that it is completely separate management. I have heard all that before. As a member of this committee I would ask questions and hope for much more satisfactory answers.

The only concern I have in supporting this motion is that Senator Carr indicated that to get to the bottom of this matter we should be conducting a substantial inquiry. I would agree to some extent with that. I would suggest that a time frame of this type is possible. As a member of the committee I will certainly give it every opportunity to be conducted as quickly and efficiently as possible. But I feel this could well raise the sorts of matters which we may find could do with a little more time for exposure. However, that is my only concern. The Democrats see a need to inquire into this. There are questions to be asked. We support the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on this issue because I guess that if there are reasons why the Greens might support this inquiry or reference they might be different from the reasons which the opposition and perhaps even the Democrats might be choosing. But there might be common ground. We see a push for corporatisation and privatisation of government universities. In many instances some universities feel the need to go into debt to attract overseas student or to export education services. We see some risk taking being seen as part of what universities do—the new corporate image. Some universities are doing well in terms of their ability to incorporate a corporate structure; some are not doing so well. Perhaps the logical conclusion is that in the future we will see the level of corporatisation in universities such that previously totally government universities may go into receivership at some stage because of the general direction.

PARA.TAB: Because of the nature of the funding and because of the history of universities in that situation, parliament is being asked to intervene against privatisation being taken over by government, which is an interesting twist to the normal theme. In the future we may see instances of this in many different forms. Perhaps we ought to be looking at the general principles upon which we operate our tertiary education policy. By looking at the instance that we see before us, maybe some of those more important principles will come out and will at least be on the record for when other instances occur in the future that may well involve government or what are currently 100 per cent government institutions now. That is the reason we will support this motion, not necessarily to protect a private university but basically to look at the implications of corporatisation within the university sector and the government corporate interaction that is involved in that.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I note that there was not a division and note that all senators, except the government speakers in the debate, indicated support for the motion. There was overwhelming support for a matter that did not need a division.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The government, through speakers in this debate, has made its position absolutely clear. The government did oppose this reference. It was rather churlish for Senator Teague to make such a comment. There are often matters that do not go to a division because a clear majority of senators make their position clear. In this case the Australian Democrats, Senator Margetts on behalf of the Greens and the opposition made their position clear. The government made its position clear.

PARA.TAB: You are right. If a division had been called, the good sense that had been argued by the government in this case and the strength of our arguments would not have been embraced by the majority of senators. I do make the point that it was an unusual contribution for you to make and, I think, a rather churlish one. The government's position has been made very clear and is on the public record.
Motion (by Senator Faulkner) proposed:
That the order of the Senate of 29 November 1994, relating to the consideration of legislation, not apply to the following bills:

Airports (Transitional) Bill 1995

Therapeutic Goods Amendment Bill 1995

Sydney Airport Curfew Bill 1995
Vocational Education and Training Funding Amendment Bill 1995.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I have to say that we do not believe that all bills in the list that has been circulated by the government should be in that list. We believe that many of them are perfectly reasonable to go through. However, we do not think the privatisation of airports is an urgent issue, particularly as a Senate inquiry has nearly finished an inquiry, one of the terms of reference of which was the privatisation of Sydney airport.

PARA.TAB: The Senate agreed to a motion which I moved during debate on the Aircraft Noise Levy Bill, the last part of which reads that the Senate:

(e) urges the Government to delay the introduction of all legislation dealing with the privatisation of Sydney's airports until such times as the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise in Sydney has reported on this matter to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: That was agreed to by the Senate. It was agreed to by the Democrats, the opposition, the Greens and Senator Harradine.

PARA.TAB: I cannot for the life of me see why the privatisation of Australian airports, particularly Sydney airport, is so urgent that a bill has to be put through this chamber before a Senate inquiry into this very matter has reported; let alone before the Senate has had time to consider the results of that inquiry. The Democrats cannot possibly agree that this is an urgent bill.

We disagree that the airport bills are urgent. We also disagree that the ANL bill is urgent. We cannot see the absolute urgency in that. I would be interested to hear what the urgency is. We cannot see that the privatisation of any other asset, including the airports, ANL and any other asset, is of such urgency that bills have to be pushed through in the next four weeks of sitting.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens recognise that the government has reasons for its feelings of urgency in regard to the sale of assets. On a procedural basis, it may well have a case in terms of the urgency. However, in relation to the airport sale bills, we want to find out just how much time the community throughout Australia has had to look at the ramifications of a very important level of privatisation. Airports are extremely important to a vast number of people, not the least of which the people living around airports.

PARA.TAB: We have been advised by the department that, yes, there had been extensive consultation, but the list in fact only relates to some peak bodies and people living around the Sydney area. This might be fine but the privatisation bill actually enables privatisation of airports right throughout Australia. That is the important issue. People in Western Australia are only beginning to realise—it is only beginning to hit the community—that this means them and just about every airport in Australia.

That level of consultation has not taken place across the states; it has taken place only, if you like, where the noise is loudest. It is legitimate that government should address that level of obvious community concern but for people in Western Australia, for instance, in relation to the Perth airport, it means that they may be presented with a fate accompli.

It might not be obvious to a lot of people that there is a third runway proposal for Perth. Currently the plans show two parallel runways and another east-west runway. Funnily enough, that is what was presented to the people in Sydney and that is not how it ended up. Here we are going to have various stages of privatisation and later on people will say that they were misinformed or ill-informed or not given the full picture. We will then have to deal with safety issues, community noise issues, inconvenience and all sorts of other things as well as the very real issues that are involved with trashing heritage listed wooded wetlands, which is exactly what would happen if you put the third runway in.

It is all very well at the moment that the community in Perth is being presented with stages one and two, which have `minimal environmental impact', which is debatable. Privatisation might or might not lead to a third runway. We should have learnt all of these things from Sydney, but we did not. What the government says is an appropriate level of community consultation is actually not an appropriate level of community consultation. There will be a lot of very annoyed electors in Western Australia when they work out what we are being asked to consider before they have even had a chance to look at the ramifications.

In terms of wooded wetlands, we know we have a chance to make some representation to CEPA when it is still fully under government control. What consultation will occur on those kinds of issues once it is privately leased and so on? Therefore, for procedural reasons we do not think the government has satisfied the concerns that are associated with this kind of very important legislation. There must be community consultation so that whatever decisions are made by either side of the parliament those community concerns are actually taken into consideration.

In terms of the Australian National Line, once again the government may well have legitimate reasons that it believes relate to the possible sale. It may have gone far enough in respect of a sale. It may well find itself in a difficult position if it does not have a legislative basis for what it is already negotiating to do. However, there is still a committee working on the Australian National Line, and it has not yet reported. It seems strange, considering the lack of assistance the Minister for Transport (Mr Brereton) gave in allowing the committee to look at the ramifications of the sale of ANL, that this will go ahead without that committee having the chance to report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to indicate that the coalition will not be opposing this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have very grave concerns about the Airports Bill. I do not believe the Senate is interested in frustrating government legislation. I believe the government does have a responsibility to try to ensure that legislation is introduced into this parliament and received by this chamber in an orderly fashion, particularly, as has already been indicated, so that we and the public have sufficient time to give the legislation and its ramifications careful and detailed examination.

PARA.TAB: What is being suggested by the government is that certain bills be exempted from the order of the Senate of 29 November. Paragraph (4) of that order of the Senate—and I will not read all of it—states:

SPEECH.PARA: (b) such a priority reflects and ensures effective use of the time available:
(i) to Senators to research the implications of the bills, consult the community, prepare speech notes and draft any necessary amendments, and
(ii) to the media and the public to become aware of the possible effects of the proposed laws . . .

Frankly, I have not heard the government give a proper explanation, as it is required to do, of why it wants the Airports Bill 1995 through as an urgent bill. I invite the opposition to indicate where the government has given that explanation.

PARA.TAB: The resolution of 29 November 1994 requires the government, where it wishes the Senate to depart from the terms of the legislation, to justify each such departure in debate which concludes with a resolution of agreement by the Senate. Unless I have missed something, I have not heard a compelling argument in debate concerning the necessity for exempting these measures from that resolution, particularly the Airports Bill.

As a senator from the state of Tasmania, that concerns me. I do not want to debate the issue in general, but I point out that there has been a great deal of concern and outcry from residents in Sydney and other parts of the country about the effect of airport noise. That may pale into insignificance if, as a result of this legislation to privatise certain airports, the communities concerned are going to be hit heavily with increased costs on a user-pays basis.

That is why, as a senator from Tasmania, I am concerned about this bill being regarded as an urgent bill. I do not believe that the people of Tasmania have had a proper and adequate opportunity to research this matter and to see how this package would affect the cost structures of the Hobart airport, for example. I think this is a matter that concerns you, Mr Acting Deputy President Watson. I know it would concern opposition senators and Labor Party senators from my state.

I believe that we should adopt a situation which would at least make sure that that bill is not exempted. I am testing the waters here. I know that the opposition has said that they will support the government. They no doubt have valid reasons for doing so in respect of the other pieces of the legislation that are listed. Therefore, I move:
Omit ``Airports Bill 1995'' and ``Airports (Transitional) Bill 1995''.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I ask that the arguments that the government has put to members of the Senate on the urgency be incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—Senator Margetts, the debate is yet to be closed by Senator Faulkner and I presume he will canvass those arguments during his closing remarks.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Margetts, I am happy to table the statements of reasons. However, I want to make this point to Senator Margetts and particularly to Senator Harradine: these statements of reasons are circulated to senators as a matter of course. They go to the whips and copies are also made available to Senator Harradine. That is a routine occurrence, I can assure you, and it did happen on this occasion.

PARA.TAB: I am also advised that a complete set of the statements of reasons for the relevant bills was recirculated to whips and also to Senator Harradine just two days ago. So I do believe, quite genuinely, that there has been an adequate opportunity for all senators in the chamber to avail themselves of a close examination of the statements of reasons which, as Senator Harradine pointed out in his contribution, was the intention when it was found necessary for us to take the course of action that the government is now proposing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: the motion currently before us seeks to exempt certain measures from a resolution of the Senate of 29 November 1994. That resolution of the Senate specifically states, `Where the government wishes the Senate to depart from that general chronological priority'—in other words, exempt the legislation as it is trying to do here—`the government should justify each such departure in debate which concludes with a resolution of agreement by the Senate.' PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—I understand that the government has given prior notice as a matter of courtesy and that the minister will be expanding on those issues that have been previously circulated during his closing of the debate. TALK.START.PARA: —Further on the point of order: I did not say that these matters should be raised before debate. I am sure the minister will think, as I do, that that is a reasonable way of going about things. I will not take it any further.
—Senator Harradine, it is really a matter for the Senate to determine whether the government has discharged that obligation accurately or correctly.

—I was outlining the way in which the government complies with the spirit of this order of the Senate. I think Senator Harradine has acknowledged—and I appreciate that—that statements of reasons have been made available on a number of occasions on the key bills that are before us. I might also make the point that the debate we are having at the moment really did not gain a great deal of focus until Senator Harradine moved an amendment specifically in relation to the two airports bills. We have had two speakers previously in the debate. I acknowledge that those particular bills were of concern to both Senator Bourne and Senator Margetts—they made that clear in their contributions. But there was no suggestion that there should be any bills deleted from the list until Senator Harradine formally moved an amendment.

PARA.TAB: In the spirit of what Senator Bourne said when she indicated that she was looking forward to the arguments that the government would be presenting and also in the spirit of what Senator Harradine has put forward let me, as briefly as I can but to ensure that we do this with total thoroughness, go to the key bills that you raised in your contributions a moment ago. In relation to the Airports Bill and the Airports (Transitional) Bill, these bills establish a regulatory framework and provide for the leasing process of the 22 federal airports currently owned by the Federal Airports Corporation and Sydney West airport. This is a major policy initiative, which the government believes will further enhance the development of a vital part of Australia's transport infrastructure.

By ensuring continuing government controls over key functions such as planning, pricing and, importantly, environmental management, the bills ensure that the public interest will not be compromised by commercial considerations. It was not possible to introduce this legislation earlier as the complexity of the legislation required extensive community consultation. The finalisation of the bills follows the same extensive consultation process with a range of interested parties including states, territories, local government, the aviation industry, community groups and potential investors.

In relation to the ANL Sale Bill 1995, it is proposed that the ANL Sale Bill be passed by both the House of Representatives and the Senate during the 1995 spring sittings of the parliament. The bill is to facilitate a sale of the Commonwealth shares in ANL Ltd to P&O Australia Ltd, a sale which has been deferred pending a satisfactory outcome from negotiations between ANL, unions and P&O on ANL's future industrial arrangements. That was announced on 31 August this year.

Legislation will be necessary to effect the sale, given the terms of the draft agreement for the sale of the Commonwealth shares, an agreement which has been negotiated with P&O. The draft sale agreement provides that P&O need not complete the agreement if the legislation has not been passed by both houses of parliament by the end of October 1995. There is, therefore, a considerable risk that the opportunity for a sale will be lost if the Commonwealth is not in a position to complete this process by that time. There is also a risk that P&O may not follow through with its offer if the bill is opposed or its passage is not facilitated as soon as possible.The passage of the sale legislation is, therefore, urgent and essential to enable a sale to proceed.

The bill was not introduced earlier as government decisions about a possible sale of ANL were made by the cabinet only at the end of August. The bill is also inextricably linked to the terms of the draft sale agreement with P&O. Final negotiations on this lasted until near the end of August. So it is for those reasons that those bills are included with the others to which attention has not been drawn. I accept that there is a general view amongst senators that the case that has been made in the statement of reasons provided to senators has been accepted in the case of the other legislation proposed to be before the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 June, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Science and Technology and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to table documents which contain government amendments to the Primary Industries and Energies Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995. I table the amendments forthwith. These amendments refer to the sections of the bill relating to the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act 1993. The amendments provide for the continuation of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation's chemical residue monitoring and educational programs which were to cease at the end of 1995. Under this amendment these activities will now be specified functions of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation, although it will not have any regulatory powers in that regard.

PARA.TAB: The second set of three amendments concerns the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967. The first of these amendments reflects the government's commitment to ensuring that the rights of indigenous Australians are protected when it comes to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act functions. That act will be amended to ensure that persons conducting offshore petroleum operations under the act will be required to respect and not unduly interfere with native title rights and interests when conducting these operations.

The second proposed amendment takes into account the government's responsibilities in regard to industrial health and safety. The third amendment deals with a revised system of awarding offshore petroleum exploration permits under the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act. This is known as the guaranteed work program bidding system. It was introduced by the government almost 10 years ago. Under that program, work program bidding differs from bidding in monetary amounts by indicating to the authority what amount of work will be done in the mining tenement by way of seismic or drilling to explore fully that tenement. Presumably the contract is won by those who have the most convincing bid on the amount of work. It is a different type of bid from that of bidding in money terms for the right to drill and explore in that area. There are amendments, as well, under the—

The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—The explanation of amendments usually takes place during the committee stage of the debate. I called you on the basis of providing an amendment to the committee to give it an opportunity to examine the amendment. I just point out to you that the usual procedure is that the explanation of amendments takes place during the committee stage of the evaluation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of that, Mr Acting Deputy President. My advice is that the agreed procedure for the moment was for a very brief explanation from me—not a full one—and this would enable Senator Tambling then to address those issues in his remarks during the second reading debate in this chamber.
—So that was agreed to by the whips this morning?
—That is my understanding.
—Thank you, continue.

—Perhaps I should have indicated to you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I did not want to put you in an embarrassing position. Let me continue with what I assure the Senate will be a brief explanation of the other amendments.

PARA.TAB: A further amendment is to the Export Control Act 1982. That deals with the government's announcement in the budget that a dedicated and independent monitoring unit would be established within the Department of Primary Industries and Energy to implement new monitoring arrangements to monitor compliance with hardwood woodchip licence conditions. The costs of the monitoring arrangements are to be recoverable from licensed hardwood woodchip exporters.

There is a set of amendments here concerning the Exotic Animal Disease Control Act 1989. In line with the five-year time frame of the exotic animal disease preparedness program, a number of sections of this act cease to have effect from 30 June 1995, and the amendments rectify that situation.

That concludes what is a thumbnail summary of these amendments. I obviously commend them to the chamber. I apologise for not informing you, Mr Acting Deputy President, of my understanding about the whips' arrangements on this. I commend the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The legislation before us, the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1995, has undergone dramatic change in recent weeks. I am pleased that you, Mr Acting Deputy President, picked that point up in the way in which it is being dealt with. In fact, I will deal with that as we go through.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, the original omnibus bill is scarcely recognisable today. The original bill was introduced into the House of Representatives on 8 March this year and it proposed to: firstly, change the way export inspection charges are imposed on certain fish exports in accordance with industry wishes to ensure equity; secondly, remove the need to register wool tax payments on sales of small amounts of wool to apply mainly to hobby farmers and others who occasionally remit small amounts of wool; and, thirdly, provide a rollover of wool tax collected for research and development in one year to later years.

While it is true that the bill remains committed to these objectives, the coalition questions the government's motives in now introducing a swag of very last minute amendments. As the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology, Senator Cook, has just alluded to, these new amendments radically alter the entire intent of the legislation.

These new amendments seek to: firstly, allow the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation to continue its role in chemical residue monitoring and education; secondly, give the minister the power to set charges to recover the cost of monitoring compliance with the conditions attached to woodchip export licences issued by the Commonwealth; and thirdly, include a series of administrative amendments to rectify the unintended consequences of the cessation of sections of the Exotic Animal Disease Control Act 1989 on 30 June this year. As the minister rightly pointed out, there are now three major amendments to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967, and I will deal with these later on.

It is fair to say that these amendments are not merely technical or housekeeping amendments, as you, Mr Acting Deputy President Watson, alluded to and presumed would have come up in the normal committee stage. The government has put forward these amendments and they represent significant new initiatives, and, as such, the government has an obligation to allow time for consultation and scrutiny.

We became aware that the government intended to move down this path on the last sitting day of the previous fortnight. Its motives were questioned and treated with suspicion by the Australian Democrats, by others and by myself when we saw the range of the new initiatives that were proposed, that had not been canvassed with any of us and that had not gone through the process of proper scrutiny by the shadow cabinet or party room debates in this area. So the government walked away from its obligation of consulting, which it normally does with processing in this area.

The coalition, after much wheeling and dealing in the last week of the last sitting fortnight, won that two-week reprieve to allow the new material to be examined in detail. While we support the original bill and the new government amendments that have been flagged today, we certainly did not support the way in which the government has ambushed this legislation in the Senate.

We have just now had for the first time an attempt at an additional second reading speech. The minister comes in and makes some comments in a very cursory way about adding new principles. Many parliamentarians and people outside the parliament have not seen copies of the new proposed legislation and have not had access to the explanatory memorandum. I certainly ask the minister to explain in his summing up any consultation process and the motives for bringing in this sort of legislation in this sort of manner.

It became very apparent to me in the wheeling and dealing of the last two or three weeks that obviously, in putting this legislation forward, it must have been tacked on in some way, both by cabinet and by caucus; and it certainly highlighted a number of differences between the ministers, Senator Collins and Mr Beddall, that have been going on as part of this process.

I would like to reflect on the original bill for a moment. The legislation that was passed by the House of Representatives proposes changes to the way export inspection charges are imposed on certain fish exports. Currently fish exporters pay a range of fees and charges to AQIS, including $15 per tonne of fish exported. Until now this fee has not been payable on exports through brokers. This legislation aims to close the loophole and ensure brokers and others pay their share of fees. It also reduces the tonnage fee from $15 to $10.

Turning to wool, it is worth noting that when this important industry was restructured, with the cooperation of the coalition, the government promised that Wool International would be privatised, most likely in 1997. It also promised that growers who paid wool tax for debt repayment between July 1993 and the date of privatisation would be given shares in the privatised company. Equity was to be determined by calculating the amount of wool tax payable by growers during that period.

Wool tax, for the purposes of debt servicing and repayment, is set at 4.5 per cent of sale price. However, the wool industry has grown increasingly concerned about the cost of registering the name and address of every person who sells a small amount of wool, particularly those who sell less than $500 per year. This legislation provides for regulations to specify an amount below which Wool International will not be required to automatically register wool tax payments. Individuals, however, can continue to register payments by request.

Under this legislation, the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act 1993 is to be amended to allow the board of AWRAP to meet outside Australia. This is appropriate in light of the amalgamation between AWRAP and the International Wool Secretariat.
