Another amendment brings the manner of paying research and development funds for wool into line with other research and development corporations by providing a rollover provision. This will ensure that the government matches dollar for dollar the amount contributed by woolgrowers for research and development up to a maximum of 0.5 per cent of gross value of production.

I now turn to the government amendments that have been put forward today—and that is the only way we can describe them. Earlier I outlined the main provision of the government amendments. I turn specifically to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967. These amendments seek to ensure that persons conducting offshore petroleum operations under the act respect and do not unduly interfere with native title rights and interests when conducting those operations; strengthen the minister's ability to make safety regulations under the act; and give legal force to the system of awarding offshore petroleum exploration permits to ensure that it is fully effective and adequately protects the rights of explorers. This final point is worth considering in detail.

Under the Petroleum (Submerged lands) Act of 1967 the federal government awards permits for companies to undertake offshore petroleum exploration in specified areas under the guaranteed work program bidding system. However, a loophole has emerged that potentially allows holders of exploration permits to surrender their permits at any time. This has caused a crisis of confidence in the bidding system. The purpose of amendments now before the Senate is to guarantee that agreed work programs will be carried out. The amendments do not vary the criteria on which bids for work programs are decided and should have no influence on the outcome of outstanding bids. The Australian Petroleum Production and Exploration Association supports this move and, more importantly, the resumption of the award of exploration permits by the Commonwealth.

While the federal coalition supports this legislation, we wish to place on record our criticism of the government's handling of this bill in the Senate by ambushing the legislation with a swag of last minute amendments that not only amended but totally transformed the bill. That point needs to be stressed. The government has revealed a dangerous disregard for proper parliamentary scrutiny. We trust that this is not a sign of things to come, particularly now as the government panics with its own legislative program—we have just seen that in the previous debate—in the lead-up to an election that the Australian Labor Party surely knows that it will lose.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the outset I would have to agree somewhat with Senator Tambling's concerns about the timing and methods used in bringing this legislation to the chamber. This omnibus bill amends bits of legislation and has been put into the Senate after the original bill was circulated. This legislation now contains Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act amendments and a few amendments to other acts which it did not originally contain. That brings some difficulties to those of us who want to contribute to the debate.

PARA.TAB: Originally this was outside any portfolio interest I had and any responsibility I had to comment. But now I see an opportunity to contribute, and that is what I will do. I will focus on schedule 5, the Export Control Act of 1982, which the government wants to amend to impose licence fees in connection with monitoring compliance on hardwood woodchip export licences. Those who have paid any attention to any of the work that I have done in this place would recognise my ongoing interest in and concern about the monitoring of the practices that are involved in deriving the subject of the woodchip export licences.

While we believe the principle of this amendment is sound and looks great and that it may go a tiny way towards making friends with some angry conservationists, the Democrats are cynical about the commitment of the government to actually do the monitoring and the prosecuting when there are breaches of licence conditions. We have had to push the government into investigating one saw miller in Tasmania, Barry Arnold, when there were clear breaches in Tasmania. We have had to force documentation from the government, like blood from a stone, about breaches in Western Australia. We have had to rub the nose of the government in the fact that there were breaches in the Wombat forest in Victoria. We have had to do that with no assistance in terms of resources or research opportunities from the government.

These several examples are perhaps the tip of the iceberg. Perhaps they are typical of common occurrences. We do not know. We cannot know. The government should know. What does it take to get this government to actively seek out licence offenders and to prosecute them for their offences? We have little faith in the government's commitment to prosecuting and persisting in the actions which are necessary to find out who should be prosecuted.

Last year Mr Beddall made a commitment to Australia on 20 December to have tough monitoring conditions. He has not kept that promise. He deferred the implementation of the establishment of the monitoring unit and, despite his promise in December last year with the 1995 licence, I hear he is going to re-announce it all again this year for the 1996 licences, in other words taking two bites at the same cherry, which has not even been produced yet. I do not know how we can believe him this time around.

For the record, the Democrats will agree to the government amendment. We could hardly do anything else. We need to see some action from the government straight away, when there are offences occurring. I do not want to have to take the trouble to stand here again and draw the minister's attention over and over again to breaches in licences which his department should be discovering. I do not want to have to force him to act because he has been embarrassed by the Australian Democrats over the issue. If there is a commitment the government, of its own volition, ought to be able to determine where the breaches are and take the appropriate action.

I am thankful that this chamber provides a forum for us to demonstrate where the breaches are. I am thankful that we have a democracy so that such a responsibility can be accepted by people like me. That should not be the way it works. If the government was committed to doing its job—following up on its own policies, enforcing its own laws and monitoring them—there would be no reason for people like me to have to accept that responsibility.

We have one amendment to this bill. While the government has the Export Control Act open on the table for amendment, we would like to amend it in line with Labor policy as stated by two Prime Ministers, Prime Minister Hawke and Prime Minister Keating. On 12 March 1991 Prime Minister Hawke made the `Building A Competitive Australia' statement. We would all be familiar with the statements made. He made this one in conjunction with the then Treasurer, Paul Keating, and the then industry minister, Senator Button. I quote from that statement:

SPEECH.PARA: There will also be provision in the legislation to establish plantations for long term timber supply. The objective is to phase out woodchip exports by the year 2000 or soon after and replace them with value added products. This new emphasis will take pressure off our native forests.

That is a direct quote from Prime Minister Hawke. On 22 December 1994 in his position as Prime Minister, Mr Keating gave that commitment again, although he was a little more subdued and qualified. It was not in the effusive style of Mr Hawke. Prime Minister Keating said:

By the year 2000 the Government will ban the export of woodchips from those areas of Australia's native forests which are not covered by Regional Forest Agreements incorporating a Reserve System that comprehensively represents all forest types.

Our amendment simply seeks to put this worthy ALP policy statement into legislation and seeks to prevent the export of woodchips from natural native forests by the year 2000. Since it is the stated policy of two Prime Ministers, I look forward to support from the ALP. It should support its own policy. In the committee stage I will move the amendment which has been circulated.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief on this matter. There are a couple of points I would like to make in addressing the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). It seeks to amend the Wool International Act 1993 to make provision for the regulations to specify an amount below which Wool International is not required to automatically register wool payments. I understand that that figure will be about $200. There has to be a figure, as far as I am concerned, because small amounts of wool come in at odd times. There is one bale here, two bales there and three bales there. What you have to remember is that probably those sellers will be around every year, even though they produce a small amount. I believe Wool International has to do that.

PARA.TAB: If I remember rightly, some $2 million to $5 million was spent by its forerunner on computer equipment before the collapse of the reserve price scheme. We were supposed to have a wool quota scheme. Can anyone remember that? It was about two or three years ago. A heap of computer equipment was purchased for that wool quota system. I understand it was used very little. So it would not be beyond the realm of possibility for Wool International to get a bit more organised.

I have declared my interest in the wool industry. I have also noticed that ever since this new system came in on 1 July 1993 you seem to finish up with a new wool tax number with every clip that is sold. I believe Wool International is not doing enough to sort out its own house in that respect.

At least once a year, or maybe twice a year, you are sent a form giving you your new wool information number—WIN is the proper term for it. They tell you that if you have any other numbers, you should consolidate them—there is a place on the form to consolidate the numbers you already have. Every time you get one of those forms you complete them to consolidate those numbers. Even when the new number is consolidated, the next time you sell a clip or a portion of a clip, even if it is 10 or 20 bales or whatever, you get another number. So they have a lot of work to do.

The fact is they have been silly. When filing in alphabetical order, they sometimes use the trading name, the surname or the first initial of the person concerned. For example, if there is a trading name of R.B. Jones and Co., sometimes they will file it under Jones and sometimes they will file it under `R' because that is the first initial. In this day and age that is a totally ridiculous situation. Wool International has to clean up its own house rather than impose limits for registering under under a certain amount.

When wool goes to auction, Wool International could ask for or demand an existing Wool International number. In other words, there would be a specification that the existing number be provided when wool goes on to the floor for sale—and most wool growers in Australia would have an existing number. Therefore, even if only one bale was sold, there would be no confusion with the minimal wool tax because credits would be made automatically rather than the growers having to request that amounts under $200, or whatever the figure may be, be credited against their name. If there was provision to ask for that number, all those sorts of problems would be overcome.

It is time Australian wool growers and Australia as a whole started to ask Wool International how the new scheme to get rid of the stockpile is working. Everyone involved in the rural industry will remember the collapse of the reserve price scheme and the fact that Wool International was set up and charged to unload the stockpile of some five million bales. So far it has worked reasonably well. The stockpile is now down to 2.8 million bales, and the price for wool going onto the export market, or wherever, is still reasonable.

Of late, Wool International has found it a bit difficult to forward sell its 185,000 bales per quarter—I think that is the right figure. A minor fiasco was caused last May when Wool International started unloading the wool at a fairly hefty discount as the sales for the season finished and there was that two-month break. I believe that the discount at the time was too heavy. That meant that when the market opened in August the price moved down far too quickly. It took a lot of value out of the woolclip. China's absence from the market, hopefully only temporarily, caused some of that concern and therefore the prices dropped.

Wool International has to really look at how it is going and see how it will handle future sales. It has put some wool on the auction market. I believe the proposition of putting wool that has been compressed into small bales on the auction floor is not very attractive. There are problems with the industry. Those problems are a big worry for the Australian wool industry, which has suffered a downturn of 200c a kilogram since last May. It is also a worry for Australia as a whole. It worries farmers who owe the banks a certain amount that their incomes will be cut further.

We cannot fix the price of wool from here, but we can point out that certain aspects of Wool International need to be looked at. I was the biggest supporter of the new scheme to unload the 185,000 bales per quarter. Hopefully we will get to the situation where there is no stockpile, or a minimum stockpile; because one of the lessons learnt from the late 1980s and early 1990s is that there will never be another stockpile in Australia as a result of the reserve price scheme. That scheme should have been wound up a lot earlier than it was. There are problems that have to be looked at.

The representatives of the growers have to look at what they are doing. The Wool Council of Australia, a subcommittee of the National Farmers Federation, has been involved in negotiations with Wool International on an ongoing basis. The week before last Wool International gave the Wool Council of Australia a very important briefing.

The Pastoralists and Graziers Association in Western Australia, which I happen to be a member of, has been asking for a while what Wool International and the Wool Council are doing. The representative of the Pastoralists and Graziers Association was excluded from the confidential briefing that Wool International gave the Wool Council of Australia two weeks ago simply because of comments he had made. I am not ashamed to say that this person is Barry Court. Whether he was excluded because he is the brother of the present Premier of Western Australia I do not know. I do not think so. I presume he was excluded because of the comments he made as the representative of the Pastoralists and Graziers Association of Western Australia, which I consider to be the best representative of the wool industry in Western Australia.

I was very annoyed that the Wool Council of Australia and the NFF agreed to have this confidential briefing when one person was excluded. I believe that the Wool Council of Australia should not have accepted the briefing when one of the members of the council, Barry Court, was excluded. I believe the Wool Council should have had the guts and gumption to say, `No, you can keep your confidential briefing until all the nominated members of the Wool Council of Australia are present.'

I put those few remarks on the record because I believe the Australian wool industry has a big future. It has provided a lot of export income for Australia in the last 180-odd years even though we have run into difficulties at various times. I know there were difficulties in the mid-1950s and the early 1970s and we now face difficulties in mid-1990s. These difficulties can be overcome and the wool industry can still return to its proper place in Australia; but we cannot go along with our minds shut. If it is necessary to finetune this legislation, which was instituted two years ago to unload Australia's wool stockpile, then let's do it. I support the bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McGauran Sen J.J.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is discussing the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation (Amendment) Bill which, as all other speakers have noted, is an omnibus bill which amends certain administrative elements of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. However, this second reading debate gives us an opportunity to speak on broader matters relating to our very vital primary industries. Given that the health of the Australian economy very much depends on our primary industry and our rural sector, it is worth spending some time on the matter.

PARA.TAB: Sixty-one per cent of Australia's export earnings are still derived, essentially, from the efforts and the production of those in the rural and regional areas. To put that in perspective and demonstrate its importance, Australia's ratio for primary industry exports, at 61 per cent—and this is an OECD figure—dwarfs the OECD average of 19 per cent. So you can see that Australia still very much rides on our rural industries. Specifically, the farm sector contributes 25 per cent of our export earnings. I believe that would go up to 30 per cent inclusive of forestry and the fishing industry.

It is not often readily acknowledged in this chamber that Australia's improved manufacturing contribution really stems from our rural sector. Our export earnings are predominantly in food value adding and, of course, all the raw materials come from our farm sector. Regrettably, the underlying fundamentals of the farm economy are still very poor. Many regions of Australia are still in drought and many are teetering on the edge of drought suffering all those consequences of that natural disaster.

One of the great long-term effects of the drought is and will be for some time to come the farm debt problem that we have in this country. The main cause of the accumulation of farm debt over the past decade has been spiralling interest rates. During the 1980s interest rates on farm overdrafts hovered around the 20 per cent mark. Due to several poor seasons on top of the recession, farmers were unable to trade their way out of this problem, as you would expect. In fact, even today the figures are poor and getting worse. The 1994-95 ABARE statistics farm survey report found that the average farm debt increased in that year some four per cent.

So even out of a recession and into a so-called recovery, farm debt has still been on the rise by some four per cent in the last 12 months to an average of $145,000, while profitability of farms, the ability to service that debt, has fallen from 64 per cent to 46 per cent. In gross terms—the larger figure—the Australian farm debt has reached some $17 billion.

At the present rate of compounding farm debt, the number of farmers will be likely to fall below the 100,000 mark by the year 2000, which will surely trigger a collapse in many of the services in our rural towns and trigger a population exodus. On a practical level, a continual exodus from our rural sector will place great burdens upon the major urban and metropolitan areas. This was the very point made by the Premier of New South Wales, Mr Carr, when he signalled a great concern about the extreme pressures on the services of Sydney simply because there is a cramming of the population into the Sydney metropolitan area. Hence, any significant decline in our non-metropolitan areas really does affect metropolitan Australia.

Let us look at the raw statistics that measure the seriousness of the decline in the number of our family farms. In March 1982, there were some 174,466 farms—predominantly family farmers—and by a decade later, in March 1992, Australian farm numbers had collapsed to 122,053, and that figure is continuing to tumble.

We so often hear from the government the concept of a new-age farmer with high tech machinery and a computerised business operation, but that is not happening. In fact, the new-age farmer is failing under the weight of debt and falling income. The average tractor age, which is always a good benchmark, is some 13 years; yet the tractor is the most used and productive piece of machinery on all farms. That is why it is such a good benchmark but at that rate the tractors will be declared vintage. Yet the worth of the family farmer as an efficient, social and economic unit is measurable. A factor recognised by both sides of the house is that the family farmer is a tangible asset to Australia's economic and social wellbeing.

A report on the adequacy of the rural adjustment scheme and the extent of rural debt was handed down by my National Party colleague Senator Brownhill, who is chair of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport References Committee. That committee travelled the country gathering a great deal of information on the great concerns about rural debt across Australia. I would like to refer to one witness who came before that committee, Sister Marjorie Hennessy. She pretty well summed up the ongoing concerns in rural Australia when she expressed her concerns about the longer term implications of the current rural crisis. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . we are losing skill and expertise of thousands of farmers. Farmers are dispossessed, families are displaced, millions of hectares of lands are being reallocated and we are not sure to whom . . . A kind of a social revolution is taking place without our knowledge or our full realisation that this is so.

The National Party—indeed, the coalition—has been extremely aware of this seemingly insurmountable financial crisis facing the rural sector. To that end, the coalition—as announced by my leader, Tim Fischer, on 8 October—will as an absolute priority in the first 100 days of a coalition government bring together a rural financial crisis summit to address the problems that agriculture faces in rebuilding after the drought and after the recession. I quote from the speech that my leader gave:

The summit will be convened within the first 100 days of a coalition government. It will address the immediate effects and consequences of the drought, but its primary focus will be on the longer term financial structure facing agriculture. The farm sector is famous for its ability to recover from drought. But this time around, so many farms went into several years of drought in such poor financial circumstances—thanks to the high interest rates of the late 1980s—that there is a real doubt about their viability to fund a recovery. This is now a national problem because of the implications it holds for regional communities and the environment in regional areas.

That should also be a concern to the Greens senators in this chamber. Interrelated with the debt plight of the rural sector has been the decline over the past decade or more in the terms of trade for farmers. The National Farmers Federation estimate that business margins for Australian farmers have dropped by more than 90 per cent in the past 40 years. To put that in perspective, the Victorian Farmers Federation have said that, as a rule of thumb, to buy a new Holden ute in 1974 would have cost 12 bales of wool or 41 tonnes of wheat but, 20 years later in 1994, the same Holden ute would cost 42 bales of wool or 177 tonnes of wheat.

PARA.TAB: ABARE forecast farm costs for 1995-96 are set to rise by some 5.2 per cent, far outstripping their forecast for price increases of 1.8 per cent. I have to think, now that we are well into the 1995-96 year, that the estimate that costs would rise by 5.2 per cent was conservative. I would say, from anecdotal evidence, that it is far more than that. What it means is that farmers' profit margins will continue to trend down and there is no light at the end of the tunnel.

Even for the most buoyant of farmers, like the dairy farmers in Gippsland who have seen some good seasons of late where debt and drought are of less concern to them, the great complaint is related to continual rising costs and overheads to operate the farm against the very negligible rise in prices. As a measure of the cost structures farmers face within a particular sector we need only look to the beef industry. The high cost structures of this industry affect not only the prices farmers receive for their product, but the volume they are able to export overseas.

The root of this problem has been debated in the chamber before: basically the abattoir costs—production costs. The figures I take are from the Booz Allen and Hamilton report that was recently tabled in this parliament by the minister. It states that on a per kilo finished weight basis, the cost of our meat processing is highly uncompetitive. For Australia the cost is 113c per kilo; for Argentina—one of our major competitors, if not our major competitor—it is 105c per kilo; for New Zealand, just across the waters, it is 72c per kilo; and for the United States it is 41c per kilo.

We reached an absurd situation last year when the United States-owned Sizzler chain of restaurants decided to import United States beef into Australia around Christmas time because that was cheaper than buying it here. They were able to supply all their chains throughout Australia with United States beef. Even though they were paying the American farmer 60 per cent more for beef than they were paying the Australian farmer, they were still able to bring it to this country cheaper than they could buy it in Australia.

Sizzler were able to buy beef from the American farmer for 60 per cent more, put it through their own abattoirs, move it to their wharfs, ship it across the Pacific and then onto our wharfs, pass meat inspection and then distribute it through the Sizzler restaurant chain still cheaper than the Australian industry can provide it.

For further evidence of this absurdity you have only to look at the growing trend of meat exports. So expensive are the Australian abattoirs and processing chains that it is now a far more viable option to export live cattle to Asia. This is a growing trend. Backing up the Booz Allen and Hamilton report, the government's own Industry Commission report on the meat processing sector says that if we brought in fundamental change to the cost structures, we would have savings of some $1.5 billion per year.

I mentioned the American industry being able to export beef to this country—getting it past their wharves and our wharves—more cheaply than the Australians can produce it. There is another great cost for the Australian beef farmer and the Australian farmer in general. Australian farmers have to compete with the world market when they simply cannot get product past our wharves without 50 percent, 60 per cent, sometimes even 100 percent, being added on to the cost. Australian wharves are so inefficient. The Bureau of Industry Economics, in its report entitled International Benchmarking—Waterfront 1995, has this to say about just one indicator of how inefficient Australian wharves are:

SPEECH.PARA: The greatest concern with Australia's performance must lie with stevedoring productivity where crane rates . . . declined during 1994 and fell back to around 1991-92 levels

Crane rates at the best performing Australian container terminal (18.5 moves per hour at Fremantle) is equivalent to some of the poorest performances in Europe—and in America. How can our rural sector possibly compete internationally when our wharves are that inefficient?

PARA.TAB: The third underlying fundamental problem in the farming sector, having touched on debt and farm costs, is, of course, our competitiveness on international markets. Great promise was held out to the farming sector with the introduction of GATT and the World Trade Organisation that hundreds of millions, if not billions of dollars, would be coming their way. The farming sector undertook great restructuring at a very high price to meet the demands of the World Trade Organisation. Of course, it is now looking increasingly like they are being let down. They will be let down unless we have a very firm government with conviction to protect our rural sector from the fix that it is in. We have been let down by some of our closest allies, no less, in the market. The United States, of course, are backing up their rural sector with various and different export enhancement programs, in the dairy and wheat industries in particular. Regardless of commitments made, they are intruding on our Asian and Middle Eastern markets.

It is incumbent upon the government, then, to vigorously oppose these moves and to stand up for our farming sector on every stage and at every conference possible. That is why it is a great disappointment that the government have seen fit to withdraw our ambassador from the United States. If that is the worth that the government places on his appointment, probably he should never have gone there. They have withdrawn him at short notice, at such a crucial time of negotiations with APEC and the WTO, simply on political grounds. What they should have done in the beginning was to appoint someone for the long term for the good of the Australian farm sector who would represent us in Washington and would not be a fly-by-night like the current ambassador to America.

All in all, the farm sector still needs a great deal of focus and concentration. It does seem, as former Senator Richardson put it very well in one of his articles, that this government has no concern for the farm sector, because it does not vote for them. They do not believe they will get any more than one per cent of the Australian rural sector voting for them. That has been shown over the last decade or more of this government. It is time for a change. We have made a commitment that, within the first 100 days of a new government, a financial summit recognising the seriousness of the problems of the rural sector will be held and certain policies will be formulated and help given to the rural sector to make it viable for the next decade.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address a most serious concern for all Australian primary industries, and that is the issue of quarantine policy. In 1988, the Labor government changed its quarantine policy from no risk to an acceptable or minimal risk. Minimal risk is considered to be the point at which the potential risk posed to the nation by a proposed import is small enough to be manageable. AQIS, in making this decision, must, firstly, consider the biological factors and, secondly, the economic and social consequences that flow from the biological considerations.

PARA.TAB: Another relevant factor in quarantine policy is that under GATT a country cannot use its quarantine policy as a non-tariff barrier. Quarantine standards must be justified on a scientific basis. I raise these changes to our quarantine policy in the context of loud concerns from many Australian primary industries. Many have had draft papers prepared by AQIS, which relax quarantine measures and will, in effect, allow imports from a wide range of countries. They are often smaller primary industries, with all of them pointing to the very real risk of disease being introduced into their industries from imports.

The pork, chicken meat and salmon industries have all expressed serious concerns, which have been backed up by scientific evidence, about quarantine changes in the pipeline that threaten the present relatively disease-free status of the industries. These concerns are very real to these industries. Frightening scenarios emerge from studies done by ABARE, the government's agricultural economic research body, on the economic effects of the most serious exotic diseases in these industries being introduced into Australia. For example, should Newcastle disease occur in Australia, under present quarantine conditions, according to ABARE, the $1 billion Australian poultry and egg industries would suffer economic losses of $69 million in the first year. Consumers would lose $109 million, or $6 per person, due to higher prices. ABARE estimates that, should quarantine requirements change, imports would quickly grow to 20 per cent of domestic consumption. An outbreak of this disease would see a total loss of $93 million to producers if cooked imports were allowed. This would rise to $169 million if cooked and frozen imports were allowed in.

Even more frightening scenarios emerge from what has already happened to some Australian industries because of the introduction of diseases and pests. Just this morning, a flower grower sent me a box of flowers that had been infected by thrips. I will table a letter from him at a later date.

Two years ago, the Australian flower industry had a rosy future with increased domestic and export markets. Today it has been devastated in certain areas by the introduction of thrips. If we now have a disease that had not previously existed, it must have come from somewhere. In two years, thrips has spread all around Australia; there is no cure for it. Australian growers have been forced to apply large doses of very strong chemicals to reduce by 50 per cent the occurrence of thrips on their flowers. This is four times the level whereby a flower can be affected and is therefore saleable.

Growers have lost entire rows of plantings. It is moving onto chrysanthemums, baby's breath and all other species. Growers in Queensland have been excluded from Tasmanian and Victorian markets. They are reduced to selling their flowers produced from a three-month cooler period when thrips can be held under control with cooler conditions. These flower growers have invested huge sums into their flower businesses and they have become the victims of inadequate inspections of imports by AQIS and, it seems, the non-existence of import protocols for imports.

The damage will not stop at flowers. Thrip is a ready vehicle for the transfer of other diseases. Our vegetable industry is now threatened by the widespread occurrence of thrip. It is now only a matter of time until we have similar problems with our vegetable industry. This is exactly what happened in Hawaii where the lettuce industry was written off because of the introduction of thrip.

Does the government quarantine policy have the right to take away the livelihoods and investments of Australian flower growers because it is sloppily imposed? Are there any protocols on the importation of flowers from countries where these diseases are known to exist? Surely examples such as the flower industry provide enough scientific evidence for a sensible quarantine policy that is scientifically justifiable.

Although I wish only to emphasise the disease risk arising from changing our quarantine requirements, there is a real world out there where, for example, chicken meat imports from Denmark, the United States, and Thailand—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—Before you go on, I think you might seek leave to table your paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to table the paper.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —which have all requested a relaxation of quarantine controls—have an enormous advantage in the huge subsidies and assistance given by their home governments. Chicken growers in the United States reap the competitive benefit of the government's export enhancement program which recently was subsidising chicken meat exports at 96c a kilogram into Saudi Arabia, 109c into Oman and Bahrain, and 79c into Singapore. The European Community gives higher subsidies by means of import levies and Thai industry receives great tax advantages—amongst others, encouraging large Japanese involvement in their industry.

PARA.TAB: The recent report from CEDA on APEC evaluates the effect on regional trade barriers into Asia from the perspective of Australian business. It has not only pointed out the extremely high tariffs into most Asian countries where we hope to further develop our export markets, but it also reinforces the damaging trade environment created by export enhancement subsidy programs of the United States government. For example, Australian exporters are met with average tariffs on food products of 50 per cent into Japan, 40 per cent into South Korea, 34 per cent into Malaysia, 34 per cent into Thailand, 33 per cent into the Philippines and 15 per cent into India.

With our continuing success in Asian markets with our food products, in spite of high tariffs and in spite of the US export subsidy scheme, the government needs to be reminded of the relevance of the words of the NFF when it said:

SPEECH.PARA: Governments must enhance not squander Australia's comparative advantage in food production.

That is a comment that is equally true when it comes to realistically and truthfully assessing the disease risks to our Australian industries from the expansion of imports as a consequence of changed quarantine requirements.

PARA.TAB: Australia, an island nation, has the competitive and comparative advantage of being virtually disease free. For this reason, its primary industries are the envy of all our competitors. We must maintain these high quality health standards set over the last 90 years through our quarantine inspection service. We must maintain the advantage of clean, green, disease free products and not jeopardise it by allowing exotic diseases to be introduced through quarantine changes which are highly questioned by scientific evidence and which would clearly put it all at risk.

The most recent illustration of disease entering Australia through imports is the massive pilchard kill that extended from Western Australia to Noosa in Queensland in the middle of this year. I questioned the minister about its cause when it was at its peak—when he effectively said that the scientific jury was still out. However, in recent weeks the Four Corners program has made some alarming allegations. The program presented scientists who stated that there was a very strong probability that the kill was the result of disease introduced by imported pilchards. There were further allegations of vastly differing scientific opinion from those expressed in the final AQIS paper from the state agricultural departments of Tasmania, New South Wales and Western Australia—an opinion supported by Dr Humphrey who, since 1992, has conducted a detailed study on the importation of aquatic animals and their products for AQIS and the government.

According to Four Corners, scientists from these state departments disagreed strongly with AQIS recommendations, threatening to make a dissenting report that an exotic pathogen could not be discounted as the cause. The extent of scientific disagreement between scientists in the field and AQIS must raise grave doubts about the basis of all their draft papers in the pipeline recommending lifting imports in the salmon, pork and chicken meat industries—such as the AQIS report which found negligible risk from Canadian and American salmon imports, which is opposed by everyone in Tasmania who knows anything about the salmon industry. It is an industry that has spent over 20 years quarantining its stock to establish a unique disease free salmon export industry in Tasmania.

You have the chief executive officer of the Tasmanian Department of Fisheries telling Four Corners, `The AQIS officers concerned, the technical experts, have made an assessment. We believe and have clearly demonstrated that technically, they've got it very, very wrong.' He goes on:

SPEECH.PARA: Now it's pretty much about AQIS protecting their own professional integrity—so it's going to be very difficult for them to climb down from the recommendations that they've made but clearly on the evidence which we've put before them, we're hoping that will come about.
Mr Minister, we cannot allow the important issue of quarantine for important Australian primary industries to rest on a department losing face—there is too much at risk for everyone.

PARA.TAB: I would like to raise several other important issues here. Firstly, the downsizing and under-resourcing of AQIS.As pointed out by a former AQIS director, Bill Gee, `If they are downsizing AQIS resources and if state animal health resources are reducing, no governments are going about it the right way.' This was reinforced by Dr Humphrey, the consultant to AQIS, who said, `Developing industries, by their very nature, will have emerging disease problems. And to be protected from new and existing disease problems they deserve an increasing resource base to address and protect them.' If this is the considered scientific advice, why is the government cutting AQIS staff by a third when imports have increased by 40 per cent? Why is it cutting funds to the CSIRO for research? Why is this being done at a time when the government has put our economy into such a parlous state? Our export trade is our lifeline and must be able to continue to rely on our clean, green, disease free status.

This year we have had the graphic illustration of the massive pilchard kill—the biggest fish kill ever seen in the world. We had the government's response of a task force and AQIS report—a report prompting a senior research scientist in the NSW Department of Agriculture to take the step of faxing AQIS, `The overall conclusions appear to have been sanitised for political consumption.' We have senior scientists going public to expose their enormous concern at the downplaying of the cause of the pilchard kill being the probability of disease from a virus, and an imported virus at that.

Since June this year I have been questioning Senator Collins on the reasons for the pilchard kill—whether the Humphreys report which had been under way since 1992 had given any warnings on disease risk from imported fish or fish products;whether it should have alerted the government to inspect imported fish products which they did not do till mid way through this year. I have been asking why AQIS could not release the draft Humphrey report.I have been pointing out indications from CSIRO scientists that an exotic virus may have been the cause. I have drawn attention to calls from CSIRO scientists of our dangerously lax quarantine standards and calls for a significant review.

All the time the minister, with more information at his fingertips than me, downplayed the possibility of exotic disease being the cause of the massive pilchard kill.Now we have allegations that the AQIS report was sanitised for political consumption; that revelations of threats and dissenting opinions that an exotic pathogen could not be discounted; that AQIS has to stick to its position to not lose face; that Dr Humphreys after a three-year study for AQIS on importing fish warned of the serious threat of introducing diseases by feeding killed fish to captive marine species and that the practice should not occur.

These are most serious allegations. Many industries will be put at risk from changes in the government's quarantine policy and this is how the government is treating it. With cover ups, with defensiveness and only allowing the one side of the scientific argument to be exposed, that suits its purposes.

It is disappointing that the review of our quarantine policy, as was recommended in the 1988 Lindsay report, to take place this year has not been approved by cabinet as yet.The minister has promised the Senate and the farmers organisations and affected industries it will take place.However, we were told by AQIS at a Senate committee hearing two weeks ago that the proposed review is only under consideration by the minister and that he has not taken the proposed review to cabinet as yet. It is also disappointing to be told by AQIS at the same committee hearings that changes in the pipeline—such as for the Tasmanian salmon industry—will proceed regardless of the findings of this review.

May I remind the Senate that at stake here is the future state of health of Australia's primary industries, its wildlife, its marine environment and the future export success of all Australian primary products. If there has been a sanitising of the issue for political reasons as told to the Four Corners program by senior government scientists, this is no way to run our quarantine policy.

Rural industries are very concerned about quarantine policy for their particular industries. The minister has spoken of a review as a certainty, yet according to AQIS it still has not been approved by cabinet. The government should respect the genuine concerns of rural industries about any quarantine changes. The government should also heed the call of its own senior CSIRO scientists for a significant review of our quarantine policies and the lax state of present policy. As well, the government should reassure all Australians that any future quarantine changes will be based on consideration of all scientific evidence and that this whole messy business will be cleaned up.

I raise these important issues because they are of great concern to a number of Australian farmers and to a number of Australian industries that have grave concerns about the downgrading of the import protocols. I raise these issues because I believe they are causing great concern out in the industry. The minister now has to take some direct responsibility in bringing forth some form of report. I believe there is a Lindsay report on foot, yet I have been told that the recommendations in that Lindsay report are not going to be adhered to in the near future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some comments concerning the amendments to the Wool International Act 1993 in this omnibus legislation. The four key roles of Wool International, which was set up in July 1993, were: firstly, the management of the wool stockpile; secondly, to introduce, encourage and facilitate alternative marketing methods for the selling of wool; thirdly, the privatisation of Wool International at the appropriate time; and, fourthly, the management of Wool International's non-wool assets.

PARA.TAB: It is the first of these responsibilities that has created considerable criticism. Wool International's recent selling program has been a major cause of the current—and, I believe, temporary—collapse in wool prices. This present price collapse may appear to be a ho-hum event to observers of the wool industry since the absolute collapse of the wool price in 1990, but to growers, many of whom are still in the grip of drought and have had some four years of drought, this is really a very unfair and unnecessary, I believe, collapse in prices. Growers wonder why they continue to grow a fibre when they have such limited control over their destiny.

The market indicator price has presently fallen below 600c, which is a psychological level from which it is hard to build confidence. This is 200c below the June close figure of about 820c. The real key at this stage is that the market fundamental of confidence is lacking.

The wool market has three elements. The first two are the growers and the buyers, and it has this sort of third man of confidence which sits out there in never-never land. When confidence disappears, the market reacts like the market for any commodity: if you want the commodity, you pay for it; if you don't want the commodity, the price collapses. You have speculation in reverse.

One of the most worrying aspects of the current market situation is the serious losses being incurred by merchants and processors due to the sudden cancellation of contracts for raw or semi-processed wool. Although China is the prominent culprit, cancellations have also been reported from India and Korea.

A continuation of these periodic occurrences of reneging on contracts has a lasting and damaging impact on the industry. Not only does it cause financial losses, but it inhibits this third man of confidence, reduces the availability of capital, raises the cost of wool trading and discourages forward trading—a vital element of effective wool marketing.

The wool market must move away from its near total reliance on the auction system. After 150 years of wool being grown in this country, we still have 85 per cent of woolgrowers accepting a spot price. It is in the interests of growers and buyers to have some form of more sophisticated risk management and risk management tools. Although risk management or contracts or forward trading frightens growers because it is something they don't understand, it is essential for the future of their industry.

There have been a number of statements concerning the role of Wool International and its selling schedule which is required under the legislation that we are talking about. There has been pressure from exporters and brokers about reducing the amount of wool being sold. I personally don't agree with that one bit. The actual Garnaut proposals have worked extremely well in the interests of the reduction of the stockpile and the debt.

The other suggested reason for the price collapse has been that China has been a reluctant buyer in the market. I believe that, regardless of the role of Wool International and the stockpile, there would still have been a correction in the price because China has basically been out of the market. The reason for that is that the central government in China has increased the tariff by 10 per cent on raw wool and imposed a 17 per cent VAT. As far as Chinese instrumentalities buying wool are concerned, it was immediately going to be 27 per cent more expensive to them. The tariff was always meant to be paid by Chinese buyers to their central government, but wasn't, and it is now being cracked down on.

One of the interesting things is that it is not just China that is out of the market. The ABS figures on exports to our major trading wool partners in July-August show that China has been down by 28 per cent, but that Italy has been down by 26 per cent, Japan by 35 per cent, and France by 25 per cent; and overall in July-August there has been a 14.3 per cent drop over last year's exports.

We have about 35 other markets apart from those that I have mentioned. They have had some slight increase to meet those substantial falls from our major exporting partners. In addition, the Russian wool industry has been in a position to export and has done so substantially to both China and Western Europe, an inferior quality wool. This puts into perspective the sorts of demands that are made on the Australian wool industry by our buyers about quality being the key and our buyers' requirements for high quality Australian wool. It is interesting that they have been prepared to accept Russian wool of a very inferior quality and to pay not a lot less for it. The experts suggest that the Russian wool industry is not very buoyant. The amount of their wool that has been sold will not be repeated in the years ahead.

Wool International has been accused of selling forward at a discount to meet its reduction timetable. It has rejected this allegation but I guess it is semantics. It has been selling at a price at which it can make its sales. The criticism has been made that, if that is the case, how can the auction system survive against it? Wool International then took the decision to sell a weekly amount at auction. The price continued to fall, despite the fact that Wool International's reserves were at a premium at the auction price. So it was not the fault of Wool International that the price was falling.

Ultimately our buyers will realise that they have to start to buy and the market will start to rise. Once our buyers see that it has reached the bottom, the wool market could turn around very quickly. If we had an active forward market, growers and buyers would not have the fluctuations, the crashes, which cost them so much and make it virtually impossible for efficient management and family farmers who wish to plan for the future to see their bank managers with confidence.

There has been a lot of comment in the industry about how you manage this sort of crisis. I make the point about needing some forward marketing tools and I defend the role of Wool International. They have done a very good job in the two years they have been operating. There are a lot of vested interests, a lot of baggage, in the wool industry, which tends to look for scapegoats. I guess in any industry that has gone through the turmoil that the wool industry has that is probably understandable. A lot of vested interests would like to see Wool International removed from the marketplace. Very often with brokers and buyers—especially brokers—trying to explain to an irate grower why the price fluctuates so much it is easy to find a bogeyman in Wool International. We have had criticism that Wool International should operate behind closed doors, that we should not know what they are doing in the marketplace. On the other hand that their operation in the marketplace should be completely transparent.

I would like to end on a confident note. In times like these woolgrowers feel depressed and worried about their future. But apart from what I have mentioned there are several reasons why wool textiles are poised to achieve a modest turnaround in the next two or three months. There are instances of retail optimism in our traditional markets. Consumption is already at a low base. Retailers are not heavily stocked and are in a better position to respond positively if the world economy has even a modest recovery.

I am told that the medium to long-term wool pipeline, of about 18 months, is certainly not overburdened with wool and that any price movement or any restoration of confidence will require this pipeline to be fed. Contrary to some reports, in the textile pipeline there are generally acceptable levels. There are exceptions such as greasy wool and worsted yarn in Japan and wool top in France. Most orders are being met from production, not stocks. The wool is being used as it comes out of the factory.

The downward adjustment of prices that we have seen in 1995, particularly in fine wools, and the continuing relatively high price of synthetic fibres have caused a significant reduction in the wool-synthetic price ratio. I am told that there has been some substitution back to wool in the fibre choice stakes already.

Overhanging wool textile demand for 1996 is the stark reality of a further reduction in the global availability of wool as wool production continues to decline in virtually all wool exporting countries. That is certainly the case in Australia.

Whilst it is very hard to get a real handle on the fall in any wool production, all the experts suggest there will be at least a 20 to 25 per cent reduction in new wool coming onto the Australian market in 1995-96. To put that into perspective, that is about 600 million kilos. Australia has sold, over the last five years, about 850 million kilos if you add what came out of the stockpile, which was about 150 million kilos. It means that this year we will place in the market well below the amount of wool we have traditionally—traditionally over the last five years—sold.

The reality is that even a modest recovery in demand for wool is likely to exceed available supplies at current prices. The crucial missing factor is market confidence. Once that is restored textile activity will lift and prices will begin to rise, led initially by fine wool which will be most affected by the reduced availability in 1996, especially if the drought continues to break and the fibre diameter starts to broaden.

Demand from China clearly continues to be the key to recovery, but it is not the only key. I believe that when the trigger comes—in the first instance, it will probably come from Europe—there will be a sustained recovery, and China will re-enter the market and again play a very important part as our major or near major wool buyer in 1996-97.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been following the debate both in the chamber and on the screen in my office. I want to respond to some points made by the various speakers in their contributions.

PARA.TAB: I will start with the speaker who has just concluded, Senator Sandy Macdonald. I would have to say that overall it was a well thought out and well considered contribution to the debate.
As regards Senator Panizza—I am in a charitable mood today—the less I say about Senator Panizza's contribution, the better.

I cannot agree with Senator McGauran's emphasis that the high interest rates of the 1980s were totally or almost exclusively responsible for the farm debt. There are a number of other complex issues. Overall, your contribution was balanced, except for that emphasis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Out of 10?

—Out of 10 it would be a seven—at least seven or eight for interest and five or six for accuracy. If we are talking about the issue of farm debt and acknowledge the difficulties in that sector, drought is a very serious problem as well as the continuing low prices in many commodity areas of Australia, of which wool is obviously one.

PARA.TAB: While I am talking about drought, I was in North Queensland for four days last week. I had the opportunity to visit Cairns and Tully—banana country. I spent some time with those banana growers with whom we have developed a good working relationship since some initial problems three years ago, which I will not go into in this chamber. I then went down to Townsville and had a look at the difficulties in the meat industry, and I am not going to take the time of the Senate to talk about that today either.

I also visited the town of Monto, which is about four hours drive west of Bundaberg, mainly to meet women's groups and to look at the local drought conditions. I want to thank publicly Jan Darlington, who is very active in the community of Monto, for arranging a morning tea-luncheon and community meeting in the afternoon. At least 100 people from the local township of Monto came and gave me a variety of submissions not only on drought policy but also on a range of other issues that are important to the rural and regional sector.

To return to the legislation, I will leave Senator Bell's and Senator Tambling's contributions. Senator Boswell gave a very lengthy exposition of what our supposed quarantine policy is. I do not want to go into all the details here and now but I do want to correct Senator Boswell. He said that we have abandoned our no risk quarantine policy. Senator Boswell should know we have never had a no risk quarantine policy. We have had a minimal or acceptable risk policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is hard to describe your policy.

—You have exactly the same policy as we do on this issue, Senator Abetz. I fully support acceptable and no risk policy based on sound scientific analysis. That is your policy as well, so it is totally incorrect for Senator Boswell to claim we had a no risk policy up until 1988. We could introduce a no risk policy. It would be very easy to do it. You would allow no mail into the country. You would allow no-one to leave or enter the country. You would allow no food exports from this country or no food imports into this country. If that is what Senator Boswell and the National Party are advocating, you would reach a ridiculous position with quarantine policy.

PARA.TAB: What is amusing about Senator Boswell's approach, if it was not so serious, for example, is that he says we should not allow pork imports into Australia on the basis of quarantine risk. There may or may not be valid arguments for that but we continually look ridiculous in the eyes of the international community because the pork industry says, `Let wheat imports in because we need the wheat to feed the pigs,' but some sectors of the wheat industry come along and say, `Don't let the wheat in because of the quarantine risk.' So the pork industry is saying, `Don't let the Canadian pork in but let the wheat in'—which the wheat industry argues is a quarantine risk—`so we can feed our pigs.' So Senator Boswell has given us a totally contradictory position on that sort of issue.

Nevertheless, the legislation before us is not central to quarantine policy. I have to at least highlight some of the contradictory positions of Senator Boswell on this issue. If we applied the sorts of things Senator Boswell advocates in the quarantine area, we would not be allowed to export anything out of this country. If other countries applied the sorts of principles Senator Boswell wants to practice with imports, other countries would do exactly the same and we would export absolutely nothing. The trouble for Senator Boswell is he wants to have it both ways all the time. He plays populace rhetoric out in the bush. Of course, National-Liberal Party policy is very different when you come to this place.

Senator Tambling criticised us for additions to the legislation. Those additions were amendments with respect to the Wool Research and Promotion Organisation allowing the undertaking of residue monitoring.
Debate interrupted.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—Order! It being 12.45 p.m., we will now proceed to debate matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz Sen E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today in this matter of public interest debate I wish to address the matter of the administration in the office and department of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Sciacca). The minister has in recent times received many accolades for the taxpayer funded `Australia Remembers' campaign. This campaign is undoubtedly worth while although some would argue somewhat politicised by Mr Sciacca.

PARA.TAB: The minister has presented himself to the people of Australia, and indeed the world, as the smiling, `butter would not melt in my mouth' fellow. Loves shaking hands does our minister, especially when handing out taxpayers' money. The more pomp and ceremony associated with the handing out of taxpayers' money the better.

Behind this smiling facade is a man who all of a sudden becomes media shy and runs from the glare of the lights when the focus is placed on his administrative capacities or otherwise and the costs to the taxpayers that flow as a consequence. In recent times we had a feature article in the Australian exposing the lack of ministerial direction at the Australian War Memorial. Allegations of workplace harassment have plagued the Australian War Memorial.

When problems associated with the Merit Protection Review Agency inquiry were raised with Mr Sciacca he said that he took a deliberate decision not to intervene. A Federal Court judgment cleared the names of those against whom allegations had been made. But it also raised questions about the performance of two federal ministers—Mr Johns and Mr Sciacca. To quote Michael Gordon, political editor with the Australian:

SPEECH.PARA: The more poignant section of the judgment asks just why there was no action by those in positions of power and responsibility to respond to the concerns of Kelson and McKernan without the matter having to be settled in the Courts.

The minister's excuse—I took a very deliberate decision not to intervene. The non-intervention cost the taxpayers of this country thousands of dollars. While the minister was busy glad handing people and spreading cheques like confetti he was, according to him, deliberately not involving himself in the administrative problems of his department. I say to the minister: if you want the salary, the limousine, the VIP jet, the taxpayers' money to hand out, then do what you are duty bound to do—that is, administer your department.

PARA.TAB: The War Memorial fiasco is not the only example. Some three or so months ago I raised the issue of the dismissal of Ms Fiona Hitchen from the office of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. As a result of my expression of interest in the matter, I have been provided with further and more detailed information which gives me great cause for concern about administration within the minister's office. It is noteworthy that Labor's new unfair dismissal legislation applies to members of parliamentary staff. It is just so typical that the first member of parliament to fall foul of this legislation should be a Labor minister. Labor is always so strong on the rhetoric but always so very different in practice. It is no wonder the blue-collar voter is deserting Labor and the trade union movement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do as I say, not do as I do.

—That is exactly right, Senator Patterson. I understand that Ms Hitchen commenced her political involvement as a professional assistant to Senator Gareth Evans in 1990. From there she moved to personal secretary to the federal secretary of the ALP, then to Minister Collins's office and then to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs' office. So she had a track record of some five years of being involved with the Labor Party, their ministers and their organisational structure.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, I am reliably informed that on occasions ministers such as Graham Richardson and Robert Ray involved themselves to assist in finding her placements. Hardly the actions one would anticipate from such hard-playing and callous ministers as Richardson and Ray.

In 1994 Ms Hitchen became the personal secretary to Con Sciacca. On the first day of December 1994, she was dismissed in breach of Labor's new unfair dismissal legislation. Ms Hitchen, whilst taking a one week break, was told over the telephone not to bother coming back to work and to clear her desk out on a Sunday so as not to cause any `difficulty' in the office.

Undoubtedly, the minister's office had pre-planned to tell this lady she would be dismissed whilst she was on holidays. As I understand it, while she was on holidays she rang into the office every day to make sure everything was okay. And on the fourth day she is advised, `Don't bother coming back. And when you empty out your desk, make sure it's on a Sunday so nobody else in the office has the opportunity to talk to you.' That is the sort of industrial relations that the Australian Labor Party in office practices.

The person who advised Ms Hitchen of her dismissal was Greg Rudd the senior adviser in the minister's office. It is interesting to note that he is the brother of Kevin Rudd, a federal Labor candidate in Queensland. It is all within the family up there in Queensland!

In typical Labor Party style, in dismissing Ms Hitchen without any reasons as to why or counselling or disciplining her in any way—if that was warranted—she was provided a job in the Department of Veterans' Affairs. It was promised to her on a permanent basis but then, in fact, it only became a three-month contract.

I have reason to believe that the contract was signed on 5 December 1994, some four days after she was told that she was dismissed from the minister's office. If she was not good enough for the minister's office, why on earth was she good enough for the department? The normal departmental processes were not gone through and, in fact, it occasioned great upset within the department that somebody from outside should be appointed to a special project without proper consultation with the department.

For such a person as Ms Hitchen, who undoubtedly considered that she had a career with the Australian Labor Party, such shabby treatment must have come as a deep shock. Indeed, Ms Hitchen suffered severe stress resulting from this matter and had to be taken to hospital after collapsing in front of her young son. She was admitted to a local ACT hospital on 6 December, 1994, as a result of stress-related difficulties.

A bit of history. In September, 1994, Ms Hitchen accompanied the minister as his adviser to the federal conference of the Australian Labor Party in my home town of Hobart instead of Mr Greg Rudd, the senior adviser. The reason being that it was adjudged by the minister that Mr Rudd was so politically "on the nose" that it would be better for him to be accompanied by Ms Hitchen. I understand that this may well have occasioned some of the friction within the office.
Ms Hitchen's initial appointment to Mr Sciacca's office was as a result of the intervention of Senator Robert Ray—intervention to which Mr Greg Rudd appears to have taken great exception.

Further, Ms Hitchen developed a relationship with an ALP backbencher in the House of Representatives which, to the paranoid Right of Queensland, occasioned the minister with some fanciful concerns and further paranoia. Did this backbencher stand by his convictions and Ms Hitchen—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, on a point of order: by convention this area of public interest is relatively non-controversial. We now have Senator Abetz starting to talk about relationships between a former staffer and a member of the House of Representatives, treading on very dangerous waters.
—Usually "ground", Nicholas.

—Yes, smart arse, ground. I withdraw that comment about Senator Abetz being a smart arse. I just want to draw to your attention that there is a convention and Senator Abetz is going well over it. He is creating precedents in this place that could return to burn the opposition. I do not know whether he has spoken to his whips about it—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Watson)—Senator Sherry, there is no point of order. But it might be a matter that could come up before the standing orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Abetz has been warned; so has the opposition.

—For the benefit of Senator Sherry, I have been attacked by people such as Senator Reynolds during this debate. If he wants to talk about convention, I suggest he talk to members of his own parliamentary party.

PARA.TAB: In any event, this matter appeared before the Industrial Relations Commission on 23 February 1995. Ms Hitchen took the matter to court for unfair dismissal. The matter settled. The terms of settlement have never been disclosed. But I am reliably informed that, after the initial presentation of Ms Hitchen's case to the commission, those allegedly representing the minister did not contest in any shape or form that Ms Hitchen was unfairly dismissed. Therefore, the only question that had to be determined was the question of costs, the question of damages and the actual terms of the settlement. I am reliably informed that, after hours of negotiations, a substantial payment was made to Ms Hitchen and a letter of apology was written by Mr Rudd to Ms Hitchen. We did not see the smiling minister alert the press for another cheque handover ceremony on that occasion.

Following this outcome, Ms Hitchen was then subjected to death threats via the telephone. Those death threats made mention of her recent settlement in the commission. In loyalty to her party, she did not make any complaint until the threats implicated her young son. She then had no other choice, like any mother, but to inform the Australian Federal Police. The results of their investigation, or who made these calls, is not known to me.

The purpose of raising this matter once again is not to remind Ms Hitchen of this tragedy. It is designed, however, to highlight the duplicity in which Labor undertakes employment of its own people; yet preaches a version of social justice for employers, which they themselves once they are employers are unable to match. It highlights the duplicity of Labor's approach to industrial relations. Above all, it highlights yet again the minister's incapacity to do his job.

Further, Mr Rudd and the minister appear to have got away with occasioning substantial costs on the taxpayers of Australia: firstly, by having to pay compensation to Ms Hitchen; and, secondly, by having legal representation for the Department of Administrative Services at the industrial commission, which I am reliably informed included a Queen's Counsel from Melbourne, the cost of which was at least $1,969. The costs of all this ought be visited upon Mr Greg Rudd and the minister. The minister ought be made responsible to this parliament and to the people of Australia as to why they are so incompetent in running their office on an administratively fair basis.

One wonders whether Mr Rudd has been disciplined; whether he has been counselled; and whether he has, in fact, been demoted for his behaviour. If not, the people of Australia quite clearly have a right to ask—why not? I ask rhetorically what the government has done in relation to Mr Rudd and the minister. Whilst the minister and his office bask in all the glory of the taxpayer funded `Australia Remembers' program, they ought be made to account for the unnecessary costs to the taxpayer and for the personal humiliation, loss of self-esteem and hurt occasioned to the people at the Australian War Memorial and Ms Hitchen. I am sure that Ms Hitchen "remembers"; I am sure that the employees at the Australian War Memorial "remember"; and we on this side will make sure that `Australia remembers'.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on an issue that is of importance to me. It was an issue that was highlighted last week during National Carers Week, which was held from 8 to 14 October. This is the first opportunity I have had of talking about carers since that week occurred. Caring is emerging as one of the important social policy issues of the 1990s and will continue to increase in importance as we see an ever increasing number of older people in Australia. There are 1.5 million Australians who have a responsibility for someone who is frail, elderly or who has a chronic illness or a disability. There are about 540 Australians for whom this responsibility is a full-time job.

PARA.TAB: Almost all of us will at some time in our lives be a carer or need to be cared for. The enormous extent of the contribution of carers is evidenced by the fact that 74 per cent of the service needs of people who have a disability or who are ill or frail are provided for by carers; that is, nearly three-quarters of the caring that is done is provided by carers.

The entire home and community care program—the HACC program—meets only nine per cent of that need, with a budget of $657 million in 1994-95. Extrapolating from those figures, the New South Wales Carers Association estimate that carers contribute about $7.3 billion worth of services per year. That may or may not be exactly right but it is within the ballpark of the sort of level of effort that goes into caring for those who are not able to care for themselves. Caring is becoming an important social issue not just because of the huge numbers involved but because families are finding it increasingly difficult to bridge the care gap between needs and services.

There is plenty of rhetoric from the government but only token recognition in terms of tangible support of the contribution made by carers. To be fair, the government has introduced some important programs for carers, but both the House of Representatives inquiry into HACC and the Commonwealth-state efficiency and effectiveness review of HACC concluded that there is a significant undersupply of services to carers and the people they support.

There are two issues I would like to mention regarding the issue of carers: the issue of women and caring and the issue of the needs of carers. I raise the issue of women and caring because carers are overwhelmingly women. It is a fact that almost every woman—not every woman but a large majority of women—will at some stage either be a carer or will need care at some stage.

Women make up 60 per cent of the carers and the ABS survey of Australian families found that, of these, 50 per cent are in the work force and 72 per cent are under the age of 54. So a large number of these carers are juggling the caring role, work and, most probably, caring for children. Some academics in the business talk about the sandwich generation—the women who still have dependent children and are also looking after dependent relatives, either older relatives or frail or disabled younger people. It is usually the women in the middle who provide the care, and they are often co-resident with the person for whom they provide care.

Over recent years there has been a growing recognition of women as the primary carers of children. At the same time, there has been increasing concern about the significant number of women caring for elderly parents, permanently or temporarily disabled family members or frail aged partners at home. This second group is a largely hidden group of carers who unquestioningly assume carer roles as and when their families need them.

I raise the role of women as carers not only because they do by far the greatest amount of the caring in our community but because, as one of the pop singers of my youth—I cannot remember who it was—said, `The times they are a-changing.' These changes will drastically affect the availability of carers into the future. You only have to look at a couple of the significant demographic social and economic changes that are taking place. Families are changing; they are smaller and they are more mobile. Because families have fewer children there will not be as many family members to share the caring as there have been in past generations. As we see highly mobile families, we see that more often than not they do not live in the same town as the people who need care. Even when they are in the same city, the family has work and other family commitments that reduce and limit the amount of time available for caring.

The other issue that is causing changes is the increased number of family break downs. Divorce and remarriage has meant changed responsibilities and commitments: one part of the family may have a commitment to the mother but not to the stepfather, or to the stepfather and not to the mother. I have been reminded that it was Bob Dylan who said `the times they are a-changing'. The times are a-changing and reconstructed families—new families and remarriages—mean that there are changes in the sense of responsibility for older people in the family. I believe that will reduce the number of carers who are available and who have a sense of responsibility for the care of older people.

Another factor which reduces the hours or the people available for caring is the participation of women in the work force. It is uncertain whether women in the future will be automatically available to undertake the level of care that is presently available in the community. What has not changed is the workplace, and carers, who are employed, find it difficult, if not impossible, to combine work and caring responsibilities. As I said, a large number of female carers are in the paid work force and there is not, as yet, mainstream recognition for other family responsibilities such as care for the elderly in the workplace. The choice for many is not work and caring but work or caring.

I set up, in conjunction with two of my colleagues, the first diploma of gerontology at Lincoln Institute. We geared it to train people who are not necessarily primary health givers but who may be associated with gerontology and the ageing. We envisaged that we would attract architects, town-planners and interior designers, and we did do that. I visited a very large firm in Victoria. They had appointed one of the graduates of that course. She was an occupational health and safety nurse.
