When I discovered her there, I was surprised, delighted and thrilled to see one of the products of a course that I had been involved in instigating. The reason they had employed her as an occupational health and safety nurse was that she could combine that skill and her knowledge in gerontology.

When they had done a survey of the employees in that company, the issue that came up over and over again that was affecting productivity was the strain and the demands that were being placed on the workers in terms of caring for older people in their families. They appointed that nurse because she could work with the employees and tell them how to access services and tell them about the modifications to make to their homes so it would be easier for the employees to keep their older relatives at home et cetera. I thought it was a very enlightened approach that this large company was addressing the issue of dealing with older people that its workers were facing. Unfortunately, that is an exception rather than the rule.

Some people assume that, even if working women are not available to care, the young old will care for the old old, and that is not necessarily the case. There has also been a move away from institutional care to increased emphasis on community care. Irrespective of what happens, that places enormous loads on families. We would all agree that people should have the choice as to whether they should be in institutional care or whether they should be at home and, of course, that does add another burden and another aspect to care.

The other issue I raise today in this discussion is the issue of the needs of carers. Carers are a forgotten group of people: a veritable army of thousands and thousands of Australians who are bearing enormous economic, social and health costs in terms of earnings forgone, financial stress, social isolation and deterioration of physical and psychological health.

If you are caring for someone with dementia it is not very easy to take them out when they behave in socially unacceptable ways and when they are, perhaps, incontinent. It is very difficult for the carer to take someone with dementia out with them because the person can become agitated and disoriented and so the carer stays home and becomes more and more isolated. I visit nursing homes and hostels, and staff in one after the other tell me that often the reason the person is in the hostel or the nursing home is because the carer's health has broken down.

Many carers suffer poverty and economic disadvantage because they cannot work. When I was out in one of the regional centres of Victoria, there was a case where a man aged 58 told me about his 53-year-old wife who has full-blown Alzheimer's disease. The husband was locking his wife up at home when he went to work because otherwise she would have got out. He found that this was not a viable option, but there was nothing for him to do until he found that one of the local hostels had a bit of what I call `slop in the system'. There is no Commonwealth funding for this sort of thing because our programs are so inflexible, but the hostel had been bequested some money and the management was able to offer to take the man's wife into the hostel during the day.

The man was able to pick his wife up in the evening when he came home from work and he was also able to pick her up late two evenings a week so that he could play snooker and have dinner with some of his friends. The man was, therefore, able to remain an employee and to have an income. He was able to be a taxpayer in the community and be seen to be caring for his wife and yet he was able to have some respite. It was a wonderful option for him in the very difficult situation of his wife having early dementia.

There are many people in this situation and so often our programs are designed so that we have to try to fit the client to the program rather than fit the program to the client. This is a case where funding is not flexible enough to accommodate this sort of problem and where somebody who is not as lucky as this gentleman would end up at an economic disadvantage. As I said, there are health costs for the carers and there are the additional costs of their having to modify their houses.

Another major cost is transport. I recently spent some time in rural New South Wales visiting nursing homes and hostels and looking at community programs. Comments are made to me over and over again about transport: how do people get to hospitals? How do people get their relatives to the doctor if they cannot drive a car? There is a real problem in terms of carers being able to transport the people for whom they care to various facilities. The other thing that happens with carers—especially younger ones in the work force—is that they have to move out of the work force to care for an older relative. Carers, especially women, have broken work patterns and their superannuation contributions are affected. The federal government has not adequately addressed this situation.

There are many issues, particularly for rural carers and for carers from non-English-speaking backgrounds; I could go on and on. Carers are a group of people which is under recognised and whose needs are neglected. Another thing that concerns me is that the Commonwealth government took over the organisation of the publicity for `Carers week' whereas previously it was organised by the carers association. I have some suspicions about why it was taken away from the carers association. For the government to take over a role that a voluntary organisation has been undertaking and to put its own stamp on it is a dangerous precedent to set.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the last break I had the opportunity with my colleague Senator John Herron to travel through western Queensland. We travelled in an area where neither I nor other politicians often have the opportunity to go. The areas we travelled through encompassed about 18 communities in the south-west, west, north-west and north of Queensland and we travelled a total of 4,000 kilometres by road over a period of seven days. It was a great opportunity for myself and for Senator Herron to speak to people on the ground in these areas.

PARA.TAB: The theme of our expedition was `Listening to people in western Queensland' and it was a tremendous opportunity to do just that. I would certainly recommend to other parliamentarians, if they have the time and the opportunity, to go and experience how these smaller communities in western Queensland exist. I want to spend just a couple of minutes today to run through some of the things that we saw and did and some of the issues that were raised with us in the course of that particular trip. My colleague Senator Herron is following me in this debate and he will also mention some of the things that happened, but he will be concentrating on health aspects of those smaller communities in western Queensland.

Those areas are well represented in the federal parliament by my colleague Mr Bruce Scott, the member for Maranoa, and Mr Bob Katter, the member for Kennedy, but it was important that I, as a senior member of the coalition's shadow ministry, and Senator Herron, with his involvement in policy making as part of the coalition's policy review committee and as the parliamentary secretary ot the shadow minister for health, got out and had a look at the issues out there so that we could incorporate the things that we learned in coalition policy as it is prepared for the next election.

We started the trip on Monday morning at the Cobb and Co. museum in Toowoomba. That is a tremendous facility in itself. It is a repository for all the coaches and horse drawn vehicles of yesteryear and demonstrates the ways that people used to work and get around in the early days. It was interesting that, as the curator of the museum pointed out to us, the trip we were doing was taking us seven days to do the 4,000 kilometres; if we had been going in a Cobb and Co. coach, as they did in the old days, it would have taken 50 days. That shows that, in spite of the poor standard of most of the roads out that way, we still are a lot better off than we used to be in the horse and buggy days.

From Toowoomba we went to Goondiwindi and spoke with people there about the cotton industry and about the need for water storage and the difficulties caused by the drought in that south-western community on the border between Queensland and New South Wales. During our stay in Goondiwindi we walked the main street. I had the opportunity of talking to people in a welfare shop—the opportunity shop run by the Anglican Church—and having a discussion with them. They said to us that it is very clear that their business, unfortunately, has increased in recent months as the drought has impacted more heavily on those areas of south-western Queensland. It is a tragedy. But it is tremendous to see people like the Opportunity Shop and the St Vincent De Paul playing a real role in looking after the less fortunate in those western communities.

I also spoke with a business facilitator who was doing work for the Queensland and Commonwealth governments. He has given me some very good points to take up in parliament, as I will, and I will be writing to the minister. But he points out—Senator Sherry might be interested in this—that some of the Commonwealth programs, whilst they sound good on paper, just do not work because it is too difficult for business people in the communities that are affected by drought to qualify under the government's regulations. The red tape, the regulation that is needed to be gone through, is just debilitating and very few people end up qualifying although they desperately need help.

From Goondiwindi we went on to St George and spoke with a local medical practitioner there, Dr Stone, who is also a councillor on the Balonne Shire Council. We met the Mayor of the Balonne shire at St George. We had a useful discussion with them about the problems facing those particular communities. From St George we travelled on to Cunnamulla, one of the furthest west of the towns in south-west Queensland; we got there quite late and had our meeting the next morning. I spoke to the council and Senator Herron went round to the hospital. We also spoke to other community people, other townspeople in that area.

One of the things that came out of my meeting was that, whilst the Commonwealth government is working flat out to get all these REDOs—regional economic development organisations—set up before the federal election, people in these western towns see them for the political campaign they are. They appreciate that these REDOs really are a lot of hype; there is a lot of talk about them and a lot of ribbon cutting, but not much money in it. As to the community of interest, these far western communities are being forced into an association with, would you believe, Toowoomba—many hours to the east. That really demonstrated to me what I had always suspected, that a lot of these REDO proposals are just set-ups by the Labor Party for electioneering purposes. They are not well put together.

From Cunnamulla we went into Charleville and again spoke with the townspeople and health professionals, and got a feeling of what was happening in that major western town. From Charleville we headed north to Blackall and again had a joint meeting of councillors and community people. We learnt about the problems they are experiencing, and about the kangaroo industry and what an important industry it is to that particular community of Blackall. That we found very interesting. We also looked there at how people in small western communities can access the best in communications—if not quite using the superhighway, certainly by way of computer and modem they were able to access a lot of educational facilities. The council and a group set up under the council were actually working, while we were there, teaching people with the aid of computers connected to educational resources in the east.

We then went on to Barcaldine. We spoke with local people in Barcaldine and had our obligatory photo taken under the tree of knowledge, where the old Labor Party was originally formed. It was a party bearing little resemblance to the lot of chardonnay socialists you have today—the chattering classes that run the Labor Party—and it was good to see where the old-style Labor Party was said to be initiated under the tree of knowledge.

From Barcaldine we went into Longreach, a major town in western Queensland and one that is doing very well from its emphasis on outback tourism. The Stockman's Hall of Fame is very well patronised, it has been very well put together and is one facility which all Australians should at some time in their life go and experience. We met with the medical people there and were told of the problems confronting people in the health area. Senator Herron will speak about that later. I also spoke with the mayor in Longreach, Councillor Joan Moloney, who explained to me some of the difficulties that they were experiencing. It is a progressive town and a town that has optimism, and they will certainly be making the best of what they can do. I was also able to speak with the long established Regional Development and Planning Board.

From Longreach we went on to Winton, stopping at the hospital there and speaking with the local doctor, and then from Winton we went west for a four-hour trip, seeing practically no other cars and very few houses or people. It is really heading out towards the Simpson Desert. There is a little town halfway called Middleton, where there is a very old and rather quaint hotel sitting completely in the middle of nowhere. We stopped there and had a couple of beers with the locals who happened to be in there. You get a feel in those places of just what it is like for people who spend all of their time in that isolation—far from neighbours, far from the services that people in the east and in the capital cities treat as just common, everyday facilities. For these people, really, their only facility is the hotel and their nearest neighbour is, in many instances, an hour away.

From Hamilton we went to Boulia, and spoke with the local council there about some of the problems impacting on people in that area. They have problems with their mail service; it is very irregular and it sometimes takes five days to get first class mail in. They do not have mains electricity—something that we all take for granted in the east—but they were prepared to contribute $80,000 each to get the mains electricity to their property. However, that was rejected because the government wanted them to subsidise the main from Mount Isa to Boulia. These are the sorts of things that people living in those areas put up with. A better TV service was something that they desperately wanted. They have two channels but with a bit of help from government they could access the cricket and the football from another source and that was something that should be easily available and would make a big difference to life in the west.

From there we went to Mount Isa and spoke with many people in that community. The fly-in fly-out of the mining operations is the big issue in Mount Isa at the moment. From Mt Isa we went to Cloncurry, the town where both my mother and father were born in the first decade of this century. In Cloncurry, I spoke with councils and, again, Senator Herron and I went up to the hospital and spoke with professionals there.

We left Cloncurry and headed further north to the Burke and Wills Roadhouse and met some interesting people there, including the chairman of the Burke Shire Council. We then went on to Normanton and finally to Karumba, where we arrived at 10 p.m. to a blackout. The white ants had eaten the insides of an electricity pole holding the main transformer in Karumba but no-one had noticed the damage because the outside of the pole looked good. On the day that we arrived the transformer fell and the whole town was blacked out. But it did not deter us. We got to bed that night and then early the next morning spoke with locals about the proposal to dredge the port at Karumba to facilitate live cattle export through Karumba. We also learned about the proposal for Century Zinc to pipe out zinc slurry from the mine site to Karumba. The slurry will be de-watered there and then taken out by marine transport to its ultimate destination. That is quite an exciting project and one that will mean a lot to the north-west.

We then travelled to Normanton and spoke with the Carpenteria Council there and the hospital about matters of importance to them. From Normanton, we went east to Croydon and met the council there. We then went on through Georgetown to Forsayth. We spent the night in Forsayth with the publican, who is also the mayor, John Smith and his wife Grace. We learnt a great deal from our very interesting evening at the bar with the mayor and the locals.

The next day we left early and travelled through Einasleigh past Innot Hot Springs to Herberton and then to Ravenshoe where they were in the middle of their annual festival. Ravenshoe is a community with whom I have had a long association. Senators might remember that this is the community that the Labor Party practically shut down several years ago because of its insensitivity in dealing with World Heritage listing. If you want a good fight in Ravenshoe you just have to say `Graham Richardson is a good fellow.' From there, we went to Atherton where we talked with a very significant medical practitioner there, a Dr Green, who is renowned around Australia—I am sure Senator Herron will speak more on this—and finally on to Cairns to ocnclude our 4,000 kilometre trip.

The trip was tremendously beneficial for me as it helped me to understand what is happening in those smaller western and remote communities. It was interesting to see that in the south-west there is a concern about the future, about the population drift from the inland—people are uncertain where they will be in 10 years or 15 years time. In the north-west by contrast there seemed to be a lot more optimism on the back of new mining ventures and frontier tourism. The trip was particularly beneficial and it is one that I recommend to all senators. (Time expired).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in following Senator Macdonald and I enjoyed his company on that trip. It was an education for both of us. I grew up in North Queensland and have been to western Queensland many times throughout my life but it was the first time I had been to Boulia. It was interesting in that the further we got out from the cities the less people complained. There were two things that people complained about. The mantra I heard all the time was, `Get rid of that mongrel in Canberra.' That was the first one I heard. In every pub we went to people said, `Get rid of that mongrel in Canberra.'
—Fancy saying that about John Howard.
—Senator Burns, there is one big mongrel in Canberra and you know to whom I am referring. I have used the word `mongrel' but it might be unparliamentary in that sense.
—On a point of order—

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Childs)—Yes, I think under the circumstances I might request—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is appalling. The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard—
—No, we shouldn't speculate on this innuendo.
—Mr Acting Deputy President, that is not the word that was used. The word that was used was completely unparliamentary and blasphemous, but I wouldn't use it—
—The request is that you withdraw, Senator.

—Yes, I am happy to withdraw it if you find it offensive or if Senator Sherry finds it offensive. He is concerned about the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) being considered so in the west, but there it is. I withdraw.

PARA.TAB: The second thing that struck me as we went along is that, if anybody has cause for complaint, it is these people. They went through the worst recession in 60 years as a result of this government and this situation is compounded by the worst drought that they have ever had. You will read in the papers about how the drought appears to have broken, but I can assure you that it hasn't broken. It is still a major problem, particularly for the people of western and central Queensland.

The third thing that has affected these people is the Goss Labor government. The Goss government withdrew economic rationality in that it started closing railway stations down and services followed. Post offices have also been closed down. It is interesting that the biggest centre in Cloncurry is the Commonwealth Employment Service; it is the main government industry there. The other thing that has occurred, of course, because of the failure in services is the dramatic drift of population from these western centres. The combination of the recession, the drought and the closure of services means that people have shifted to the coast. This in turn has meant that a lot of the social services have diminished in these towns.

You would think that large provincial cities like Toowoomba—where population has actually increased—would not be affected. But, just a couple of days after we set out, there was a letter in the Toowoomba Chronicle from Dr John Hede who is the President of the Visiting Specialists Association, Toowoomba General Hospital. I quote:

SPEECH.PARA: There are more than 1,000 people on the waiting lists,
and most will not be pleased to be compared to those "buying airline tickets". (TC 27/9/95).
He quotes from the regional director there. He goes on to say:

At least an airline usually accommodates an excess of numbers by putting on extra flights. A waiting list should be dynamic—within a reasonable time, an individual's turn should come around. For many at Toowoomba General, their turn never comes. The present waiting list is the worst it has been for 20 years.
If this is not an indictment of the federal government, nothing is. The Toowoomba General Hospital is dependent on the funding that comes from the federal government.

PARA.TAB: This situation is just the precursor of what I saw as we visited health groups in all these country towns. The biggest complaint, interestingly enough, is the shortage of doctors, but that should not surprise you. The interesting aspect of this situation is that the major cause of the situation is the Hawke Labor government's abolition of tax deductibility for educational expenses. Once upon a time doctors could stay in a country town and, when their children needed secondary education, the children would go to boarding school on the coast. Once that was abolished, of course, the doctors shifted with their families for the sake of their children's education and this has had a dramatic effect.

The second thing which has had an effect and which has not been spoken about is the feminisation of medical practice. More than half the number of medical students now are female and, inevitably, they get married. They usually marry non-medical people and they stay in the cities. In bulk-billing clinics female doctors can earn an income and raise their families at the same time, and this, in turn, has had a compounding effect. There is a dramatic shortage of doctors in the county areas because half the graduates are now female and they marry and stay in the cities. Female doctors do not want to go to the country, understandably, because of their family situation.

The third aspect of the shift of doctors from rural areas is the fact that they cannot get locums to relieve them either for holidays or to enable them to get postgraduate education. These days, doctors are reaccredited on an annual basis. To get reaccreditation a doctor has to attend postgraduate training exercises, but they cannot get away. The government—in its wisdom—by looking after the citizens of Sydney and Melbourne in particular, has put in a rebate system where, if the doctors are not accredited, patients get a lower rebate from Medicare. It is economically unsound for doctors to stay in these areas. There are a number of fine doctors in rural areas, but the constant complaint is, `We need a break.'
The doctor in Cloncurry had been there for six months and, when I was there, he was getting his first week off in six months. He was on call 24 hours per day, seven days a week for six months.

There is also a dramatic shortage of nurses in these country areas, for similar reasons: they are expected to work beyond the call of duty; they are expected to be on call at nights and during weekends. Although a lot of the facilities are good, they cannot get relief. The college based education for nurses, as opposed to being hospital based, has meant that they are now university graduates from four-year training courses. These graduates do not want to go to rural areas.

This is compounded in Queensland because there has been a dramatic increase in population. My friend Senator Warwick Parer appropriately spoke about the town of Warwick. He said that, when he was a child, the population of Warwick was 10,000 and the population of Australia was six million. It is now 8,000 in Warwick and 18 million in Australia. As a Queenslander, I look forward to the year 2020 when the population of Queensland will outstrip Victoria's. I am delighted that Queensland will not have that monkey on its back any longer. Queensland will no longer be regarded as a less populous and therefore less important state. In 2020, we will become the second most important and most populous state in Australia. But that, perhaps, is beyond my time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tasmania will get there first.

—You will recall, Senator Sherry, that Tasmania was so highly thought of during the Commonwealth Games that it was left off the map. I am sure that was regretted at the time. It is interesting to go through the population of the towns that we visited. For example, when I first went to Mount Isa, it had a population of 30,000. Five years ago, it was 25,000; it is now 18,000. Mount Isa is the largest city in Queensland, outside the provincial cities and the capital, and this is something that people do not consider. It has a large population and many changes have occurred. In fact, whilst we were there, we saw a deputation that was interested in stimulating small business to try to retain the population.

PARA.TAB: During our trip, it came home to me that not only was there a shortage of nurses and doctors but also there was a shortage of pharmacists and dentists. As we are being broadcast, if there are any dentists, pharmacists or doctors who have reached retiring age, who would like to help the rural communities, I assure them that there is plenty of opportunity for doing locums in Queensland country towns. They would be welcomed with open arms, and the facilities are there. I came across a dentist who was spending his time helping the people in the west. It is particularly the case in that occupation.

Pharmacists are in similar straits. I met a number of pharmacists who were considering moving to the city because of the draconian control that now exists over pharmacies. Due to the pharmaceutical benefit scheme, they cannot get extra remuneration from anything other than the dispensation of pharmaceuticals under the PBS.

The drought, the recession and the lack of amenities and facilities become a vicious circle. This compounds, and nurses, doctors, pharmacists and dentists leave the country towns. Because of the lack of available facilities, these people shift to larger centres.

The other thing that I learnt from this trip is the wonderful character and the almost pioneering spirit that still exists among the people that we met. Not one complained about their lot. I will not mention the town, but I was a little amused at the time that its shire clerk said that he could not understand why people wouldn't shift from the cities. He said, `We've got some of the cheapest land available.' When we questioned him, he said the land cost $600 for a home site. He said, `We have the best climate in Australia.' When I questioned him about the climate, he said, `The top temperature here during summer is 40 degrees, and that is not unreasonable.' I questioned him about water—of course, bore water is available there—and in all sincerity he could not understand why people were clustering on the coast.

There are demographic changes, of course, that will not attract people but, quite rightly, the complaint also is that the wealth of the country comes from these areas. This is particularly so in Queensland with its mining areas. There is also the tremendous mining development that Senator Ian Macdonald referred to—the largest goldmine in Australia at Kidston, just north of Forsayth. And, of course, there is Mount Isa itself, which is a huge producer of overseas earning for this country. There are also the coalfields. Some of the largest open-cut coalfields in the world are situated on the coast.

One of the delights of going through this area—out to Boulia, out to Mount Isa, through to Karumba in the Gulf and across through the centre of the base of the Cape—is to recognise the tourism potential of the area. I have travelled the circumference of Australia and, as I say, it is the first time that Senator Macdonald and I have driven to Boulia, but I thoroughly recommend the hospitality and the facilities that are available. The roads are good, too. We had to dodge a few kangaroos and cattle across the roads in the middle of the night—particularly when Senator Macdonald was driving—but I will not mention anything else as he might not take me with him next time.

The people we struck have wonderful personalities and there is a spirit of sacrifice by the people who stay there and who provide the social services: the nurses, doctors, pharmacists, and the dentists on whom I particularly concentrated. Senator Macdonald and I learnt a lot from these people about the requirements that they have. I must say that we did not strike one Labor voter in any of the pubs. I have a lovely memory of a fellow I thought might have been misguided enough to vote for the Labor Party. I asked him what he did for a living and he said that he chased a few cows around the place. Even he repeated the statement that I made at the beginning about getting rid of that XYZ; that unmentionable person in Canberra. All of us would agree with that—on this side of the chamber, at least.

The other thing that was said to me—I got it from everybody I met—is that it is time to change. The message that I got from everybody is, `Let's change.' After 13 years of Labor, the worst recession in 60 years—the one we had to have—the unemployment that exists in the country and the lack of hope that we struck with the present government in power, the constant mantra that we got from everybody we struck—everybody without exception—was, `Let's change.'

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity today in the matters of public interest debate to report to the Senate on the result of the 94th Inter-Parliamentary Conference which was held in Bucharest last week. I was one of the Australian delegates, along with the honourable member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), Senator Woods and Senator Denman. Unfortunately, Senator Woods had to return home because, I believe, of food poisoning of some description. It is quite understandable in that particular part of the world. At various stages we all succumbed to food poisoning and whatever.

PARA.TAB: Four major topics were discussed at the conference and three of the topics were set down at the last conference. One topic in particular—in which Senator Denman played quite a leading role—is from the conference in Copenhagen and it concerned strategies for the effective implementation of the resolution of the World Summit on Social Development in Copenhagen.

Australia made the point that the international forum and the World Summit for Social Development are the starting point of a long process. It is up to each and every country to be single-minded in working towards achieving outcomes that contribute to the alleviation of poverty, the reduction of unemployment and the enhancement of social integration. That was the point of view being put by the Australian group. Obviously, that Australian group, including myself, would recognise that poverty and unemployment exist in our own country. We were not being critical of other countries. We were just pointing out that that particular conference in Copenhagen last year made those points.

This very important matter was discussed by the third committee at this conference. Senator Denman was on that drafting committee. After three very long and arduous days they came out with a statement which will be presented to the United Nations.

The other very important topic that was covered was the matter of corruption and I spoke on that saying that parliamentary action defied corruption and I spoke on the need for international cooperation in that field. I pointed out to the conference the system that we have here, the Senate committee system and the scrutiny to which we subject the government and government departments. From my understanding of speakers from other countries, we seem to have a system as good as, if not better than, any other. We have a better system of being able to scrutinise wastage and possible corruption within our community. I made the point that, if we cannot keep our politicians and parliaments corruption free, then it is very difficult to make the rest of the community corruption free.
Unfortunately, you cannot say the same in other countries. We heard plenty of examples of corruption within parliaments and by public servants, particularly in developing countries.

A lot of very good recommendations were put forward and a very complicated draft was adopted. It is hoped that that will help, particularly developing countries, to develop within their parliamentary systems ways and means of scrutinising their parliamentary operations and their dealings with public money through such things as ombudsmen, whistleblower protection and all those other things that we take for granted but which do not exist in other countries.

The supplementary item was something that particularly Australia and our neighbour New Zealand can be rightly proud of. We fought very hard. The supplementary item was voted upon by the members of the conference which consisted of over 130 countries, with some 1,000 people in attendance. To get that item adopted is no mean feat when you realise that countries like Germany put forward proposals such as the protection of minorities as a global problem; the challenges for parliaments as guardians of human rights; economic sanctions and their effect and destructive effects on its people by Iraq. There was a very controversial one about fighting terrorism, but those matters were all put aside after the vote which was 895 for, 392 abstentions and 97 against, to debate the matter.

The adoption of the comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty and its implications for continued nuclear tests was put forward by New Zealand. It was co-sponsored by the Asia-Pacific group, in particular Australia and Chile. That went to a drafting committee that consisted of France, Chile, Australia, New Zealand, UK, Indonesia and Japan. Most of the work in that drafting committee was done by Leo McLeay.

I participated for part of the time. As one would expect, the French used delaying actions in trying to change the strongly worded statement. In fact, at one stage, they even suggested that we took out a paragraph which recalled the effect of nuclear explosions on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. I made the point that we were only using that particular statement as a matter of fact. They tried to argue the old debate about the rights and wrongs of dropping atomic weapons, but we used that example so that everybody could see the effect of a nuclear exploding device. Thank goodness it was kept in, because it strengthened the very strong motion.

After eight hours of debate and argument with the French delegates, I am pleased to say that the general session of the IPU eventually voted on the motion on Saturday. The results of that vote were 930 in favour, 300 abstentions and only 65 against. The 65 against included 27 votes from China and 11 from France. Interestingly, France is entitled to 17 votes from two delegates but only one of them voted; the other one, supposedly, was locked in the toilet. As we know, Senator Sherry, that is a favourite device that is used when people do not want to vote.

Even amongst the French, one of their delegates did not want to vote against this particular motion. Of course, one of their colleagues, Senegal, did vote and cast a maximum number of 17 votes. The UK used one of its votes to put up a token resistance against the motion, as did Cameroon and a few others. Since the conference, I have noticed that, in the last day or so, the United Kingdom, which has been playing a rather passive role in the nuclear testing controversy, has become much more anti-testing and this really isolates China and France.

I am also pleased to report on our good friends from India. There was a ballot for the executive positions and there was controversy about which candidates Australia should support. We had to make a decision on three candidates: one from Korea, one from China and one from India. Needless to say, at the end of the day, the Chinese candidate was not elected and the candidate from India, the candidate from Korea, and the other recommended candidates that had already been decided, were elected.

I am pleased to report that Australia had a very successful conference. We had the opportunity of putting the point of view of the South Pacific and the other Pacific nations as far as the test ban treaty is concerned. It cemented our relationship with New Zealand because we worked very closely with them and I think they really appreciated our support in this matter. I also think the Japanese and the Chileans appreciated the support that they received and the work that was put into this by Leo McLeay and other members of the delegation.

I wanted to put this on the record today before some of these matters passed from memory. I would like to congratulate my fellow members of the delegation for the very hard work that was put in because we lacked a few members due to illness. Finally, I was impressed with the progress that seems to have been made in Romania since it became a free state. It is one of the biggest receivers of Australian exports.

I was staggered by the palace in Bucharest. It was erected by the former dictator, Ceausescu, to his memory. A place that consisted of something like 6,000 rooms, took 20 years to build, took two million people to build and took 25 per cent of the gross domestic product for 20 years while the rest of the country starved, is not a very good example of communism in any shape or form. It is still not completed. I doubt if it ever will be.

But it certainly did provide a venue that was described by some as stunning; others described it as disgusting. It must, I suppose, be seen in years to come as being—probably not one of the wonders of the world—like a lot of other structures that have been erected by dictators. It will be something to look back on in awe and remember, and perhaps it may be a memorial to a very bad government—the government that put a dictatorship before the people.

The people are recovering well from that regime. There seems to be food in the shops at last. And that was the reason they had the revolution, of course—because they did not have any food, amongst a lot of other things. There seems to be quite an improvement in the situation in Romania and we were certainly treated very well. I would like to put on the record our appreciation to our hosts for doing such a fine job in the running of this conference.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —In the couple of minutes remaining, I would just like to touch on a couple of matters.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, Senators Herron and Ian Macdonald gave us an outline of their seven-day tour of western Queensland. Like them, I was in rural Queensland last week—I was in Queensland for four days—but I went to the town of Monto, mainly to consult with rural groups, particularly women's groups, about the drought. It has been mentioned here today that some people think the drought is over: well, it is not. The region I visited has had little rain for five years. The purpose of my visit, discussions and consultations was to listen to the community and consult with them about our drought policy. It really is very tragic and heart-rending to visit a drought area such as rural Queensland and talk to the local communities about their particular problems.

Before I conclude, very briefly: Senator Abetz made an extraordinary attack on Mr Con Sciacca, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, and I did by way of a point of order draw to the Senate's attention the precedents that Senator Abetz broke in launching into a very controversial area, which is not the norm in matters of public interest. I think what was even worse about Senator Abetz's attack on Mr Sciacca is that it involved a mixture of accusations about a former member of his staff, apparently involved in a relationship with a member of the backbench in the other place and her alleged dismissal and the reasons why she was allegedly dismissed.

I came into this place believing that there are three issues you do not talk about involving members of parliament. One is their relationships with staff, one is their personal lives and one is their physical appearance. If Senator Abetz wants to lower the standard of debate and talk about ministers and their staff and their relationships with staff, then that is up to him. It does not really reflect on Senator Abetz very well. He is rapidly becoming known not as the Senator for Tasmania but the senator for sleaze.

All I can say to members of the opposition is that if you want Senator Abetz to make the sorts of accusations and speeches he did during the debate on matters of public interest, which was not supposed to be controversial, you should have a look at your own relationships with your own families and your own staff. If you want that sort of sleaze raised in this chamber, as Senator Abetz did, at lunchtime, then you are going the right way about it. That is not a threat, it is just drawing to the attention of the Senate the precedent that Senator Abetz is creating not just by raising that sort of dirt in the Senate during discussion of matters of public interest, which is not supposed to be controversial, but by raising those sorts of issues at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 2 p.m., the discussion on matters of public interest is concluded.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Economy: Ambassador to the United States

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Dr Russell, Mr Keating's political soul mate, says he is returning to Australia to save us from the development of an American style underclass. I ask the minister: isn't it a fact that, under this Keating Labor government, Australia now has almost two million of its people living in poverty, many of whom are not receiving social security payments—many of those being small business people? The figure includes some 600,000 young Australian children. We have a situation where charity and emergency relief centres report they are as busy as they were during Mr Keating's recession we had to have. Why in such circumstances, where this government has already given us an underclass, should Australians believe that Dr Russell is capable of cleaning up the mess that he and Mr Keating jointly created in the first place?

—I do not accept the basis of this question from Senator Hill. The recall of Dr Russell is a recall for the Prime Minister's office and the improvement—an addition to his staff in the Prime Minister's office.
—Improvement! You said it.

—I think by adding Dr Russell to the Prime Minister's staff, the level of the Prime Minister's staff will be improved, too. That is right. What Dr Russell has been quoted as referring to is from his personal experience as Australian Ambassador to the United States, and concerns the manifest evidence that one sees in major cities in the US of the existence of a permanent underclass of underprivileged people. That is a prospect held open for Australia if there were a Howard government in Canberra.

PARA.TAB: What Dr Russell is referring to is that the policies, to the extent that we are aware of them—certainly if one looks at the policy structures of state Liberal governments as well—are aimed at duplicating the Thatcherite, Reagan type social policies which give rise to such an underclass. It is a problem that afflicts the United Kingdom as well as the United States and some other economies in Europe. The policies that this government pursues are policies that prevent the establishment of such an underclass. They are inclusive policies aimed at ensuring that the people in unfortunate circumstances in Australian society have a safety net and are properly protected, and that their levels of protection are improved and increased commensurate with their needs and the ability of the economy to pay.

I know that the opposition has consistently gone off and pretended that it, a silvertail party, is the party of the battlers. That is another pretence at synthetic compassion from Senator Hill. Many of the allegations that are made by the opposition about the poor of Australia are not true. It is not true as this question, in terms of the way in which it has been put, suggests that the rich have got richer and the poor have got poorer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are too many interjections on both sides. Senator Cook has the call.

—One of the best ways of addressing this problem is by ensuring that we have a growth economy and that we continue the growth of employment. I have quoted often enough the statistics from the conclusion of the Howard period of Treasury incumbency—that is, the years of the Fraser government. Your record was of double-digit unemployment, double-digit inflation and negative indicators of economic growth. They go to the falling levels of social security protection you provided which gave rise to the threat of an underclass in Australia.

PARA.TAB: During our period of office, we have achieved sustainable economic growth. Employment is growing at a level faster than promised at the last election but still growing substantially now and expected to deliver 100,000 new jobs in the next period. Inflation is now at a manageable and low level and we have sustainable economic growth as well. There is no underclass in Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't the minister and his millionaire leader Mr Keating understand that, with 760,000 unemployed Australians and 1.9 million Australians living in poverty, Australia has an underclass?
—You could not make money out of a hotel.
—Order! Senator Bolkus.

—The underclass is the legacy of 13 years of Labor government. The point of the question is: don't Mr Keating and you understand that it is all to late to bring Dr Russell back? Dr Russell and Mr Keating jointly created the problem—the Australian underclass. Why won't your government finally face up to that reality?

—For the simple reason that it is not true. We prefer to deal with issues of truth and fact and address the real issues and not fall for your blandishments in terms of rhetoric. If one compares the level of protection for people who are unemployed or on pensions and the social security net—our government versus the opposition when it was in power—it flatters our performance and condemns yours.

PARA.TAB: Let me pick up a single aged pensioner, not renting. Under your government the value of their pension went down by 2.3 per cent. Under us it went up to 11.9 per cent. A reduction under you; an increase, by 11.9 per cent, under us. All of the other scales of pension protection are reflected as well. The social wage under you went down 17.5 per cent. Under us it went up 73.1 per cent. They are the reasons why I do not accept this story from the opposition that we have created an underclass. We have removed the underclass of Australia. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Senator Bob Collins. The minister would be aware of recent media reports quoting the Leader of the National Party pledging the coalition to hold a rural debt summit should it win office at the next election. Most unlikely, obviously! Can the minister advise the Senate of the government's view on such a project?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of this piece of populist politics from Tim Fischer. The interesting thing—
—Did you propose another economic summit?

—The interesting thing about it, Senator Alston, is this: what the coalition proposed to do in respect of the drought, the single worst crisis that farmers have ever faced in this country, the current drought, was that they have a talk to them after the next election—not before, after the next election!

PARA.TAB: What Tim Fischer is now proposing in respect of rural debt—I have read everything he said—is that he is going to have a talk to them about that after the next election, too. No suggestion that the coalition is going to pledge another couple of billion dollars along with some of the other promises they have made around Australia to actually bail people out of debt, just to have a summit after the election. I have to say that I hope someone on the benches opposite, and in particular Senator Brownhill, might take time to explain to his leader that this is not a two-minute issue. Mr Fischer appears to be blissfully unaware of the findings of the very recent report, Senator Crane—

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you finally noticed? You have woken up at last.

—You know. Tim Fischer has not woken up, Senator. You tell him. The Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Committee on rural adjustment debt and reconstruction was chaired, of course, by his colleague, Senator Brownhill. That committee held 17 public hearings throughout Australia; did a very comprehensive job, I must say, Senator Brownhill; took evidence from 262 witnesses; and received 290 written submissions. That was a very comprehensive job, I think, by any measure, that that Senate committee chaired by Senator Brownhill did.

PARA.TAB: In terms of this nonsense about having a debt summit, I would have said, in commending that Senate committee, that we had reached a peak—we do not need a summit—in terms of information received. Two hundred and sixty-two witnesses gave evidence to the committee and there were 290 written submissions on the subject of rural debt. Senator Brownhill might tell his leader about his recent work.
Why, then, would we want a summit? I suggest that Senator Brownhill might also point out to his leader the following conclusions from Senator Brownhill's report. I will quote from it:

ANSWER.PARA: The Committee considers that, although rural debt is estimated to be $17 billion, this debt is a symptom rather than the cause of more fundamental and deep seated problems in rural Australia. The Committee believes that responses and solutions should be directed to the sources of these problems rather than their repercussions.
The report goes on to say in part:
The Committee agrees with evidence that the underlying causes of poor profitability on some farms are fragile business structures, inadequate management performance and insidious land degradation.
Hear, hear! Tell your leader that, Senator Brownhill. I will quote from the report again:
It also agrees that improved business management performance is the key to tackling these causes, thereby developing a strong competitive and sustainable farm sector.

In other words, debt is not the major problem; it is a secondary symptom. Mr Fischer's attention might also be usefully directed to the recent report from the Prime Minister's Land Management Task Force entitled Managing our future, which we are going to have widely circulated in the rural community of Australia.

PARA.TAB: The banks agree with the government—we are continuing our dialogue with them—that the new emphasis on productivity is addressing the underlying structural problems in the rural sector. That is what needs to be done. That is precisely what the government is doing in encouraging and assisting farmers to become more productive and sustainable through initiatives such as the rural adjustment scheme, regional initiatives and the landcare program.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Trade: Ambassador to the United States

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. How does he justify the politically partisan comments of Dr Russell, our ambassador to the United States of America? Should he not now be withdrawn from trade negotiations and immediately replaced as he is clearly representing—
—The farmers would like that!

—For God's sake, let him listen. He does not say much when he talks, but let him listen to the question. Should he not be replaced, as he is clearly representing the party political interests of the ALP rather than the Australian national interest? Bearing in mind the failure of Australian trade diplomacy on the issue of US subsidised grain and the delicate stage of negotiations on agricultural subsidies, would it not have been better for the government to have appointed a professional to the office rather than a party political hack?

—It does appear that where I thought there were two hopelessly contradictory positions from the opposition on Dr Russell I now find three. I noticed Mr Fischer being very angry about the fact that Dr Russell is being recalled. We have now lost Dr Russell's particular access to the White House. He was angry that he was being recalled for purely partisan political reasons. He was concerned that we would not have an ambassador in Washington when we needed one. Mr Downer then said—
—What is the reality?

—I will explain something about reality in one second. On the same day, at the same time, the shadow minister for foreign affairs said that he should step down. He said, `If we are going to be left without an ambassador for a few more weeks, well, so be it'.

PARA.TAB: Are we going to have these two bumblers representing our country around the region? Will we put this pair in charge of the international representation of this country? It is like Dad and Dave. It really is a very sad reflection of what might happen. With great apologies to Rumpole of the Bailey, it is like Dad and Dave.

We now have a third equally confused position. If we recalled Dr Russell today, we would then have a several-week process by which we would get a replacement to the United States. It is our absolute intention to ensure that we have adequate continuing successful representation of Australia's interests in Washington. We will do that, but we cannot do it if we withdraw him straight away. It takes several weeks to get the replacement in place, so we cannot do it straight away.

Do you think we should keep him there? It would be useful if the two of you—three of you now—went away and sorted out whether you think he should go or stay, whether he should be replaced or not, or whether he should ever have gone there in the first place. It is a hopeless, confused situation and you are making an embarrassment and fools of yourselves. It is a very extraordinary situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —You had better get on the phone again, Bob.
—You should check your popularity again.
—Could I just present the simple facts about this? Ambassador Russell will be departing Washington as soon as it is practicable for him to do so. We will be ensuring that there is a smooth—
—It is a shocking action.
—You have no consistency.
—Order! Senator Alston and Senator Ray!

—We will be ensuring that there is a smooth transition and that Australia continues to be adequately represented in Washington in the interests of all Australians, including Australian farmers, as we have been until now and as we will continue to be.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me beyond doubt that, with the incumbent ambassador, Dr Russell, as a person who has just been appointed to a senior position in the office of the Prime Minister, he will have increased standing in Washington for the period he is there—not less. If the United States ambassador to Australia was appointed as a high level adviser to the President, Australia would think this was a great plus for our capacity to enhance our relationship with the United States, as the United States—which is much smarter than the opposition—will work out straightaway.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the minister actually heard the question. Would it have been better to have appointed a professional rather than a party political hack?
—Could I just comment on this tawdry situation? When we came to office Australia's ambassador to Washington was Sir Robert Cotton.
—He didn't come back to run a campaign.
—And he did not—
—Order! Senator Hill and Senator Faulkner!
—He was an excellent ambassador and we kept him there.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, Senator Schacht. It concerns the fifth annual review of Small

QUESTION.PARA: business in Australia. What progress has been made in developing the proposal to amend the Trade Practices Act as announced in your small business package released on 21 September?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Reynolds for her question and her obvious interest in small business which, of course, is never forthcoming from the other side. Yesterday the fifth annual review of Small business in Australia was tabled in the parliament. I noticed Senator Baume and Senator Murphy commented upon the report yesterday. Senator Baume was the only opposition spokesperson who referred to it. While I do not agree with his remarks, at least he took the trouble to make some comment.

PARA.TAB: Before tabling, the report was distributed at the international small business conference held in Adelaide in mid-September. It comprehensively outlines the range of initiatives that this government has taken to assist small business. That is a matter which this parliament can debate because the document has been tabled.

Senator Reynolds asked me specifically about the major issue coming up for discussion and which will be before the parliament soon. I refer to the government's proposals to address the issue of the Trade Practices Act and how it will operate to help small business in Australia. I announced the policy on that some three or four weeks ago and said that in the near future I would release an exposure draft of the actual amendments to the Trade Practices Act in this area. I anticipate that by the middle of next week that exposure draft will be made public. It will be made public for about a month and members of the Australian community—particularly the business community—will be able to comment on the technicalities of the drafting. The government will be more than happy to take fine tuning to ensure that what we have drafted carries out the effect of our policy announcement some three or four weeks ago.

I remind the Senate that the major thrust of these amendments, which are very much in response to the small business community's concerns as expressed to the government, deals with the issue of prohibiting harsh or oppressive conduct in the following three circumstances: firstly, when two parties are in a pre-existing commercial relationship which relationship may or may not be based on a contract; secondly, when the nature of that relationship gives one party significant advantage in bargaining power—the most common cause would be where one party cannot leave the relationship without incurring substantial costs; and, thirdly, when the stronger party knowingly exploits that advantage to engage in conduct or impose terms and conditions of a contract that are subject to a reasonable person test outside prevailing market conditions. As I said, that is the policy intent; the actual drafting we will release next week.

What I find interesting is that, since we announced the policy intent three or four weeks ago, we have had overwhelming support from the genuine small business organisations in Australia. Public comments, public statements and letters have been coming to the government saying, `At long last. Thank you very much for taking this action.' Two organisations—the Australian Chamber of Commerce and Industry, and the Victorian Employers Chamber of Commerce and Industry—have said they oppose the recommendations. They oppose the change. I think the problem they have is that they do not know whether they represent big business or small business, and have some difficulty sorting that out.

The most glaring omission is that in the last three weeks the opposition has made no comment on whether it supports or opposes these amendments. Despite all the rhetoric of Mr Howard that small business is the number one issue for him at next election, he cannot comment on whether he supports improving the Trade Practices Act to strengthen the bargaining power of small business people in this country. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to Senator Robert Ray, the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the minister to yesterday's blockade of Western Australia organised to protest against the Court government's industrial relations legislation. Will the minister give his assurance that the provisions of the Industrial Relations Act are sufficient to allow WA workers and all Australian workers under state awards to escape the excesses of ideologically driven governments? Will the federal government be doing everything possible to ensure that in future advantage is taken of legislative processes to give workers the coverage of federal awards rather than condoning the provocative and futile actions that we saw yesterday?

—This government is always concerned that workers have a choice as to whether they are covered by a state or a federal system of industrial relations. The exercise of that particular choice should not be frustrated by the actions of governments such as the Western Australian government, which seeks to reduce the wages and conditions of workers or deny them access to an independent umpire.

PARA.TAB: Just as the Industrial Relations Act has facilitated the movement of more than 370,000 workers from Victoria under Jeff Kennett—

TALK.START.PARA: —You are just reading a prepared essay.

—Legislation supported, incidentally, by you and the Australian Democrats—we are seeking that the same happens in Western Australia and we are giving our assurance that we will do everything to cover that. Some 16,750 workers in Western Australia have already transferred to the federal jurisdiction. Over 100,000 represented by unions have applied to move to the federal jurisdiction and are awaiting a decision from industrial relations.

PARA.TAB: The Western Australian industrial relations minister, Mr Graham Kiearth, is doing his best to stop this by saying that any union that seeks to transfer its members to the federal jurisdiction will have its rights in the state system immediately cancelled. It is not going to work. The workers are voting with their feet; they are moving into the federal system under the legislation we passed here in 1992. That is the same minister, incidentally, who said in today's Australian, `When he was shadow spokesman for industrial relations, John Howard's policy was more right wing than ours.' That gives you a view of an alternative government.

He has set a minimum wage of $317.10 a week in Western Australia—a wage set by the minister himself, not by an independent tribunal. Is it any wonder that workers will vote to go into the federal system when the federal system is a system which guarantees a comprehensive award safety net, a real no-disadvantage test to ensure that workers are not left worse off and access to a truly independent industrial relations tribunal.

Mr Kierath's first wave was put in place with the Workplace Agreements Act, which commenced on 1 December 1993. It provides for individual contracts and workplace agreements—and the agreements are secret. There is no public ratification by the Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission. What it did was to guarantee a minimum of $301.10 a week for a full-time adult.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why is the WA wage increase double that of the average federal wage increase?

—I know you're probably ashamed to hear all this, Senator Crane. On 26 September 1995 the Western Australian minister announced that this would be increased to $317.10. In doing so, he rejected the view of the umpire, the Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission, that it be $325.40.

PARA.TAB: There is no disadvantage test to ensure that workers are not worse off under the Western Australian legislation. The Western Australian Industrial Relations Commission has had its power removed to enforce minimum conditions of employment. Workers who seek enforcement of conditions have to go to the court, with all its associated costs and delay. The minister can suspend or cancel state awards or union coverage if there is a significant federal award coverage. That is what exists at the moment.

They go on now, of course, and are proposing legislation that would interfere directly with the right of workers to join unions of their choice, and it also breaches the principles of freedom of association. The postal strike ballots, of course, become a legal requirement and there is no immunity from civil liability after ballots—just the threat of criminal sanctions, even if the refusal to work is for health or safety reasons. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Yesterday the ACT government restricted the distribution of how to vote cards at polling booths for the ACT election. What, if any, are the implications of these restrictions? Does the government have any intention of proposing such restrictions federally?

—This action by the ACT Liberal government denies to ACT residents access to information to which they are entitled to assist them in making a decision which is fundamental to our democracy, that is, their choice of political representation. It denies individuals who wish to distribute the information the right to distribute it. It restricts people's rights to distribute information they want to distribute; it restricts people's right to get access to information they want to receive. It makes it very hard to understand why people want to do this.
—What's today's policy position?

—Ask me a question and I'll tell you. I can assure senators that the federal Labour government has no intention of introducing such measures. It makes you wonder why anybody would deliberately set out to legislate to deny people access to information and deny people the right to distribute information. And the answer is fairly simple. They perceive a partisan political advantage, because they detect, as we know, that there is likely to be a correlation between the socioeconomic characteristics of people voting informally and people who have a propensity to vote Labour. They think that, if they restrict this information, they will get a partisan political advantage, particularly from those of a non-English speaking background, who do not get benefit from the advertising that is presented otherwise and who can get access to information to assist them with their voting, to implement their voting intention, by the distribution of how to vote information. To say it can be done 100 metres away or, with respect to Senator Lees, 500 metres away, you might as well say it can be done on Cocos Island, because it is of no practical value to any citizen.

PARA.TAB: Why do they want to deny people the right to this information? It is the same reason they want to make it hard for people to get on the electoral roll; it is the same reason the Liberals want to do away with compulsory voting—because they think that each time they reduce the number of people who vote formally, they gain a partisan advantage out of it.

That is a very cynical and a very sad situation and a reflection on our democracy. There is no way this federal Labor government will introduce legislation like that. I am delighted that the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, with the exception of Senator Lees, has unanimously agreed with us. They have said that there are civil liberties implications in refusing candidates and their supporters.

All the minor parties who cannot get their how-to-vote cards distributed lift their inadequacy to the point of high principle. They lift their inadequacy and make it a virtue. But it is a very small fig leaf covering your virtue, I have to tell you. It is a serious problem about our democracy and it should not be being done here. I am advised that the Minister for Administrative Services will be seeking legal advice on the constitutional appropriateness of imposing such restrictions on information consistent upon the High Court decision on the implied right of freedom of speech in our constitution. Now that they have made that decision it needs to be consistently applied and applied as a matter of protection of freedom of speech.

I think the Minister for Administrative Services acted appropriately and I am pleased he has initiated that matter. I look forward to receiving the advice. I hope that the ACT Assembly will reconsider and reverse its position. What is it that they are afraid of in giving people information about how they might vote? They are afraid that they might formally do so in a way that the majority of the Assembly does not want. The people who cannot distribute their information and the people who do not want the information to be distributed are conspiring against the interests of voters to deny them their right of access to information and to deny citizens the right to distribute that information.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I preface my question with an excerpt of the speech given by the managing director of Tourism Australia last Friday at the 11th Australian Tourism Conference, who said in relation to Senator Evans's proposal for a levy on airline tickets to fund the United Nations:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . why should the travelling public be singled out? What this small example conveys is the enormous lack of awareness that exists for the key role that tourism plays in the Australian community. If there is one reason why organisations such as the Tourism Council exist, it is to react to incidents like this.

Given that this statement reflects the justifiable outrage in Australian tourism circles over your government's proposal for yet another tax on the aviation and tourism industry to pay for an institution which is totally unrelated to tourism, will you rule out the possibility of the implementation of another new tax on tourism?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure how it becomes a matter for the minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs to rule out the tax but, through all the hyperbole, if the question is `Will Australia act separately from any other country in imposing such a tax?', the answer is no.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Senator McMullan is a pretty good at these devious answers. I ask you straight out: will you categorically rule out the imposition of a tax on tourism or the promotion of it in the United Nations to fund the United Nations?

—I am sorry. If you think the word `no' is devious then you have a different interpretation of the language from me. If there is a universal international decision to do it, we will be part of it. If there is not, we will not.

—My question is to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. Yesterday the South Australian government announced that United Water had won the contract to operate the Adelaide water supply. What benefits will this have for Australian industry?

—This is a very sad decision by the South Australian government, and it is a decision that the South Australian government should be condemned by all Australians for making. There are very few advantages to Australia in this. There are massive advantages to non-Australians in this. They made a decision to outsource the management of the Adelaide water supply. They commissioned Boston Consulting, a foreign consulting group, to write a report. That report, apparently—because it has remained secret and will not be revealed—recommended that only two British and two French companies should be invited to tender for this contract. No Australian companies were invited to tender. There is a capacity for Australian companies to have won this contract. The Australians were excluded.

PARA.TAB: It seems that the South Australian government was working on the theory that if you are a foreign company in this country you are preferred; if you are an Australian company in this country you are out. There was not the slightest intention by the minister, Mr Olsen, to do anything about changing that.I made representations to him and asked him to reopen the tender system to enable an Australian water supply company to tender for the management of this project, on the basis that if they were not good enough to beat the foreign competition they ought not win but they should at least be given a chance to try. In my belief, if an Australian company were given a try to be a lead contractor, they would win.

The environmental management industry, the management of water supply throughout the world, is a major growth industry throughout the world. It is estimated that the world market for this industry by the year 2000 will be worth $600 billion. That is a doubling of the current market. Most of the opportunities in this global growth area will be in the Asia-Pacific region. A number of Australian companies are well placed to take part in this market.

The Australian environmental technology firms are among the best environmental technology firms in the world. Australian companies are winning contracts all over Asia and have demonstrated an ability to operate at the best level of international performance.
Let me give you one example. Memtec is an Australian water management and environmental technology company.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not supporting them.
—It conducts 90 per cent of its business outside Australia but is an Australian owned company.
—You have been no help.
—Order!
—You have done nothing.

—I do not know what the interjections coming from the Democrats are, but Memtec has been strongly supported by this government. We have helped it to win contracts overseas. It now does most of its work in the United States. One could hardly say the United States market is not a contestable market and not a market which demands excellence. It is a market which demands excellence and it is contestable.

PARA.TAB: Australians win in that market, but the South Australian government won't allow Australians to win in the Australian market, and that is the tragedy here. The South Australian government, if it had chosen an Australian contractor, would have enabled Australians to build a bigger basis of their credentials at home so that they would be better able to win contracts abroad.

Mr Olsen has said there are 1,100 jobs coming out of this and $628 million in exports. Phooey! Rubbish! The way in which this company will save money is by sacking people and shedding labour in the private sector. None of the figuring on this has been revealed publicly. It is all secret. You cannot access it. They won't show you. No-one can prove it. Can anyone believe that a French multinational and a British multinational would allow an Australian company and its partners to tender against them in foreign markets? (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Faulkner. You will be aware of a statement in the Cairns Post that discussions have been held between the Australian Conservation Foundation and the federal government about turning Cape York into a wilderness zone. Could I have your response to three matters? Have discussions been held with the ACF on this matter? What is the attitude of the Commonwealth government to the ACF's proposal? Have you, any other government minister or departmental officer had discussions with the Goss government to turn Cape York into a wilderness zone, a similar reserve system or any other type of reserve which could change current land tenure arrangements?

—The Queensland and Commonwealth governments have enjoyed a cooperative approach to the first stage of the Cape York Peninsula land use study which included the collection of data and information. This cooperative approach is expected to continue before and during stage 2 of the CYPL study, which goes to the development of principles, policies and mechanisms for the management of the area. I can inform Senator Boswell, through you, Mr President, that I have no proposal before me regarding a World Heritage nomination for Cape York.
—I refer to the statement by Trish Caswell where she says she has had discussions with either your department or you. Could you confirm or deny that those discussions took place?

—It is common knowledge that for at least a decade, and possibly for two, the Australian Conservation Foundation has had the proposal for Cape York's World Heritage Listing on its indicative list. This is something that is not a secret; it could be made available even to you, Senator Boswell.

PARA.TAB: In the many discussions I have with many environment groups around Australia, they present their views to me very regularly in relation to these and any number of other matters. It is not a secret that the Australian Conservation Foundation has argued for a very long time in support of its position which goes to a prospective listing of Cape York on the World Heritage list. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President—
—Nice tie.

—Thank you, Senator Vanstone. My question is directed to the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. In December last year, Minister, you opened the northern suburbs Migrant Resource Centre in Mirrabooka in Western Australia. Given the phenomenal population growth in Perth's outer northern suburbs, and given the fact that the area is increasingly attractive to migrants of non-English speaking background, can you inform the Senate how the new centre is keeping pace with demand and how its services have developed over its 10-month existence?

—I must thank Senator McKiernan not just for his question today but also for his continued strong personal support for the northern suburbs Migrant Resource Centre. As he points out, I opened the centre at the end of last year. I did so having decided to act on a recommendation to relocate Perth's northern Migrant Resource Centre from the inner suburbs to the area of greatest need—that is, the outer northern suburbs of Perth.
