We chose that area particularly, as Senator McKiernan mentions, because that part of the country is growing. In fact, migration is at the core of the growth in that particular region of Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: In terms of that growth, it is worth placing on the record that between the two censuses of 1986 and 1991 the proportion of residents in the city of Wanneroo who were of non-English speaking background jumped by 34 per cent. In fact, in the neighbouring city of Stirling it jumped by 31 per cent. In looking at the similar sets of figures and assessments released regularly by the Bureau of Immigration and Population Research, it is clear that those figures will be at an even higher level at the next census.

We felt this was the appropriate place to start the northern suburbs Migrant Resource Centre. I was pleased to be able to make that decision last year. I was also pleased to go back there last week to see how the centre had developed a range of comprehensive and impressive services over a very short period.

They are working with a core funded staff of four people and three grant-in-aid workers. In doing so, they provide advocacy, referral and welfare services. They have also established cooperative arrangements with other agencies which work from the MRC from time to time to look after clients and to manage programs. As well, they have also run an extremely impressive and successful campaign to involve the local community as members. At least 340 or 350 people are members of the MRC today.

To justify the decision to take the centre out there, the MRC's caseload will give you an idea of how busy it has been. In the first eight months of this year, the MRC helped some 1,400 clients from 75 different countries of origin. The demand for casework assistance has been greatest from people who arrived in WA from the former Yugoslavia, Burma, Vietnam, the Philippines, Rumania, Afghanistan, Iraq, India and several other African countries. For instance, in terms of community involvement, over the period from June to September this year more than 1,000 people used the centre for meetings, classes and community functions.

The demands are increasing, Senator McKiernan. I am sure you would know that. They are increasing to such a level where more space is needed particularly as bodies like the community policing council of WA, the welfare rights and advocacy service, the Vietnamese community in WA and Relationships Australia have full-time or sessional workers operating from the premises. In response to this, I have decided to provide funds to get additional premises so the MRC can accommodate these valuable workers. The premises are next door and they will be used to provide extension space for the MRC.

I am pleased that the MRC has gone so well in such a short time. I am also sure that those who criticised the decision this time last year to establish the northern suburbs MRC will be in no doubt today that it is a very important resource for that particular part of Western Australia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. I refer the minister to Ms Jennie George's comments to the few protesters on the steps of Western Australia's Parliament House yesterday. Ms George said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . that the action was just the beginning of an ongoing campaign which would now see the focus move to industry-by-industry action.

Following the obvious endorsement by you and the government of yesterday's attempted Keating supported blockade of Western Australia, I ask: is this not further evidence of the conspiracy between Prime Minister Keating and the ACTU to incite industrial action in the lead-up to the next election? Is this action not just for political purposes even though it will seriously damage industry?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought the question had other parts, but it has only one part so let me answer that part directly. Let me do so by quoting the Victorian Premier, Jeff Kennett. Mr Kennett said yesterday:

ANSWER.PARA: The fact that the Prime Minister makes comment on it now—
this is referring to the rally and blockade—
is a matter for public record, but I do not think his comments after the strike had been called actually inspired the strike.

A media report on the wire reported that Jeff Kennett said that he did not believe the Prime Minister, Paul Keating, had inspired the blockade as it was an issue between the Western Australian union movement and the WA government. I am invited to answer a question from Senator Crane which indicated that there is a conspiracy here. There is not a conspiracy and there never was. It existed as a figment of your imagination. That is clear and on the record. It is unequivocal.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are the names of these people who turned up?
—You want their names so that you can take action against them.
—Order! Senator Ray and Senator Alston!

—This is a statement from Jeff Kennett, the Liberal Premier in the state of Victoria, who does know a bit about industrial relations and is responsible for some of the worst industrial laws in this country. He is not in our camp. He is one of yours and he is in your camp. He says there is no conspiracy, Senator Crane. Do not come in here telling us about a conspiracy. Why do you not do the right and proper thing as a senator representing the state of Western Australia—
—How many came. Very few!
—Order! Senator Alston!

—I am a representative in the Senate of the state of Western Australia. I am disgusted by the Western Australian state government's industrial relations laws and believe they ought to be removed. Every business person in Western Australia who may have lost money because of that blockade should now write out an invoice and send it to Richard Court asking for pay on delivery because Richard Court provoked this dispute. Richard Court has been condemned, along with his industrial relations minister, by every expert in industrial relations in Australia.
—Your office has been on strike all week.
—Order! Senator Knowles!

—He has been condemned by every independent commentator saying that he is going too far. He has been condemned by the Western Australian Confederation of Industry and Commerce, the Chamber of Mines in Western Australia, the Small Business Association in Western Australia and many of the members of his own party in Western Australia. So do not try to put this albatross of conspiracy around our neck. Not even Jeff Kennett believes that. No-one else believes it so do not continue with this fiction. If people have been hurt by this blockade—and I am sincerely sorry if they have—I point out that the provokers of it, those who are responsible for creating the chain reaction that led to it, are the ones who take the blame in the beginning.

PARA.TAB: I will conclude with this point. Many people in business—and I have cited a number of the business organisations—are concerned about the excessive, ideologically driven zeal of this minister and that government in Western Australia who espouse the industrial relations policies of John Howard and try to implement them in the state of Western Australia. They are concerned about it. They appreciate the level of industrial harmony brought to this country by the Australian Labor government and they appreciate that we know about industrial relations. The level of strikes is now at a 40-year low. They look back with disgust and horror at any possibility that the strike level would again rise—and we are seeing this with the chaos in Western Australia—should a Howard government every come to the Treasury benches in Canberra.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I will just say to you, Minister: don't tell me what to do when I ask a question.
—Or you will do what?

—I will deal with you. My question to you is very simple and is in two parts. Why was your office on strike yesterday, how long have they been on strike and when are they going to go back to work? In the process of answering that question, will you tell us whether or not you support the position of industry by industry industrial action which will seriously damage those industries that you represent as a minister of the crown?

—The supplementary is more complicated than the original question and I only have a minute to answer it. You beauty! What an absolute joke! My office was closed down yesterday, Senator Crane, because my staff, along with a lot of other workers in Western Australia, were rallying in support of industrial democracy and fair and proper industrial standards and expressing their solidarity and opposition to the Western Australian draconian industrial relations laws. That is where they were.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There are far too many interjections.

—That is where they were and that is what they were doing. The best way industry in Australia can indemnify itself from the sort of industrial action that we have seen in the state of Western Australia yesterday is by supporting the election of a federal Labor government and ensuring that our ability to handle industrial relations to reduce the level of disputation, which I repeat is at a 40 year low in Australia now—lower than since the war—is by supporting Labor. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government. I refer to the UN conference on inhumane weapons last week which ended without any resolution at all to limit the use of anti-personnel mines. Indeed, Australia's compromise position was rejected. Now that the politics of compromise has failed, what urgent steps does the government intend to take on this life and death issue of such importance to Australians that, over a period of seven weeks, ACR plus 28 other Catholic and ecumenical groups collected almost a quarter of a million signatures on petitions urging a complete ban on these weapons? Since this is a very important subject, when will the government make a ministerial statement in this parliament explaining what it intends doing about the situation?

—The government has made its attitude clear through statements by Senator Gareth Evans and Mr Punch on several occasions. There is a slight contradiction, I suspect, in your question in which you point out that the position Australia took was not accepted, but then go on to say that we should take a more extreme position that would be even less acceptable. We had to make the decision as to what we thought was possible but did not prove to be possible.

PARA.TAB: Nevertheless, our position was as follows: anti-personnel mines are different from other weapons inasmuch as they remain in continuance after the conflict has finished. That is apart from their general misuse which is a secondary issue. Our attitude was that all anti-personnel mines in inventories should be detectable and should have a self-destruct mechanism so that they do not remain a continuing problem as they have around the globe in countries that you know well such as Cambodia, Afghanistan, Mozambique, Angola—and, indeed, we still have many mines going back into the Alamein area in Libya and Egypt at the moment.Our attitude was that, if you could make all anti-personnel mines detectable and self-destructive, many of the problems would disappear. We had the support of a less than a majority of nations for that at the recent conference. Those advocating a total ban would not have numbered more than 10 or 12, in my view.

It is interesting to note that none of those countries, other than Cambodia, is willing yet to take the step to take anti-personnel mines out of its own inventory. So even those countries that have been advocating a total ban have not been taking them out of their inventory. Our attitude to this particular question is not to throw up our hands in despair but to persist in our lobbying efforts around the globe in time for the next conference—which I think is in June next year—to again push the position and to at least establish the intermediary step of making all anti-personnel mines detectable and self-destructive.

We are putting on ourselves the long-term goal of eliminating these weapons out of inventories around the globe as the following step. But before anyone gets too starry-eyed on this, Senator Harradine, I also have to put this cautionary note down that no-one else seems to be saying: that is, once you have done that, you will not eliminate anti-personnel mines from around the globe. These are things that can be built in garages or anywhere else. For those who have the malicious intention to misuse these weapons and to damage other people, they will continue to do so. Clearly, if you could get a total ban in the long term, you would restrict some access. You would not run into the problem of their being used for legitimate purposes and then having a continuing life and maiming people.

It is not that the Australian government has in any way taken a heartless or an intrusive position on this particular issue. Yes, our judgment may have been wrong inasmuch as we went for what we thought was a workable compromise and we did not succeed. But, if we had adopted a total abolitionist approach, we would have got no further down the track. We would have been worse off in our view.

But we are not going to give up on this issue; we are going to persist. We are going to try to get the intermediary position up of detectable and self-destructive anti-personnel mines. In the meantime, in the Department of Defence in Australia, we are working on plans to replace our inventory—limited though it is in the anti-personnel mine area—to make sure that anything we have in our inventory is detectable and self-destructive.

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect, Minister, I knew what you have said. I happen to be a member of the foreign affairs, defence and trade committee, and we have had briefings. But isn't it a fact that, originally, Foreign Affairs had the view that there should be a principled stand and a complete rejection of these weapons? I am just wondering why that original stance was undermined. Why can't that original stance be resurrected and you appoint, say, a roving ambassador to press this issue with various countries? I mean, you have other roving ambassadors around the place for other specific purposes. Isn't this a very vital situation? Secondly, Minister, will you respond to the question I asked: will there be a ministerial statement about this so that we can have a full debate about it?

—Senator Harradine raises three points. On your second point about whether we take on board a roving ambassador: I would have thought that was a job for the Ambassador for Disarmament, who is a roving ambassador and who will continue to pursue these issues. On your last point about a ministerial statement: as I have said many times here before, many things would be benefited in this chamber by ministerial statements. If only we could run the chamber a little more efficiently and have a little more help from you to do so, we might get more ministerial statements.

PARA.TAB: On your first point, yes, I am sure there are some in the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade that took a total abolitionist view, but that was not the overall position of the department. As they developed their views on it, they did not take a total abolitionist view. Also, they are required—they do not just make these decisions by themselves—to consult and operate in conjunction with the Department of Defence. The government position evolved in two parts. The first concentrated on detectable and self-destructive weapons and then made a further advancement after the first conference and before the second one to go long term to a total abolition. (Time expired)

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to Senator Cook, the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology. Minister, you would be aware of the rabbit calicivirus disease program being conducted by the CSIRO and partners on Wardang Island in South Australia. Now that it has been confirmed that the disease has escaped from the island testing station to the mainland, why have you as minister responsible remained silent on the issue? Is the outbreak under control? Have you responded to the letter from the South Australian Minister for Primary Industries who wrote to you last week? Lastly, can you guarantee that the strategic research will continue and that there will be no interruption to the timetable for the national release of the rabbit calicivirus disease?
—To take the last part of that six-part question first—
—Three parts.

—Three parts, each with two parts to them. To take the last part first: the program on Wardang Island has ceased at the moment because what is being investigated is not the effects of the virus, which is rabbit specific and not transferable to humans or other species, but how the virus may have transported itself from the island testing station to the mainland. So the program at the moment is on hold.
—They escaped from quarantine?
—The current view—there is no definitive evidence because the research is not completed—is that it may have been transported by bush fly.
—It was transmitted by bush fly?

—I am telling you what the scientific evidence is. You may be incredulous but you are not a scientist. On the first part of the question as to why I have remained silent, I do not understand the question because I have not remained silent. I have conducted a public interview today expressing the government's view. But it is appropriate that the scientific facts be best explained by the scientists running the program and in charge of detecting any transport of that virus off Wardang Island, and those people in charge of the program for containment.

PARA.TAB: I am pleased to say that I think the CSIRO's spokespeople and those involved in containing the flight of this virus have conducted themselves publicly in a proper and responsible way. I cannot say that the same is true of some of the reporting which is overdramatic. One headline I saw the other day, `Killer virus escapes', is hardly true in this situation because this is a virus specific only to rabbits. Its specificity has been established in 40 countries over the last 10 years. My office is in constant contact on this issue with those—

TALK.START.PARA: —How can they be? They don't work. They are closed.
—Order!

—My office is in constant contact on this issue with those who are in charge of this affair: the CSIRO and the South Australian government. The South Australian government deserves praise for the way in which it has speedily and very effectively started to deal with the containment and with the eradication program. The final comment I make—I am not sure I answered all the questions—is that this project is being conducted by a consortium comprising all Australian and New Zealand governments, the Australian Nature Conservation Agency, the CSIRO, the Meat Research Corporation, the International Wool Secretariat, the CRC for Vertebrae Biocontrol and the National Farmers Federation. It is the CSIRO that is the managing authority, as I understand it, of this experiment. It is aimed at proving the effect of this virus on Australia's No. 1 exotic pest, the imported European rabbit.

—As a supplementary I ask the minister—and one of my original questions was—is the outbreak under control? If it isn't under control, what is your response to reports in the Adelaide Advertiser today which suggest that, if it cannot be controlled, there will be a national release of the virus almost immediately?

—I said publicly today that there is a body of respectable scientific opinion that says that the best thing that can happen now is to let the virus run. That is not my preferred position; I am certainly not in favour of that. I do think that the CSIRO's approach on this is correct. Experiments should be properly concluded and reported, and a considered decision can then be made about releasing the virus in a controlled way. That is the appropriate course. On the containment of it, my understanding is that people are conducting the ripping up of warrens and the fumigation and poisoning of rabbits within a 14-kilometre zone at Point Pearce, I think it is, in South Australia. At this stage, we do not know whether the virus is properly contained or not—I am not sure and nor are they; but the indications are that it is contained.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—I have answers to two questions. Senator Knowles in question time yesterday asked me a four-part question, but in part regarding the appointment of Dr Don Russell to the Prime Minister's office, whether this was an additional appointment and whether anyone was sacked to accommodate this appointment.

PARA.TAB: I have been provided with the following information. Prime Ministers often do not take full advantage of their staffing allocation. At present there are vacancies within the Prime Minister's establishment of staff and ministerial consultant positions. As a result, the appointment of Dr Don Russell will not mean any addition to the existing establishment. Also I can confirm that no-one has been sacked.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 September, Senator Gibson asked me as Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations a question concerning the stevedoring industry levy. In addition to the reply I gave him on 27 September 1995, I undertook to seek further information from the Minister for Industrial Relations on certain matters raised by the senator. I have been provided with the following information an seek leave to incorporate it in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

ANSWER.PARA: In response to Senator Gibson's question that was it true that the Minister's appointee to the Stevedoring Industry Finance Committee had been removed from his position the answer is no.
In response to Senator Gibson's question will the Government guarantee:
(a)to repay to any shipping company that is found to have made overpayments the full value of those overpayments with interest;
(b)to pursue any shipping company that has failed to make correct payments, including, apparently, the Government's own ANL; and
(c)to impose the statutory penalty of 20 per cent on any unpaid amounts, the answer is as follows:

(a)under the legislation governing levy collection, stevedoring employers were obliged to pay levy, not shipping companies. Where a claim of levy overpayment is substantiated, refunds are made to the stevedoring employers. Any matters between the stevedoring employer and an individual shipping line are matters to be resolved on the basis of the commercial arrangements between them.
(b)where the levy may not have been paid in accordance with the legislation by a stevedoring employer the outstanding amount(s) will be pursued in accordance with the legislation.

(c)the Stevedoring Industry Levy Collection Act 1977 makes provision for a penalty, payable to the Commonwealth, where levy has not been paid by the due date. Penalty will be applied in accordance with the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Neal this day, relating to the privatisation of Adelaide's water supply.

SPEECH.PARA: The answer of Senator Cook was totally misleading, hopefully given in ignorance, because otherwise he would have known that what he was saying was untrue. The company that has been successful has to be 60 per cent Australian owned, for a start. The minister was suggesting that it was to be a foreign company. Secondly, the majority of the board have to be Australian citizens. Thirdly, the prices for the product will remain set by the South Australian government and the assets will continue to be owned by the South Australian people.

PARA.TAB: The minister also failed to mention the advantages of this initiative which is consistent with the competition policy that has been adopted by the federal government in Australia. The purpose of the contract is to create a further 1,100 new jobs in this area, to provide savings to the South Australian taxpayer of $164 million—you have got to remember that this was a South Australian economy practically driven to the wall by incompetent Labor governments under Mr Bannon—and the need for the South Australian government to rebuild the economic base of South Australia, which it can only do by getting costs down. Here is an initiative that is going to save the South Australian taxpayer $164 million. That would have been something that Senator Cook could have told the Senate and it would have been useful for him to have said so.

Furthermore, a contract was designed to provide a $628 million export boost for South Australia. The minister would have been aware that the successful contractor has to deal with established South Australian companies in order to build an export orientated industry in this area. This will be a first for Australia and an opportunity to lock into an enormous growth market throughout the whole of the Asia-Pacific region. It therefore not only is going to save the South Australian taxpayer money, but has got great potential for providing long-term jobs for South Australians and future wealth for South Australia that can be shared to the benefit of all South Australians. South Australians should be pleased with this first, this initiative of the South Australian Liberal Brown government and this minister should have come in and acknowledged the initiative, which is in fact consistent with the federal government's competition policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join my leader, the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill), in condemning the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook) for his outrageous answer to the dorothy dixer he received today. He gave a completely incorrect, misleading, parochial answer which in itself was completely inconsistent with federal government policy. It was completely wrong of him to suggest, as he did, that there was no Australian involvement. As Senator Hill has said, if Senator Cook had read today's Adelaide Advertiser, he would know that this contract requires that the consortium be 60 per cent Australian owned. That is a clause of the contract.

PARA.TAB: In the paper today we read that Mr Olsen gave a pledge that the company would be registered in SA with 60 per cent Australian equity. Its board would have a majority of directors residing in Australia. It was a term of the contract that there would be 60 per cent Australian equity by the end of 12 months operations. On the front page today, we have the Australian chairman of the consortium, Mr Malcolm Kinnaird, of Kinhill Engineers talking about the contract, the success for Australia that it represents and the advantages to South Australia that it represents.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is Australia's largest engineering firm.

—Exactly. Clearly, this government has never heard of Kinhill Engineers. It is a major Australian engineering company. It is a major part of this consortium. Its chairman is the chairman of the consortium. Clearly, his answer indicates that the minister has no idea what he is talking about. He ought to come in and retract it.

PARA.TAB: Another unfortunate thing about the answer is how utterly inconsistent it was with what we understand to be government policy in any event. The government proclaims that it is internationalising the Australian economy. It wants an outward looking economy and for Australian companies to invest overseas. It wants Australian involvement with foreign companies and, ipso facto, foreign involvement in Australia. You cannot have it both ways. This is not a one-way street.

Internationalising the Australian economy must by definition mean that there will be greater international involvement in the domestic economy. I would have thought, according to all the rhetoric of this government, that that should be welcomed. How would Australian companies feel when they tender for jobs like this in Asian countries if ministers in Asians countries spoke like this minister did today? He spoke in the most extraordinarily jingoistic, parochial fashion. He condemned any foreign company involvement in contracts overseas.

Australian companies, with this government's encouragement, are tendering for contracts overseas. We all hope that they are successful in winning those contracts overseas. How will they feel if ministers overseas take a lead from this jingoistic, parochial minister and condemn any Australian company that wins a contract in some Asian country where, we are lead to believe by this government, it is encouraging foreign involvement by Australian companies? It is a ridiculous approach by the minister. It is wrong in the first place. Even if you take his words on the face of it, he is condemning any involvement by any foreign company in any contract in Australia and, ipso facto, causing an enormous problem for any Australian companies which are seeking to have involvement overseas.

We share this government's enthusiasm for internationalising the Australian economy and for linking it into the international economy. That must mean that increasingly there will be contracts flowing both ways. Australian companies will be winning contracts overseas, and foreign companies will be winning contracts in Australia. That is healthy and good for Australia. It creates jobs for Australians.

That is also what was pointed out today with this fantastic contract which has been granted and for which the South Australian Liberal government should be congratulated. It will create 1,100 jobs in a state which was almost destroyed by the last Labor government in South Australia. Water prices will be controlled by the government. The government will still own the water and sewage pipes, treatment plants, dams and reservoirs. There will be exports to Asia worth $630 million over 10 years. Interstate water related companies will establish headquarters in SA. About 150 local companies will be on the short list to be subcontractors.

After what Labor did to South Australia, how dare this federal Labor government condemn the South Australian Liberal government for the contract that it has brought about. This is part of the resuscitation of South Australia after the damage done by Labor for 10 years.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Economy: Ambassador to the United States

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Hill this day, relating to the economy and remarks made by Dr Don Russell, Australian's Ambassador to the United States.

SPEECH.PARA: This concerns the persistent approach by the opposition on questions about an underclass in Australia. It is very important. They have been running this little line for some time. The people of Australia want to know—it is very important—how well off they will be under the opposition. The inference in Senator Hill's question is that they would be much better off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course they would.

—Senator Abetz says that they would be much better off. I will refer him to a few facts about what they did when they were last sitting on the Treasury benches and what their now leader did to the social structure and social benefits of this country.

PARA.TAB: It is very important to look at some of the facts, particularly as they related to pensions. We need to look at the coalition's position at the last election and see what it was going to do to people who were receiving social security benefits—particularly those on unemployment benefits. The opposition was going to boot them off unemployment benefits after nine months. What were those opposite going to do for young people? They were going to pay them $3 an hour. Some of the young people sitting in the gallery would have been the recipients of a wage of $3 an hour. Tell us how good that would have been.

Under Labor, age pensioners who were not renting premises have received a real increase of 11.9 per cent. If they were privately renting they received a 20.4 per cent increase. When we consider some of those things we have to look at what happened under the opposition. It is necessary to look at the social wage. For the information of those opposite, the social wage includes expenditure on health, education, housing and child care. When Mr Howard last sat on the treasury benches the social wage went backwards to the tune of nearly 18 per cent. Under Labor it has increased by 73.1 per cent.

It was very good of Senator Hill to come in here and ask questions about the social fabric of this country and tell us how we ought to look after people who do not have jobs. It would be very good if we had no unemployment. We totally support that view.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are you doing about it?
—I have to say to Senator Abetz that we have done a significant amount about it over the last few years. We have created almost 1,000 jobs for every working day in the last 12 months—at least.

PARA.TAB: It is important to refer to some comments in the Weekend Australian Magazine. Some beneficiaries of the social programs that this government has put in place were interviewed. This article concerned a place called Woodridge in Senator Ian Macdonald's state of Queensland. The report read:

SPEECH.PARA: In these circumstances Woodridge's unemployed and homeless young people, people like Angie, could be expected to give way to the attitudes of underclass—despair and defeatism. The following stories, however, demonstrate the reverse—that with the help of Australia's social support systems, even our most disadvantaged youth still have dreams built around strong notions of a work ethic and economic independence.
The article goes on to name people: Derwent Tranby, Kerry Stubbs, Lenita Cahill, Anthony Castle and Angie Greatly. The article continues:

. . . have all survived hardships including homelessness and long-term unemployment, and some of them violence and alcoholism as well. Most completed their schooling living away from home and, with the dedicated, years-long support of youth workers from the Logan Youth and Family Service centre, are gradually rebuilding their lives and planning their futures.
The article continues:

`We are not poor,' says Angie of herself and partner Andrew Bull, also unemployed. `We are big on spirit and big on hearts. We are carrying on the great Aussie battler tradition. We have everything (in a material sense) we need. We know what we want, but we are just taking a bit longer to get there than other people.

This is the very essence of this matter. This is the difference between us and you lot over there. These young people know what they are going to get under us, but they do not know what you are going to give them.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Economy: Ambassador to the United States

TALKER.NAME: Senator BROWNHILL
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —A diplomat is meant to be one who is just that—one who deals and speaks diplomatically. It is not one who promotes a particular political view. His actions are one thing; his comments subsequent to that action are quite another. They are absolutely inappropriate for somebody who represents this country. He is the one who should be censured. But this is absolutely a disgrace. To bring somebody back to head a department for purely political reasons when that person has disgraced Australia overseas before he comes back, does no credit for this government and does no credit for the Prime Minister. Prime Minister Keating is the bloke who sent him over there. He sent him over as a party hack and he has brought him back as a party hack. But he has brought him back too late to save this government that is falling into the mire.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Economy: Ambassador to the United States

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOB COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to respond briefly to that humbug, and that is what it is—political humbug of the highest order. I was not going to respond to Senator Brownhill until I heard him make the statement that Dr Don Russell has disgraced Australia overseas. I have never heard such—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Abetz, even standing you next to Dr Don Russell is a joke. Dr Don Russell has been the senior adviser in the Prime Minister's office for a long time, and it was a mark of the importance we place on the relationship with the United States that we sent someone with that kind of access and association to the United States. Dr Russell is a person of significant talent.
—He's just a hack.

—Senator Abetz, have a look at what your leader, Tim Fischer, said about him. I agree, Senator Brownhill, with Tim Fischer's assessment of Dr Russell and the impact that he has had in Washington and his `access to the White House'. That is a great compliment indeed to have from the Leader of the National Party. This government, of course, will ensure that the all-important negotiations on the US farm bill are continued as effectively as they have been to this point in time, despite the fact that Dr Russell is coming back to Australia.

PARA.TAB: It is nonsense to say he has disgraced Australia's position. Having known him for a very long time now, I know the talent of that particular individual. He is not only talented. Senator Abetz says that he is a political hack. He is far more intelligent than you are, Senator Abetz. Dr Russell in fact has so many brains that it has pushed all his hair out, as you may have noticed from recent photographs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know the feeling.

—Is that what has happened to you, is that your problem, Senator Baume? You could accept some of this nonsense—and they are going through the ropes, as they have to, tired old political hacks that they are over there—but to suggest that this could happen, particularly in Washington, is a nonsense. I just want to go on the record as saying that from personal experience I am well aware of the extremely high regard in which Dr Russell has been held in Washington, the great respect in which he is held, and the knowledge, of course, that the American people we are dealing with in terms of the US farm bill know full well the importance that Australia places on that relationship. I also know that the Americans perfectly well understand, being the democratic nation they are, the reasons for his return to Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology (Senator Cook), to a question without notice asked by Senator Crane this day, relating to an industrial dispute in Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: Following the outrageous government supported blockade of Western Australia by the TLC and the ACTU, there are some observations I wish to make about Senator Cook's answer. Firstly, I want to deal with the situation with regard to the staff of Labor members being on strike. Senator Cook insinuated today that that was tied up with yesterday's strike. It has nothing whatsoever to do with yesterday's strike. It is because their enterprise bargaining has broken down under the federal award under which they are operating.

PARA.TAB: One of the reasons they went out on strike is that, under the Western Australian system, wage increases over the last couple of years have been more than double the average of what they have been under the federal system. That is the principle thing behind it. To try to mislead this chamber in that way is irresponsible of the minister.

The second point concerns the comments by Ms George, chairman elect of the ACTU, that we will now see the focus move to industry-by-industry action. Relating to that question is my charge that there is a conspiracy behind this in the lead-up to the election, and that is borne out. One of Senator Cook's problems as a minister of the crown is that he cannot forget his old trades and labour council days.

He has to threaten people. He did it to me across this chamber today when he said: `Don't you dare ask me a question about conspiracy.' He also did it in the answer when he said, `the best way industries can indemnify themselves against further industrial action is by ensuring a federal Labor government is elected at the next election'. In other words, he is saying that this industrial incitement is going to continue until the election and then, if they do not get elected, is going to continue afterwards. If that isn't threatening the people of Australia and, in particular, the people of Western Australia, I don't know what is threatening a state or individuals. Senator Cook should rethink his position. We see the position adopted in the headlines today in the West Australian: `Power next target on unions' hit-list'. What is going to come after that? There are proper ways to respond to these things.

I acknowledge, as I did yesterday, the fact that at least the Opposition Leader of the Labor Party in Western Australia has come out once again against this blockade in the state. Not one of those people sitting on the other side of the chamber did that. They supported the blockading of the most productive, profitable state in this Commonwealth.

As Richard Court said yesterday, if Bill Clinton were to do something like this in America against Texas there would be civil war, and there should be because of the behaviour of people like yourself. You, minister Schacht, get up there and talk about small business and how important it is, yet you will be part of boycotting the most successful small businesses in this country. You cannot hold your head up in this place. Let me come back once again to what Senator Cook said in that answer today. He said, `The best way industries can indemnify themselves against further industrial action is by ensuring a federal Labor government is elected at the next election'.

Western Australia is not going to bow down. Business in Western Australia responded in such a way yesterday that they kept working. In virtually every workplace that was forced not to work the employees agreed themselves to make up that time without penalty. That is their attitude. They will not be intimidated by the actions of this government. They will not be intimidated by the actions of the ACTU. Nor will they be intimidated by the actions of the TLC, or anybody else for that matter. It is unbelievable that we have a minister of the crown here today threatening me and endorsing by default the comments by Jennie George with regard to the action yesterday and what she said on the steps of Parliament House in Western Australia. It was a very sad day yesterday, given what occurred. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is illuminating for us to finally see what the opposition's position is on industrial relations. The Opposition Leader, Mr Howard, has not wanted to do anything or say anything. He wanted to have a position that is not a position at all. This is a demonstration of the leopard never changing his spots. The questions in here and the action being taken by Senator Crane and his colleagues on that side of the chamber demonstrate that the opposition is totally opposed to workers having any right to defend their terms and conditions of employment.

PARA.TAB: With regard to the legislation that Senator Crane referred to, it has been reported: why should a state government have any right to interfere in internal union matters such as political donations? Do you want the same interference in companies and the large employer groups which make significant donations?

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't have to buy shares.

—There are shareholders in companies. You don't want that. You want to deny workers the right to protect the very terms and conditions that they have had to struggle against conservative governments over long periods of time to achieve.

PARA.TAB: Another matter that is very illuminating is that over the last 13 years of all of the wage increases that have been applied for under the federal industrial relations system the former Treasurer, now Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, and the coalition have opposed all but one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Government amendment No. 3, proposed Schedule 5, after item 2, add the following item:
"(3) After section 9:

SPEECH.PARA: As I said in my speech in the second reading debate, the purpose of this amendment is to implement what has been stated in various ways by two successive prime ministers—that is, to implement the policy of removing from export woodchips obtained from natural native forests. I would expect the government would support this because it is after all a reiteration of government statements. Two successive prime ministers have made this statement. Unless it be consigned to that growing list of promises which have the flavour of `no child shall live in poverty', et cetera, I would expect this one to be supported.

PARA.TAB: The expression of those prime ministers and the support they derived from the community after having made the statements about phasing out woodchips and protecting our native forests mean nothing unless they can be backed up with action. Here we have the opportunity for action. Here we have the opportunity for the government to be judged by its actions rather than its promises. I have made it quite plain that this is the opportunity which the government should grasp.

Far too often I have had to come into this chamber to do the government's work for it and to reveal and demonstrate where breaches of licensed conditions have been proven and where operations have been conducted in contradiction to the operations which have been approved by the government. It is about time the government actually did some work itself. It is about time we saw some action rather than heard promises. It is about time we had agreement on this amendment that I have circulated.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government is opposing the Democrat amendment.
—You surprise me.

—I am not surprised you are moving it given the fact that Bob Brown is standing against you for the Senate. I will not say that is your only motive but, if you are honest, I think it has something to do with it, Senator Bell.

PARA.TAB: The amendment before the chair is to prohibit the export of woodchips derived from natural native forests as from 1 January 2000. It is a bald cut-off point, that is the end of woodchips. It is important to understand that at the moment the government is concluding a process of establishing criteria, with the cooperation to varying degrees of state governments, to establish a nationally consistent reserve system right throughout Australia.

It was in December 1994 that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) announced that this year a ceiling of about 6 million tonnes would apply, subject to special circumstances, to export licences with respect to woodchips sourced from native forests. To be precise, the Prime Minister has clarified that the ceiling will be 6.025 million tonnes for 1995. Each individual application for an export licence for hardwood woodchips will continue to be assessed on its merits. The ceiling is an integral part of the government's approach to dealing with applications for woodchip licences and forest policy in general.

By the year 2000, the government will ban the export of hardwood woodchips from native forests in areas which are not covered by a regional forest agreement. This is a responsible and proper way to deal with the contentious issue of woodchip exports. It will not put a blanket prohibition of zero from 1 January 2000 regardless of circumstances.

In the development of our comprehensive forest policy, it is important to have an appropriate balance in managing Australia's forests. The approach of the government will be both to protect the forest conservation values and to maintain ecologically sustainable production of wood and paper products. The government's policy is based on the national forest policy statement, which has been endorsed by all state and territory governments. Senator Bell would be aware that last year Tasmania was not a signatory to that document but has since become a signatory.

The short-term implementation of our policy involves identifying areas that are known as DFA, deferred forestry areas, from which a comprehensive, adequate and representative forest conservation reserve system will be developed. This cannot be done overnight. The time frame will vary from region to region and state to state because of the differing levels of scientific data available.

I think this government can be proud of the lead we have taken in developing criteria for conservation reserves that are world's best practice. We are seeking in this period to conclude negotiations and establish the criteria with the various parties, including industry and environment groups and the state governments. That will be going to cabinet some time in the near future.

The current period for public consultation on the draft criteria will be used as the basis for issuing the woodchip export licences for next year. The Prime Minister has made it very clear that there will be a 20 per cent reduction in export volumes which will apply in states which refuse to cooperate with the Commonwealth. Hopefully, none of the states will refuse to cooperate with the Commonwealth.

The long-term policy has two components—the regional forest agreements and the wood and paper industry strategy. The assessment of the RFAs, as they are known, includes the assessment of the economic and social as well as the environmental and heritage values of forests in a region. This will provide industry with secure access to resources but it will also identify development opportunities.

Senator Bell, like myself, comes from Tasmania and we know that there are a number—and I do not think it is idle speculation—of proposed MDF plants, medium density fibreboard plants. I think they are serious proposals. There is also a proposal from Taiwan Pulp and Paper—I think that is the name of the company—to establish a new pulp and paper mill. There are some significant proposals for downstreaming the significant woodchip export resource from Tasmania. The industry has to have some security of resource for those proposals to advance.

The wood and paper industry strategy will chart the way forward for an internationally competitive and sustainable industry to produce high value added products. There will inevitably be woodchip by-products from forestry operations. What do you do with that product? You can either burn it on the forest floor, which I think is an atrocious waste of a resource as well as not being particularly environmentally friendly.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what they do with about 30 per cent of it anyway.

—That is because you will not let it be exported or you will not allow a pulp and paper mill be built in which it can be used. I think it is appalling that we are exporting hundreds of millions of dollars of woodchips a year. Those woodchips should be converted not only into pulp and paper but also into MDF products. We should be lifting the yields from our native trees.

PARA.TAB: Very significant new technologies will reduce the by-product waste that is turned into chips. I have seen some of this new technology, like laser reading of logs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very labour intensive stuff, isn't it?

—Whether or not it is labour intensive, the fact is it does lift yields in the industry. You do not, as the Democrats and the Greens do, advocate the end of an industry because employment numbers have gone down in an industry. That is true of almost every manufacturing industry in Australia. You do not say, `Let's kill the industry' because the employment numbers are going down. That is just mad logic—and that is what you are arguing with that type of interjection.

PARA.TAB: Conservatively, in Tasmania a very substantial proportion of about one-third of the state in various reserves, national parks and world heritage is forest. We have a very comprehensive system of world heritage, reserves and national parks which will be tested against the current draft criteria of the Commonwealth government that is being considered by the various industry parties.

On the importance of industry policy and value adding, I think it is dreadful that we export hundreds of millions of dollars of woodchips. We have a net deficit in forest products that I think is now approaching $2 billion. Imports of pulp and paper and pulp and various other forest products have skyrocketed. Yet we are exporting hundreds of millions of dollars of woodchips.

In fact, on the figures I have seen, if you can convert woodchips into pulp or paper or board products, you add 10 times the value of the woodchip—10 times! We could be a net exporter of forest products from this country. The simple slogan and solution of the Democrats and the Greens is: ban woodchip exporting from native forests. That is your simple solution, but that is not the solution to this issue.

I have laid out in my comments here this afternoon the proposal of the government. It is a phase-down of woodchip exports from areas that are not based on our proposed criteria but regionally assessed as suitable for logging. It is a matter of developing a creative and imaginative industry policy, very detailed, to strike a satisfactory balance between the requirements of industry and the need for a sustainable forest industry—and our policy is based on sustainability—as well as the important environmental considerations.

If the proposed 15 per cent of pre-settlement forest types are put aside throughout Australia, by international comparisons—of which 10 per cent is the norm—we would have the most comprehensive and highest proportion of forests of any region of the world in a reserve system.

I would just conclude my remarks on this very important issue and would urge the chamber to reject this simplistic amendment of the Democrats by alerting people to the sorts of consequences of the approach that they are taking. Looking at the forest industry in my home state of Tasmania—I know Tasmania is geographically relatively small to the rest of Australia and we do not have the same economic weight, but about 55 per cent of Australian woodchips come from Tasmania, well over half the good quality timbers in Australia are in Tasmania and about 12 per cent of the employment in Tasmania is in the forest industries, direct and indirect—certainly there have been some job losses, as Senator Robert Bell said, but you do not need to then follow his logic and say that you should shut the entire industry, which is what he is advocating.

Tasmania also has significant value adding products such as paper and pulp, MDF, craft and furniture. The industry is interrelated; it is not just a woodchipping industry. You should not be advocating policies of this type, Senator Bell, when you know the economic outcome of them in our home state would be catastrophic. In my own home city of Burnie, we have 16 per cent unemployment but, by any reasonable calculation, with no forest industry we would have 28 per cent unemployment—and that would be replicated right through other areas of Tasmania.
This is a very serious amendment of the Democrats. It is inappropriate in the circumstances given the development of our policy and it should be rejected by the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —The simple question was: here is an opportunity to invoke the statements made by successive prime ministers from your side. I did not hear the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) discounting their statements or, in any way, explaining to the chamber why we should not invoke the thrust of their statements. I do not know whether the parliamentary secretary is tired or sick of the debate or what it is, but a less inspiring contribution I have not heard for some time. I really cannot understand why it took so long for him to dribble out a fairly pathetic list of reasons.
—I thought they were pretty compelling reasons.

—If you thought that was breezy, I think you are in for a boring next couple of decades. We sat here waiting for something that was going to get us all excited about why this should be rejected out of hand. But there was only this pathetic dribbling out of some sort of vague understanding that Tasmania's future was going to be in MDF factories. It was a fibre driven and a chip driven vision that you gave us. It was not until the very end of—I wouldn't call it a tirade—that droning session that you gave us a couple of phrases about furniture and craft. But you really failed to recognise that my comment about the lack of labour intensity of the proposed new industries was matched by my understanding of the very high degree of labour input that is in the craft furniture industries—things such as the preparation of interior panelling and of high quality, high value products that we see around us in this chamber—which must be taken account of.
—What happens to the waste when they produce it?

—The parliamentary secretary has seen the photographs—he has probably even taken a couple himself—of the incredible waste under the present regime where we are so focused on chips and fibre that we see myrtle, blackwood, celery-top pine and other wonderful species all being lined up log after log ready to be chipped.

PARA.TAB: Yet here we have no attempt to remove this incredible demand. Six million tonnes of woodchips are being demanded. Labor's prime ministers in succession have asked for that to stop. But what have you done about it? Here you have a chance to implement those various statements and to stop that incredibly foolish waste. But, no, you deny it with a little bit of sophistry and a lot of boring delivery.

I think the industry deserves better. We deserve better than this fibre directed approach. We need an approach which recognises the non-wood values of our forests; that they are not simply piles of woodchips sitting there on stumps, inanimate, waiting to be fed into the chippers, to be slaughtered and given a crew cut. Our forests are not like that. They have incredible non-wood values, whether it be for the apiarists whom we saw mentioned in today's press, or for the cultural, scenic, flora and fauna, heritage and social values. They are non-wood values.

You did not mention that, Senator Sherry, in your contribution. It is really not at the forefront of your mind. What is at the forefront of your mind is some whiz-bang laser thingummyjig that produces fibreboard. Who really wants a future based on that? There is very little labour content in producing such things and very little aesthetic value. Really, it ought to be seen as a by-product rather than what is driving our industries. In your vision, it is not a by-product; it is at the forefront. Yet, we have seen Prime Ministers making these vague promises that we will not be woodchip driven, that we will be driven by other things, that it will be phased out and it will all be wonderful.

Here is your chance to deliver on this. Here is your chance to recognise the promise and turn it into reality. But what do we get? We get this pathetic little effort—and I could not resist contributing to it. I have better things to do than to respond to it, but you forced me to have another look at this and to recognise that your contribution is really nothing more than a reiteration of pathetic old cliches.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I had not been into most of the forests around Australia and actually seen what is going on on the ground, I might have been moved to tears by what the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) was saying. But the claim that he made that somehow or other the Australian Democrats are responsible for wood remaining on the forest floor and being unused is absolutely untrue. The reason that about 30 per cent of useable wood is left on forest floors, whether you go into Queensland, the northern part of New South Wales, southern New South Wales, Tasmania, or the south-west of Western Australia, simply has to do with the structure of the industry itself. The logs which they take back to the mills very often are sent in to the chippers and the large limbs which are cut off are simply left on the forest floor, and very often burnt.

PARA.TAB: Some 30 per cent of the available timber is wasted. That has nothing to do with the attitude of the Democrats in relation to protection of old-growth forests. It has to do with the chipping industry, which has set up these poor devils who drive the trucks in a structure in which they buy their trucks—they spend their $200,000, $300,000 or $400,000 for a truck—and they are paid on the tonnage of wood which they deliver to the mill. It is in their interest simply to take the logs and deliver them to the mill rather than take a mobile chipper out into the forest, chip the whole tree and deliver the whole material to the chippers.

It is absolutely untrue and flies in the face of all the evidence that timber is left there because we, the Democrats, somehow are opposed to the building of a mill. It is because of the structure of the industry; and it is a structure that could have been addressed by this government. Hopefully, it will be under the amendment which the government has inserted into this legislation at a late stage. I would ask it to do this—to administer the areas from which those chips for export come—in such a way that this does not occur. If a tree is cut down the whole tree should be used and the parts which are not suitable for sawn timber should finish up in chips, not simply left on the forest floor to be burnt or to rot.

In relation to the claim that somehow or other we are going to throw people out of work, as a member of the conservation movement since the mid-1950s let me tell the parliamentary secretary that for at least 25 years every one of the national conservation bodies has put pressure on and pleaded with successive federal and state governments to expand the area of plantations. They have been pleading, getting down on bended knee and saying, `We want to get out of forests. We desperately need to expand the area of plantations.' There have been inadequate plantations established. Consequently, now in the late 1990s we are still going into old-growth forests and chopping those forests down.

It is not the fault of the conservation movement or the Democrats, it is the fault of the former Liberal government, the present Labor government at the national level and successive governments around Australia of various persuasions. That is the reason we are still going into the old-growth forests: the totally inadequate establishment of plantations.

Where we do have plantations in my state of South Australia, those plantations are being inadequately used. The reason, again, can be put down fairly and squarely to the failure of this federal government to fund a rail line which would link Mount Gambier and the national rail system. I say to the parliamentary secretary that I have been into one of those whiz-bang sawmill establishments that does everything by computer and people just sit with their feet up on the desk, watch computer screens and pull a few levers.

TALK.START.PARA: —You increase the yield.

—I agree that it increases the yield enormously. Quite small logs can be used and good timber turned out. The whole thing is done automatically and it is really marvellous to see. The Auspine plant in south-east South Australia is a magnificent example. Logs go in at one end and finished, graded, palletised, stacked and plastic wrapped timber comes out the other end within 24 hours. It is a marvellous system.

PARA.TAB: But that mill could produce enough sawn timber to replace the timber which is cut from non-sustainable native forests in Western Australia for the purpose of house framing. The reason it does not do that is that the line between Mount Gambier and Wolesley has been cut off because of the standardisation of the Adelaide-Melbourne rail line. The broad gauge line has been left there. So you have one of the largest paper mills—you talked about paper mills—the Kimberly-Clark mill in the south-east of South Australia, producing 100,000 tonnes of paper a year yet they have to send that out on trucks. That is a very inefficient way of getting that material into the market. It must be almost unique in the world. That major mill, which wants to expand, is being inhibited by the failure of a suitable rail transport system.

The Auspine plant is cutting less timber than is being produced because of the speed with which the pine trees in the plantation are growing. That plant could provide timber to the Perth market cheaper than one could get that timber for house framing out of the native forests of Western Australia, all for the want of $5 million which is required from the federal Department of Transport to upgrade that line. To come back at us and say that we are somehow inhibiting the expansion of the industry either into paper or sawn timber does not sit very well with the facts.

You also talked about sustainability. I suspect from the words you used that what you meant—my colleague Senator Bell has already referred to this—is a sustainable supply of wood. That is what you mean by sustainability: cellulose fibre in the form of wood. You have no interest in, probably even no understanding of, the fact that the forests represent a wide range of values, values in terms of threatened species of other plants, the value of the forest in terms of water catchment and aesthetic appeal, the value of human recreation and the value of the forest in terms of clean air and water. When you talk about sustainability you should be talking about sustaining all those values in a long-term indefinite future. That is what sustainability means but that is not what the forest industry in Australia has in mind.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is what this government has in mind.

—I am coming to that, Parliamentary Secretary. When Senator Bell introduced his amendment, he pointed to a couple of statements which have been made by prime ministers of this country—Mr Hawke and Mr Keating. In 1991 Mr Hawke made a statement that he would phase out export woodchips by the year 2000. It was an unequivocal statement. You today have attempted to modify that and say, `We are interpreting that in such and such a way.' But he made an unequivocal statement. The conservation movement around Australia has been quoting that statement since 1991 and nobody on your side has been saying, `Hang on, that is not what the prime minister meant. You have never disabused the conservation movement that what you intended to do was to phase out export woodchips by the year 2000.

PARA.TAB: Through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, what I want from the parliamentary secretary at the table is this: will you state unequivocally that Mr Hawke did not mean that the Labor government will phase out woodchip exports by the year 2000? Is that what he meant? You are actually saying now you have no intention of phasing out woodchip exports by the year 2000? That is what most people in Australia took Mr Hawke's statement to mean, just as he made the statement about no child living in poverty only a year before that. We know what that statement actually has come to mean. Did he mean that woodchip exports would be phased out by the year 2000 or did he not? What is the position of your government? Are you going to phase out woodchip exports by the year 2000 or are you not?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already contributed, I think, about 15 minutes to this debate and covered the issue adequately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make some comments in regard to this amendment and to place on record the Greens (WA) position, but I have some questions as well through Senator Bell for the Democrats regarding aspects of the amendment and some suggestions for amendments. I will not move on those until I have had some kind of response from the Democrats.
—Are you going to circulate them?
—I am just asking my questions and then I am going to put some amendments to the amendment. When I do that, I will circulate them, Senator Sherry.
—That's very considerate of you. If we did that, you would be very upset.

—I feel the need to comment on this. This is a democratic process. We are in committee. If we are addressing some amendments and we are not at liberty to move amendments to those amendments, you are actually radically curtailing the parliamentary process.
—You won't complain if we do that next time?
—I would never complain.
—Come on!

—If you worked to improve amendments so that they were more acceptable to the majority, I do not think the majority of the Senate would complain. The Greens obviously are extremely concerned about the export woodchip industry and its impact on the high conservation value forests throughout Australia, in particular, of course, in the south-west of Western Australia. In this latest proposal, which some people call the deferred forests assessment but other people call by far less favourable names, our karri and our jarrah forests are under great threat. Of course, woodchipping devastates our red gum or marri forests.

PARA.TAB: The first clause of the amendments that have been moved by Senator Bell—that is, 9A(1)—says:

SPEECH.PARA: The export of wood chips obtained or derived from natural native forests is prohibited on and from 1 January 2000.

My understanding, even though I understand there has been some moving away from it, is that that is no different from the commitment that had already been made by the government. So it is no considerable advance that will protect our high conservation value forests. We propose amending Senator Bell's amendment—I would be glad of his feedback on this—so that it would read:

The export of wood chips obtained or derived from natural native forests is prohibited on and from 1 January 1998. This is based on a 33 1/3 per cent reduction for each year beginning 1996, 1997 and 1998.

Apart from that, we do not see how this aspect of the amendment will protect the old-growth and high conservation value native forests that are under threat from the existing policy on woodchip exports.

PARA.TAB: Clause 2 imposes a penalty of imprisonment of five years or a fine of $100,000. The Greens have often announced our policy on imprisonment, which concurs with that of the state government. Imprisonment is a penalty of last resort and should be used that way. It should only be used to protect the community from physical danger and to protect somebody who is a danger to themselves as well as to the community. We do not agree with imprisonment for five years. We would agree with the fine of $100,000 if it were for each offence and not just a one-off. If it is a one-off, $100,000 is just a little fee for continuing to exploit our native forests. It will be no disincentive whatsoever to the woodchip industry continuing on its devastating path. The industry will perhaps complain because there will be a slight increase in the monetary costs it will have to pay. The main cost of the woodchip export industry is being paid for by the community at large because of the subsidies on the forest industry.

We wish to insert a third clause. It relates to a transitional industry strategy to be put in place which allows transitional arrangements and compensation to workers who are disadvantaged financially by a move from native forests to plantations. I am not sure whether Senator Bell is able to answer those queries, but that is what I would like to see. Would he be willing to agree with an amendment that made it a more stringent requirement to phase out the woodchip exports? Could he explain the reasons behind the penalty and whether it would be for each offence or simply for each company? Would the inclusion of some kind of transitional strategy be acceptable to him?

TALK.START.PARA: —My answer to the first proposition from Senator Chamarette is that our reason for proposing the first paragraph was quite simply that it is stated prime ministerial direction. We did expect support from the Australian Labor Party. I cannot understand why that extra drivel was provided to us by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry). He could have just accepted it, sat down and got through it. We would have had one minute on this and that would have been about it. The Democrats' reason for choosing that date is that it is the government's date. It is a little like the nuclear debate. We have been attempting on so many occasions to give the government an opportunity to vote for its own policy, to entrench in legislation its own hyperbole and to see whether we can do something with regard to action rather than promises. That was our sole motivation.

PARA.TAB: I can see considerable merit in hastening this process. At the moment, we are in 1996. The government has us locked into this six million tonne export paradigm. As you would appreciate, it is extremely difficult to extract ourselves from it. The Democrats would be pleased to see this circus stop tomorrow. I recognise the practicality of trying to extract ourselves from it.

The government will continue to make promises. We could well see the six million tonnes of woodchips being shipped away from Australia and disappearing over the horizon year after year. It has not done anything to implement the promises made by former Prime Minister Hawke and current Prime Minister Keating. It is entertaining to us to look at a stricter implication of this, but I am repeating that my reasons for doing this were to invite the government to deliver on its own promise. Secondly, I will explain the penalties. It was my intention that they be for each offence. Thirdly, Senator Chamarette, your additional paragraph on a transitional strategy is most attractive. That is where the government is lacking. We do not see any evidence of action there either. If during the process of moving the other amendments you propose that paragraph, we will support it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —If we are opposing the Democrat amendments, we will obviously be opposing the foreshadowed amendments of the Greens on this issue. Given the lateness of her amendment, I hope Senator Chamarette does not take offence if I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum that should have been tabled by the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht), who unfortunately was on duty before I could get down here. I am not blaming him; I should have been down here a little quicker. I know that Senator Chamarette will not take offence at my tabling it now.

PARA.TAB: I will go to the specific amendments that have been foreshadowed. I do not know whether you understand the serious consequences of your amendment if it were put into effect. I will give you an example of what would happen in Tasmania. Forestry, by its nature, is an integrated industry. When you log an area, you are lucky to get 30 to 50 per cent of timber that is suitable for building materials of sawlog quality. You are very lucky if you can get that quantity of timber with current technology. What do you do with the waste? You can either burn it or use it as chip, export it or, hopefully, keep it in this country and convert it into pulp, paper and other products.

The fact is that, by utilising the waste product, it is more economical to log. If you end chipping, in effect, you end the logging of very significant areas of forest. That is the effect of it. By knocking down the export woodchip quantities by a third each year over the timetable—and you have suggested that we should have plantations in its place—you are effectively saying that you would virtually end, within three years, the entire forest industry in Tasmania.

You accept that it should be replaced by plantations. I do not accept that you can do that, because, for scientific reasons, many of the species of trees that are currently harvested cannot yet be grown successfully in plantations. Assuming your premise that plantations should replace it, how can you grow sufficient timber in Tasmania in three years to replace the entire native industry that you have wiped out in three years? What are the consequences of stopping the logging of native forests in Tasmania in three years?

You say that there will be a transitional strategy and that the government will have to pay for the disadvantage of those involved being put out of work because of your proposal. There are only 12,000 people in Tasmania. I do not know what you are proposing to give them. It might be a few thousand dollars each.

TALK.START.PARA: —Alternative future industries.

—You want to get alternative future industries up in three years. Tasmania already has an unemployment rate of 12 per cent, and you want 12,000 jobs in new industries in Tasmania in three years to be created virtually overnight. If you understand anything about new industries, you would know that it does not happen that quickly.

PARA.TAB: I am using Tasmania as an example because I happen to know something about the industry down there. In Tasmania we will be looking at a bill of some hundreds of millions of dollars if Senator Bell is fair dinkum about his transitional strategy—let alone the rest of the country. The amendments are frankly absurd. What we have now is a contest between Senator Bell of the Democrats and Senator Chamarette representing the Greens because they are out there touting for the same votes. That is what it is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —And former Labor Senator Devereux.
—Well, a certain other senator. That is what we have here. Senator Bell is worried about losing out—
—To Bob Brown.

—Yes, to Bob Brown, who is a candidate for the Senate in Tasmania. I accept that you have legitimate concerns about forests, Senator Bell, but let us be totally honest about your political motives. You are not as pure as the driven snow or as pure as a Tasmanian wilderness forest on this issue. Why have you been visiting people in the forest industry in Tasmania? Why have you been making nice, reasonable sounding noises about why we have to have a forest industry? We have heard all about your trips around Tasmania, Senator Bell, trying to get the votes of people in the forest industry and trying to keep the Green vote at the same time. We hear about it daily.
