You are in a difficult position.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tambling is present and I merely want to say that the amendments that we have moved to this legislation were circulated three weeks ago. Senator Tambling criticised us for the process. We did not proceed with the act at that time in order to give Senator Tambling and other people in the industry time to look at the proposed amendments to the Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act, the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act, the Export Control Act and the Exotic Animals (Disease Control) Act. I am informed that we did consult industry on these issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the parliamentary secretary aware that we had a forest industry in Australia for over 100 years before we ever invented a woodchipping machine?
—Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to reply to some of the comments made by Senator Sherry. Firstly, I thank Senator Bell for his indication that he would be prepared to look at my amendments. Very rough notes have been circulated in the chamber because we obviously have been doing this on the run. I think he is quite entitled to feel that government support should have been forthcoming for his amendment. It was not at all unreasonable that he put it that way.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, if the government is going to renege even from its own policy and not support the amendment, I cannot see any value whatsoever in putting an amendment that goes against what both the Democrats and the Greens already fervently believe—that we should be doing it a lot earlier. I welcome the Democrat's support for the amendments.

I would like to comment on Senator Sherry's criticisms that if we were fair dinkum about the strategy we would not have done it so quickly. It was government strategy to move it out. If the government was fair dinkum it should already have something in place that would not make our amendments at all unreasonable because we have only moved it forward by two years. The government has had a lot of time since it made that commitment to put mechanisms in place that would allow movement across and out of the kind of wholesale woodchipping reliance that the industry has come to be so dependent upon.

It is more than time when alternative transition strategies should be offered as incentives to the industry to go on to a more sustainable basis which will protect and ensure the future of the people who have been employed in the forest industries and whose jobs are being continually shed—not because of any conservation movement, action or protection, but simply because the scale of equipment and technology that is being used in the industry has led to a wholesale shedding of jobs over the last 30 years. That transitional strategy is a very sensible one.

If the parliamentary secretary thinks that there is some pain in it, I think the pain should be on the government. It should be an incentive to the government to put something in place that assists the workers and addresses the employment difficulties that they might face. The parliamentary secretary's concerns about plantations and phasing out from one native forest focused industry into plantation, agroforestry or even regrowth lower conservation value forests is something that is quite achievable. The conservation movement has been prepared all along to provide assistance and cooperation in that area. A very impressive plantation study has been undertaken by Dr Judith Clarke which shows that it would be within Australia's capacity to phase into plantations almost immediately. It illustrates a lack of political will.

We are not going to get that, I assure my colleagues here and people in the community, if the government is continually politicising it and making it a fight between the workers and the conservation movement when it really is the government that benefits from the politicisation and polarisation. The government does not have to do anything. It does not have to amend any of its quotas or any of the woodchip export licences accept those that it feels it can bargain with pre-election. It is a disgrace that there is not a transition strategy in place that we could refer to instead of actually having a clause in the amendment.

As I am sadly confident that the government is not going to be enlightened enough to support this amendment, I believe that there is nothing at all wrong with making it as close as possible to what would save our native forests from the devastation that they are currently under from the woodchip export industry. Consequently, I seek leave to move my amendments to Senator Bell's amendment.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed subsection 9A(1), omit "2000.", substitute "1998. This is based on a 33 1/3% reduction for the years 1996, 1997 and 1998.".
Proposed section 9A, penalty, omit the penalty, substitute the following penalty: "Penalty: A fine of $100,000 for each offence.".
At end of proposed section 9A, add the following subsection:

"(3) A transitional industry strategy is to be put in place which allows transitional arrangements and compensation to workers who are disadvantaged financially by a move from natural forests to plantations.".

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a proposal to reduce the period of time for the cessation of the exporting of woodchips. Woodchipping currently occurs at a domestic level and is likely to go on at a domestic level for a long period of time because it is part of the process of making wood into paper and various other things. I say to Senator Bell and Senator Chamarette that, even if we are able to move to a plantation based industry right now or next year, we would still have a situation where there would be some residue from those plantations after cutting down the trees and processing certain parts of the trees. There would be residue wood and we would have to do something with it. I think it is important that we take account of that. We cannot ignore it because we do not want to waste it.

PARA.TAB: I would like to see the cessation of woodchipping but, regardless of what sort of industry we have and the base on which it works, we will always have a woodchipping industry. It is a pity that sometimes people do not support some pursuits with regard to trying to increase the value of wood. That is what we should be trying to do. We should try to increase the value of the trees as they stand. That is how we will really get the best in terms of downstream processing from the trees as they stand in the forest.

That is the objective that Senator Chamarette should be pursuing. I wish that some of the conservation groups would get behind the people who are trying to achieve that and bring about greater utilisation of the forests—whether they be native or plantation. I do not think that these amendments really head us towards achieving those sorts of objectives. I join my colleague Senator Sherry in opposing the amendments.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on this simple amendment has become wider than I expected but, then again, it does have extremely wide-ranging implications. I remind Senator Murphy that the words proposed in the first paragraph read `the export of woodchips obtained or derived from natural native forests'. So we are not proposing to ban the production of woodchips from either plantations or those other forests which are not natural native forests.

PARA.TAB: Your contribution, Senator Murphy, is really irrelevant to what we are debating. We would not prevent the production and export of woodchips from those areas that are not specified here, and plantations are not an area that is specified. I agree with you, and you are absolutely right: in plantations and in other forests there will always be the production of some waste material.

While I am talking about that waste material—whether it ends up as woodchips, whether it is left on the forest floor to provide nutrients for future forests or to return some of the phosphorous, which is absolutely crucial for the continued production; whatever happens to it—I think Senator Sherry should consider the contribution I made in this place, I think, in March 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wasn't listening—I am sorry.
—I think you were.
—Was this your first speech?
—No, it wasn't. It was two years after my first speech, Senator Sherry.
—Your second speech?
—It was about my 400th speech. I am reminded of this because I was searching the database only recently.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sherry interjecting—
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Calvert)—Order! Senator Bell, would you continue please. I ask the parliamentary secretary to stop chipping.

TALK.START.PARA: —The more he chips, the more I will mulch him. I am certain he was there because I recall an interjection that he made. In my contribution I pointed out that after a clear-felling, a craft licence gathering, a firewood gathering and a regeneration burn in a certain coupe in southern Tasmania there happened to be enough celery-top logs remaining for an acquaintance of mine to obtain those logs and build five houses. Senator Sherry, I can take you to those houses and I can show you film of the houses being built and the logs being dragged from the forest.

PARA.TAB: The point I am making here is that none of those logs needed to be cut down, they made no contribution to the regeneration burn and they were not noticed amongst the trash by those who sought firewood. I know that Senator Murphy, who was in the chamber recently, has photographic evidence of the degree of waste which derives from present forestry practices—and I am talking about forestry practices as of this week. There are still forestry practices which produce the sort of waste that existed when I made that speech in 1992.

That is what motivates me above all else: my concern about the fact that trees are cut down, are left and are not properly used. We have this voracious appetite. The woodchip material which is taken to our woodchip mills in Tasmania and elsewhere is really the cream of the crop. It is the stuff that is easy to handle and it is the stuff which fits on the truck. You don't see a truck of limbs, ends and inconvenient pieces. Invariably, we see travelling up our Tasmanian highways straight logs, some potentially millable and others which have some value for craft purposes. We see far too much of that.

That is a primary motivation for my being concerned about this, and I have been concerned about this since the day I arrived here. I have not been provoked by recent political incidents—they are part of it; I admit that Senator Sherry, I will be honest about that—but my primary motivation was revealed in that contribution I made many years ago. I continue to be concerned about it because you have done nothing to stop that happening. Your colleagues who sit close to you have given you and the ministers responsible evidence. I have waved and tabled photographs around here of that practice and nothing has happened. That has been a great concern of mine.

I think the woodchip industry is responsible for a huge part of it. As Senator Coulter mentioned, we had a timber industry in this country a hundred years ago, before the woodchip regime was involved, and it did not produce that sort of waste. It certainly did not. That has been part of it, but I will get back to the matter at hand. I had to address that because Senator Sherry spent so much time rabbiting on about having to burn the stuff because there is nothing else to do with it. Well there is and I have produced evidence here that what is being burnt is utilisable in other ways.

The other thing I had to address was Senator Murphy's contribution about what this was achieving. It is not. We are not being directed in any way towards where he said. I think we have just about talked this part of it out. We have taken this opportunity to remind the government of what its policy is and what it could do. Again I invite the government to vote for the statements of two successive Prime Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to ask the parliamentary secretary a very simple question. Did Mr Hawke, the previous Prime Minister, lie when he said in 1991 that woodchip exports from native forests would be phased out by the year 2000. A very simple question: did he tell a lie or did he not?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have covered the matter adequately in the contribution I have made to the debate.
—We will then judge the answer to that question by the way in which the government votes on this matter.

PARA.TAB: Amendments (Senator Chamarette's) negatived.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Bell's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Calvert)—Order! The question now is that the government amendments be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to return to that section of the bill which relates to offshore exploration. I am certainly pleased that a short while ago the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Sherry) tabled the missing explanatory memorandum. I refer the parliamentary secretary to the notes that refer to subsection 104(3). I am aware that the Minister for Resources (Mr Beddall) has been approached by the Australian Petroleum, Production and Exploration Association Ltd with regard to this issue. APPEA also communicated with my colleague Mr Peter McGauran, the shadow minister for resources and energy.

PARA.TAB: I would like to ask the minister to clarify a particular area that is of concern to the members of APPEA. I will quote from a letter from Dick Wells, the Executive Director of APPEA, to Peter McGauran. Mr Wells says:

SPEECH.PARA: There is one area of potential ambiguity, however, that we believe should be addressed in order to remove concerns about the potential negative consequences of a future strict legal interpretation of the provisions of the Act relating to work carried out in each of the three years of the primary work program. For example, if a company accelerated its work program and completed it within two years rather than three, a strict interpretation of the amendments could mean that the company could not apply to surrender in good standing because the actual and agreed work programs differ. The intent
of the Act clearly is not to penalise companies for accelerating their committed work program. In order to remove industry's concern, we—
that is, APPEA—

have suggested to the Minister for Resources that this issue be addressed by adding to the example which forms part of the proposed amendments. The addition of the following or words with similar effect to the end of paragraph (2) of the example in the amendment relating to subsection 104(3) could clarify the matter.
They quote it:

If the registered holder of the permit completes the full three-year work program commitments in the first or second year of the permit term, then the holder could apply to surrender the permit in good standing.

I ask the parliamentary secretary: given that APPEA made this request to the Minister for Resources, Mr Beddall, what consideration did the government give to accepting or acceding to that amendment—obviously it has not surfaced—and is the government in a position to give a clarification of this particular ambiguity?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen The Hon N.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the APPEA concern, their correspondence and the discussions with the department and the minister's office. APPEA is concerned that if a company accelerates its work programs, for example by carrying out the work program for the first three years of the permit term within the first two years, a strict interpretation of the amendments may mean that the exploration permit may not be in good standing because the actual and agreed works programs differ.

PARA.TAB: The act provides that an exploration permit may be granted subject to conditions as the joint authority thinks fit and as are specified in the permit, that is, in subsection 33(1). One such condition, that has been a standard condition of exploration permits for the last 12 years, allows specifically for exploration work to be carried out in advance of commitments and for the designated authority, that is the relevant state minister for mines, to create this work against future commitments. This condition is set out in full in the administrative guidelines issued in support of the act.

Work program commitments are set out on an annual basis in the permit document to establish clearly for the registered holder of the permit the minimum work to be carried out in each year. The registered holder is free to exceed this minimum program and, indeed, is encouraged to do so. There may be many reasons why companies would wish to accelerate their work programs. Recognising the considerable costs associated with offshore exploration, it may be more cost-effective for a company to complete more than the minimum amount of work in a given year to take advantage of the availability of a seismic survey or a drilling vessel. The condition allowing the crediting of work undertaken in advance was designed to encourage and accelerate efficient exploration. For that reason we do not believe the amendment is necessary. The concerns of APPEA are covered adequately within the act.
Amendments agreed to.
Request for amendment (by Senator Sherry) agreed to:
That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment:
At end of bill, page 6, add the following Schedule:
Section 3

SPEECH.PARA: EXOTIC ANIMAL DISEASE CONTROL ACT 1989

PARA.EMPHASIS: PART 1—AMENDMENTS RELATING TO THE CLOSURE OF THE EXOTIC ANIMAL DISEASE PREPAREDNESS TRUST ACCOUNT

SPEECH.PARA: The object of this Part is to enable the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Trust Account to be closed before 31 December 1995.
Insert:
`(1A) The Account must be closed on a day not later than 31 December 1995.'.
Omit all the words to and including `shall' (second occurring), substitute:
`Any money standing to the credit of the Account on the day before the day on which it is to be closed must'.
Omit the paragraph, substitute:
`(c)the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation (being the corporation established by subsection 5(1) of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act 1993); and'.
Omit `at the time when it is closed'.
Omit the paragraph, substitute:

`(f)in the case of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation—the total of the amounts received by the Commonwealth under section 53A of the Wool Marketing Act 1987, section 26 of the Australian Wool Corporation Act 1991 and section 79 of the Australian Wool Research and Promotion Organisation Act 1993; and'.

The object of this Part is to ensure that certain payments received by the Commonwealth in relation to the Exotic Animal Disease Control Act 1989 can be paid into the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Trust Account, before that account is closed.
(1) There must be paid into the Account:
(a)in respect of each amount of Exotic Animal Disease Levy received by the Commonwealth after 30 June 1995—an amount equal to that amount of levy; and
(b)in respect of each amount of penalty received by the Commonwealth after 30 June 1995 for non-payment of Exotic Animal Disease Levy—an amount equal to that amount of penalty; and
(c)in respect of each amount of prescribed levy received by the Commonwealth after 30 June 1995—an amount equal to the exotic animal disease component of the levy; and

(d)in respect of each amount of penalty received by the Commonwealth after 30 June 1995 for non-payment of a prescribed levy—an amount equal to so much of that amount of penalty as is attributable to non-payment of the exotic animal disease component of the levy.
(2) Interest received after 30 June 1995 from the investment of money standing to the credit of the Account must be paid into the Account.
(3) In this item:
Account means the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Trust Account established under section 21 of the Exotic Animal Disease Control Act 1989.
Exotic Animal Disease Levy means the exotic animal disease levy imposed by section 5 of the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Act 1986.
prescribed levy means a levy imposed by an Act specified in the Schedule to the Exotic Animal Disease Control Act 1989.
Amounts payable into the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Trust Account under item 8 are payable out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund, which is appropriated accordingly.".

PARA.TAB: Bill reported with amendments and a request; report adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: OZONE PROTECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1995OZONE PROTECTION (LICENCE FEES-IMPORTS) BILL 1995OZONE PROTECTION (LICENCE FEES-MANUFACTURE) BILL 1995

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 18 September, on motion by Senator Schacht:
That this bill be now read a second time.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Ozone Protection Amendment Bill 1995 amends the Ozone Protection Act 1989 to expand and consolidate Australia's implementation of the 1992 amendment to the 1987 Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer, made under the 1985 Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer. Furthermore, the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Manufacture) Act 1989 and the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Import) Act are to be replaced by new bills: the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Manufacture Bill) 1995 and the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees-Imports) Bill 1995.

PARA.TAB: Our consultations have revealed widespread support for the bill, not the least amongst industry groups. The Association of Fluorocarbon Consumers and Manufacturers, often referred to as AFCAM, in particular, have been very supportive of this bill. The ozone layer of the upper atmosphere is affected by the release of chlorine based gases, predominantly CFCs. These chemical compounds are used as refrigerants, foam blowing agents and propellants. Some 90 per cent of CFCs are produced and released in the northern hemisphere but global wind patterns have resulted in ozone depletion over the Antarctic. Commonly known as the ozone hole, this is the result of air movements mainly in the southern hemisphere spring.

The Antarctic ozone hole was similar to the 1993 hole, which was the deepest and largest on record. The 1994 ozone hole was slightly larger in area, with a maximum aerial extent of over 24 million square kilometres, occurring at the beginning of October. Another feature of the 1994 ozone hole was the abnormally high ozone values at mid latitudes to the south of Australia and New Zealand. I understand that volcanic aerosols from the 1991 eruption of Mt Pinatubo in the Philippines, which were present in the Antarctic stratosphere in 1992 and 1993, were thought to have contributed to the intense level of ozone destruction observed in these years but were not present in 1994 and yet the level of ozone destruction was similar to that observed in 1993.

There has been some debate and some statements in the press about the extent of the ozone hole in 1995. I understand that it was recently announced by the World Meteorological Organisation that there was a 22 million square kilometre sized hole. This apparently compares with the 1994 hole size of 24 million square kilometres. It would be interesting to get the government's view on this because there has been some concern expressed by the media about the extent of that hole.

Dr Paul Fraser of the CSIRO's Division of Atmospheric Research in Melbourne believes that the time it will take for the ozone layer to completely recover is 50 to 100 years. The measured levels of chlorine in the lower atmosphere have nearly stabilised. However, it will take at least three years for this to flow through to the upper atmosphere where ozone depletion occurs. Projections made by Dr Fraser indicate that troposheric chlorine in the southern hemisphere will stop growing between 1996 and 1999. Northern hemispheric and global atmospheric chlorine levels are likely to stop growing earlier but within a year of the southern hemispheric levels, probably between 1995 and 1998. Dr Fraser expects the stratospheric chlorine levels to peak some three to five years later. However, the stratospheric chlorine levels are likely to remain sufficiently high to initiate spring time ozone holes, at least according to the research, until the year 2015.

The Montreal protocol has by and large been successful. Twice altered to toughen its provisions, it has seen a 70 per cent cut in the consumption of ozone depleting gases since 1986. The global phase-out of CFCs is well ahead of UN targets. Industrialised countries, I understand, have virtually eliminated the production of CFC solvents, refrigerants and spray can propellants along with halon gases used in fire extinguishers. They have agreed to halt all production and importing of almost all ozone destroying gases by the end of this year and to establish time tables for phasing out the remainder. The Montreal protocol applies to developing countries but the CFC phase-out dates are some time in the future. Malaysia and India, for example, have until the year 2010 to complete a phase-out, with the process being scheduled to commence in 1998.

China recently announced that it would stop using CFCs in refrigerators by the year 2005 if developed countries provide it with enough money and technology. China is the largest consumer of CFCs in the developing world and it plans to build, I understand, some nine million refrigerators this year. Dr Fraser, whom I referred to earlier, has commented that `overall the Montreal protocol is working, both in developed and developing countries.'

In many respects, Australia is ahead of the rest of the world in its phase-out of ozone-depleting substances. This is especially so with the HCFCs. The Australian cap of 300 ozone depleting potential tonnes, which was endorsed by cabinet in October 1984 and by ANZECC in April 1985, is about one-half of the limit Australia is allowed under the Montreal protocol. The smaller limit has a further effect on limiting subsequent phase-out stages which are a percentage of the initial Australian cap. The rationale behind the lesser figure is that it meets the needs of Australian industry and will be an incentive to prepare for reduced HCFC supply. Thus, the overall costs to the Australian community are theoretically reduced. Reviews each two years after 2000 may further impact upon the HCFC phase-out.Australia phased out the import and new use of halons in 1992, before phase-out was required by the Montreal protocol which required the phase-out by 1994.

A national halon bank was established in Melbourne following an announcement in 1992. The bank will supply halon for essential use applications and organise the destruction of excess halons. The bank relates to one of my other shadow ministerial responsibilities, as it is administered by the Department of Administrative Services. It has collection centres in each capital city. Halons from decommissioned systems and individual extinguishers are deposited with the bank. Large concerns pay $10.50 per kilogram to deposit with the bank, while private citizens may deposit halon free of charge. The use of yellow fire extinguishers which contain halon compounds will be banned from December 1995 throughout Australia. I understand that, at around the end of November 1994, deposits with the bank were 100 per cent up on what they were in the previous year.

Australia will also ban the manufacture and export of HBFCs, which are ozone depleting substances not currently used in Australia, in line with the Montreal protocol, which specifies a total phase-out by 1996. The import of HBFCs will be banned unless an essential uses license is granted.

Under the existing regime in the principal act, Australia will phase out the manufacture and importation of CFCs by 1 January 1996, as required under the Montreal protocol. Thus, the bill terminates current licences for CFCs, halons, carbon tetrachloride and methyl chloroform on 31 December 1995. It will, however, establish a system of essential use licenses for the import and manufacture of these substances to be used for extremely specific essential uses. There will also be a system of used substances licenses for the import and export of used or reclaimed ozone depleting substances.

HCFCs will be phased out by industry self-regulation under a gradually-reducing industry limit, reaching zero use by 2030. However, most HCFCs will be phased out by the year 2015, and the only Australian manufacturer will cease production by the end of 1995.

The purpose of the Ozone Protection (License Fees—Manufacture) Bill 1995 is to impose licence fees for controlled substances licenses for the manufacture of HCFCs and methyl bromide under the Ozone Protection Act 1989. The purpose of the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees—Imports) Bill 1995 is to impose license fees for controlled substances licenses for the import of HCFCs and methyl bromide under the Ozone Protection Act 1989.

While the Association of Fluorocarbon Consumers and Manufacturers support the bills, they have mentioned to me and, I am sure, to other senators that they have set up a non-profit body, Refrigerant Reclaim Australia, to recover, recycle and safely destroy ozone depleting refrigerants. It is financed by a $1 per kilogram voluntary industry levy, which has received income tax exemption from the Australian Taxation Office. However, sales tax is payable on the voluntary contribution as it forms part of the final price. AFCAM believes this interpretation is erroneous and does not take into account the voluntary nature and purpose of the levy and says that the introduction of the ozone bills presents a timely opportunity to review the sales tax situation.
As I said at the commencement, the coalition strongly supports the bills which are currently before the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —The package of bills before the chamber, as has already been indicated in the second reading speech of the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction (Senator Schacht) and in the speech just given by Senator Kemp, is to move the legislation forward in relation to the use and release of ozone depleting substances, something which has quite a considerable history. I want to come back to that in a moment. The Australian Democrats would have no objection to any aspect of that.

PARA.TAB: Running very quickly through what this package of bills does, it amends the Ozone Protection Act, the principal act, to expand and consolidate Australia's implementation of the 1992 amendment to the Montreal protocol. The Montreal protocol was based originally on the Vienna convention. The legislation repeals the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees—Manufacture) Act 1989 and the Ozone Protection (Licence Fees—Imports) Act 1989 and replaces it with new legislation. It terminates current licences for CFCs, chlorofluorocarbons, halon, methyl chloroform—more correctly, 111 trichlor ethane—and carbon tetrachloride from 31 December 1995. It establishes a new system of essential use licenses for the manufacture and import of these substances and used substances licences for these substances beyond 1 January 1996 for limited purposes under the Montreal protocol.

It establishes an Australian cap—that is, an industry limit plus a reserve HCFC quota for the manufacture, import and export of HCFCs, the hydrofluorocarbons. It phases out the HCFCs by industry by self-regulation under a gradually reducing industry limit reaching zero, as has already been mentioned, by the year 2030. It will establish controlled substances licences for the manufacture, import and export of HCFCs below the industry limit. It will activate a two-year HCFC quota allocation period for the licences where the 90 per cent, that is, the threshold of the industry, is exceeded.

It will allocate reserve HCFCs quota to licences where exceptional circumstances exist. It will establish controlled substances licenses for methyl bromide. It will ban the export and import of HCFCs. It will establish a new user-pays licensing and administrative scheme and an ozone protection trust fund or an ozone protection reserve, provided the Financial Management Accountability Bill 1994 is enacted, to fund administration and information programs for HCFCs and methyl bromide. So far so good.

The minister has been very self-congratulatory in his second reading speech about the way in which government has over a number of years handled this situation of ozone depletion. I want to put on record that the record of this government and of the previous government prior to 1983 is atrocious. Moreover, that pattern of inadequacy is now being witnessed in another very important global environmental dimension, namely, greenhouse gas emissions.

I would like to run very quickly through the history of chlorofluorocarbons and their damaging effect on stratospheric ozone, with the consequent reduction in that ozone and an increase in ultraviolet light penetrating to the surface of the earth, with a predicted increase in skin cancers and general environmental damage in relation to a whole host of species, both animal and plant.

It is interesting that only just the other day it was announced that the Nobel Prize for chemistry for this year was given to Drs Rowland and Molina, the two American scientists who in 1974 first posed a very significant question. We have been producing these CFCs which are remarkably stable. One of the reasons why they came into use in the 1930s was that they were so stable. We have been producing these substances since the 1930s. They asked: where the devil in the environment are they going?

Some earlier work, which dates back to about 1972, had indicated that under certain conditions these substances would break down and that that could be done by intense ultraviolet light. Rowland and Molina looked around for a sink where these substances might finish up. They noted the substances were generally not soluble in water; they were not likely to be washed out of the atmosphere by rain. They postulated that these substances would rise gradually through the earth's atmosphere and get up to the stratosphere at the higher levels of 15, 20, 25 or 30 kilometres where the intense ultraviolet light would break them down. They said, `My god, when they get up there and break down, they are likely to release chlorine atoms. They will then decrease the level of ozone. Chlorine will combine with ozone and form chlorineoxide. The chlorineoxide will break down and the chlorine atom will be released and will attack another molecule of ozone. One atom of chlorine released from a CFC can then catalyse the breakdown of very large amounts of ozone.'

It was predicted back in 1974 that the release of these substances would lead to a decrease in the ozone layer, in the stratosphere, which in turn would lead to an increase in the amount of ultraviolet light reaching the surface of the earth. In 1976, only two years later, the National Academy of Sciences in the US had looked at this and said, `Yes, looking at the postulated reaction mechanisms we think that this is very likely.' That was in 1976. It was 1988 before the Australian government chose to move to control the use and the release of ozone depleting substances.

So, far from acting quickly and far from industry being responsive to very good scientific evidence from the National Academy of Sciences in the US in 1976, we saw industry resisting. Every senator in this chamber will remember the late 1970s when the phase out of CFCs in pressure pack cans was being strongly resisted by Afcam and the pressure pack can manufacturers. It was exactly like the cigarette manufacturers and the tobacco growers saying, `There is no evidence of a link between tobacco and lung cancer or various other diseases being caused by tobacco smoking.' They were defending their industry to the last saying the world would collapse, there would be a loss of jobs and everything else if they were made to control, limit or stop the use of CFCs.

We then move on to the Vienna convention when a number of nations came together and were very concerned not only about ozone depletion but also about the greenhouse effect. Certain things were said about the need for nations to cooperate to head off these global atmospheric environmental threats. That then goes on to the Montreal protocol, which gave more effect to this. Eventually that protocol was implemented in Australian legislation in 1988, which was then passed into law in 1989. Interestingly, and I put this before the Senate, because of my concern, I was the one who first introduced legislation in this chamber in 1988 to control the use of ozone depleting substances.

The lesson I want to draw from this is that for a number of years we have been getting very good and reliable evidence from a number of sources that the release of a range of other gases into the atmosphere—carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxide and the CFC's themselves—is causing another effect: namely, the greenhouse effect. We are now seeing from this government and from Australian industry precisely the same resistance that we saw with respect to the control of ozone depleting substances through the late 1970s and throughout most of the 1980s.

We see the coal industry digging its toes in trying very hard to resist the application of the very best scientific evidence which says we need to very quickly reduce our greenhouse gas emissions by 60 to 80 per cent. We see industry being supported by government. We saw our government go to the Berlin conference recently and resist very strongly, pleading a special case for Australia. In fact, one cannot deprecate the actions of our government, the actions of our coal industry in particular, more strongly.

We in Australia have seen the ecologically sustainable development committees, created by the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, coming out with exceptionally good recommendations as to how we could tackle this problem without in fact impacting adversely on Australian industry or the Australian economy. Quite the contrary in fact, it is causing Australian industry to move forward and be very productive which would move Australia into a good position to enter the 21st century. We see all those things being rejected.

Again, pressing the analogy with the ozone depleting substances, once government set in place the requirement that we needed to get rid of CFCs, we found that indeed technology could respond. We now find industry making a virtue of necessity—and it is reflected in the minister's second reading speech. It is saying, `Aren't we good? We are now responding. We are really getting rid of these substances.' Industry can respond. Industry wants a certain future, a situation in which the government outlines to industry what is required of it and guarantees those other conditions which need to be met. Industry will respond. Technology will respond. We will be able to address this problem.

I was responsible for getting the greenhouse effect as a reference before the committee that used to be called the industry, science and technology committee but which is now called the economics committee. Again, right within this chamber, that committee came forward with very good recommendations in relation to reducing greenhouse gases. It outlined a number of technologies that could be used and a number of industries that could be established, stimulated and so on.

What do we find? We find government turning its back and adopting precisely the same attitude that it did with ozone depleting substances through all the years between 1974-76, when it became clear that we had a serious problem with respect to ozone depletion, and 1988-89, when the legislation was passed.

We have seen the government recently adopting policies with respect to the electricity industry. It is totally turning its back on the opportunity to turn the electricity utilities in Australia into least cost energy service providers. We have seen the government rejecting the idea that even its own very weak target of a 20 per cent greenhouse gas reduction could be achieved simply by ensuring that a solar hot water service went into every house in Australia. That is very simple.

Imagine what would happen to that industry in Australia. We would produce cheaper solar hot water units. We would stimulate an industry with enormous capacity to provide employment. We would reduce our greenhouse gas emissions. Some 90 per cent of our solar hot water units now go overseas. The unit cost of those units would come down and we could produce even better units cheaper on the overseas market. Far from the directions that I am outlining actually damaging Australian industry, damaging the Australian economy, it is quite the contrary. The industry and the economy would benefit.

I simply want to say to the government that, with respect to ozone depleting substances, it cannot claim its record has been good. This extends back to the previous government. There was abundant and very good scientific evidence which indicated that it should have been taking action earlier. It did not do that. By analogy, it is now adopting the same head in the sand attitude with respect to greenhouse gas emissions and climate change.

In recent days we have seen the foreshadowed new report from the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change saying, `Yes, we have released a lot of greenhouse gas. We have changed the composition of the atmosphere but we are not too sure what is going to happen to the climate.' We now have the IPCC, which has some 200 world renowned scientists from a wide range of specialities saying, `Yes, we are now in a greenhouse situation and, yes, some of that global warming is due to the release of man-made gases.' It is again calling for governments to urgently respond to reduce the emission of these gases.

In a newspaper article yesterday—and I have copy of it here—the former head of the CSIRO's division of atmospheric physics, Brian Tucker, was quite out of line with his colleagues on the IPCC by saying that we should not take any action because we do not know what the climate effects are likely to be. This government has also adopted the precautionary principle. The precautionary principle is if you are not too sure what consequences will flow from an action, particularly an action which you are taking on a global front, then you should slow down the rate of change which will flow from that action until you are pretty sure that very adverse climate consequences will not flow from that action. The IPCC has said that it is predicting a 20 per cent reduction in harvests from crops in Sub-Saharan Africa and South and South-East Asia. That is certainly a consequence which will be disastrous on a global scale, and one which should stimulate this government to take prompt action.

The second point I want to make in my speech in the second reading debate is that I would hope not only that we would at this time be looking at improving the control of our ozone depleting substances, as we are in this legislation by moving forward to phase out these substances and by looking at a wide range of substances which have a much lower ozone depleting potential than the CFCs but nonetheless do have some ozone deleting potential and therefore should be controlled—all good stuff—but also that we would be looking as a nation at setting a pattern for the refrigeration and airconditioning industries well into the next century. We should be looking at new technologies which do not involve either the use of ozone depleting substances or the inevitable release, to some extent, of substances which have greenhouse potential.

Some of the substances being considered as refrigerant gases do have considerable greenhouse potential. I think it would be crazy for us to seek to control substances which have ozone depleting potential because of their ozone depleting potential and ignore the fact that the substitutes for those substances have greenhouse potential. Therefore, one might quite literally get out of the ultraviolet fire into the greenhouse frying pan.

It is about time we started looking at alternative technologies, some of which have been around for a long time. Ammonia based technology preceded, by many decades, the development of CFCs by a company in the United States in 1933. In the 1920s and the 1910s we had ammonia based refrigerators. Domestic refrigerators were operating with either gas or electricity and we certainly had, and still have today, very large commercial units that used ammonia. That is a technology which does not use a working gas, either a greenhouse gas or an ozone depleting gas. In Fremantle, Western Australia, there is a very interesting development—(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation is a reflection of the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer 1985 and more specifically the 1992 amendments of the Montreal protocol of that convention agreed to in Copenhagen. These amendments agreed to totally phase out CFCs, carbon tetrachloride, methyl chloroform, HBFCs and three types of halons by 1996. To this extent, Australia is to be commended for enacting these controls to the letter in this bill.

PARA.TAB: However, as became clear with the rejection of the proposed biosafety protocol, as part of the convention on biological diversity, by certain governments with strong commercial interests in maintaining trade in genetically engineered organism, such as Germany and the USA, often the outcome of international conventions is characterised by a lowest common denominator approach to global environmental problems. In the amendments to the Montreal protocol, the agreed method of dealing with the issue of HCFCs, themselves ozone depleting and global warming substances, was to prohibit CFC use as of 1996, replace them with HCFCs where possible and in turn initiate the phase-out of HCFCs by 2030. This was despite the fact that Switzerland and Sweden were pushing for their phase-out by 2005. Australia is to be one of the greatest affected by continuing ozone depletion. It is regrettable that we do not see these treaties as minimum standards and go above them rather than sticking to the letter of them.

It is common knowledge now that the damage caused to the ozone layer by human made chemical substances is more related to the number of chlorine ions let loose on the membrane thin layer of ozone protecting us from the sun's ultraviolet rays, rather than how long a given chemical substance stays in the atmosphere. Essentially, peak chlorine loading on the atmosphere is an instantaneous concept rather than a measure of ozone depleting potential averaged over 100 years. Therefore, though HCFCs are shorter lived than CFCs, compounds that inject chlorine into the atmosphere but have a relatively short lifetime will still contribute significantly to the overall ozone depletion in any given time frame.

It also becomes clear when we discuss environmental problems in the scheme of 100 years that many of the environmental models on which we base our predictions are very shaky indeed. Most of them rely on the principle of driving a car by the view in the rear vision mirror. We simply cannot predict the effect the massive amounts of CFCs, HCFCs, halons, methyl bromides, carbon monoxides, nitrous oxides, carbon tetrachlorides, HBFCs and HFCs civilisation has been pumping into the atmosphere will have on life on earth not in 100 years time but even in 20 years time. We must be basing our legislation on all possible outcomes rather than desperate adhesion to the predictions of computer banks made larger and larger to try to incorporate the effects of every possible variable. The earth is an infinitely, unimaginably complex system and we are dicing with its very make-up.

What we risk by arbitrarily replacing CFCs with HCFCs in this manner is another technological fix, a bandaid, that constructs a fools' paradise where we thrive in ignorance while the problem continues. With results like skin cancer, cataracts, early wrinkles, increased contraction of infectious diseases through suppression of the human and animal immune system, increased acid deposition in the atmosphere, lower yields of staple agricultural crops estimated at perhaps $2 billion a year in the United States alone and the less life threatening but unfortunate side effect of degradation of paints, plastic and other polymer materials to the same economic level, it will not remain a paradise for long.

Perhaps the most grave omission that resulted from the lowest common denominator approach to the ozone crisis by the Montreal protocol and by this act was the lack of agreement on controls on methyl bromide. Like halons and HBFCs, methyl bromides are bromide containing substances. Bromide atoms destroy hundreds of times more ozone molecules than does a chlorine atom. This omission risks placing in danger Australia's initiatives in dealing with ozone depletion, similar to turning a tap on full bore to fill up a bucket with a hole in it.

The ideal role then of the international community in global and environmental issues therefore is to create a general spirit and the highest possible standard of action for issues that can only be dealt with effectively in a global consensus environment. The role of domestic governments then is to enact appropriately stringent, and often higher, standards in national legislation. This amendment bill should seek to do this by strengthening the enactment of the protocol to more reflect its spirit, and the reason for the direction towards global cooperation in the first place, that is, to save the ozone layer. This enactment of its spirit would firstly be by phasing out methyl bromides immediately and, secondly, by shortening the phase-out time for HCFCs dramatically. My colleague Senator Margetts will outline options for achieving this.

The Greens approach to ozone and other environmental issues of this nature is to examine the fundamental causes of the problem and propose solutions that address the causes rather than treat the symptoms. Technological fixes that only address the symptoms will not solve the root lifestyle and philosophical issues that cause the depletion of the ozone layer and an impact on the environment in general. For example, if the government initiated a strong legislative framework for ensuring new buildings were designed so as to need minimal airconditioning—an area in which the government has published much of its own research—technological fixes that are more often than not ineffectual would not be necessary. In doing this the government could also be doubly effective by reducing greenhouse gas problems due to massive fossil fuel use in heating as well.

During the committee stage of the bill I will put several amendments. While a few are simply technical amendments designed for consistency or clarity, including the section inserted near the beginning of the act which is proposed as a consequence of the government's response to the Teoh decision, there are also a few substantive changes.

The first is to try to ensure that ozone depleting substances are not replaced with some chemical that creates environmental problems of a different sort, especially when the replacement chemical is covered specifically or in general under another international agreement, and where there are commercially available alternatives that don't create these problems.

The classic example is hydroflourocarbons, which may be ozone safe but are significant greenhouse gases with global warming potentials of several thousand. There are already proposals in Europe to phase out these gases and to have their phase-out included under European and international agreements.

The Ozone Protection Act was designed to protect the ozone layer, but hopefully we are not so stupid that we cure one problem by creating another we will then need to cure. Our amendment would at least ensure that some control over the replacements to ozone depleting substances we know are bad options.

This is important not only from an environmental standpoint, but also for industry. We certainly do not want to create a situation where we demand they convert from one substance only to see government a few years later demanding they convert again because the replacement creates other problems. We hope some regulation of obviously problematic replacements would reduce incidents of double conversion, with all their associated costs.

We also have substantive amendments in relation to the regulation of products using scheduled substances. While the quota on HCFCs is an example of phasing out a substance, the reason phase-out takes so long is to reduce the hardship on those who have bought equipment using the substance. It is sensible then to stop people from buying such equipment at the earliest possible date. Alternatives are already here in most cases. If not commercially developed already, they will be widely available soon. We think the time limits for equipment that we have set are reasonable, given the current state of development.

For example, while some Australian manufacturers of domestic refrigerators still use HFC refrigerants, I understand that none now use HFCs or HCFCs as foam blowing agents for insulation. All now use hydrocarbons. Email has also committed itself to hydrocarbon refrigerants. Virtually all European manufacturers use hydrocarbons, and General Electric and other US manufacturers have indicated that they will convert. In such a case, there is no reason to allow people to buy equipment which is damaging to the environment, when industry, and particularly Australian industry, provide a friendlier product.

The impact of these amendments will be minor, I believe, since in most cases industry has already converted or is converting away from ecologically damaging products. Where industry is wavering, it sends a clear message that it will need to find more appropriate solutions.

My colleague Senator Coulter was about to talk about an interesting example in Fremantle before the clock deprived him of that opportunity. I am not certain whether it is the same example as I am aware of, but I cite it as an example where industry and people within the community are much more ahead and constructive in their approach to these matters than often the willingness of state and federal governments to conform to those standards.

I will describe a meeting I had three years ago with a group of refrigeration engineers involved in refrigeration and airconditioning. They were very aware that within their own industry they needed to phase out ozone depleting substances. They were also aware that there was no regulation in the industry that protected our atmosphere from the subtle and damaging release of the ozone depleting chemicals by untrained people in the industry.

These engineers were seeking to provide two things: national standards; and within the states regulations on who was technically equipped to be involved in the refrigeration and airconditioning industries to deal with the replacement of ozone depleting substance parts. The progress made by that group within the industry has come on apace. They have had cooperation from the state government.

It is just one example of the failure of the political will of government to actually put standards. While people may test the limits of such standards and express a few concerns about how those standards will affect them economically, if those limits are in place, in the long run they will benefit industry, the community and certainly benefit our global environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Montreal protocol is the measure, signed in 1987, that laid the groundwork for containing the problem of ozone depletion. It was seen as the first singular success for international regulation for environmental protection. It has been said that the success was due in large part to the convergence of interest between the environmental movement and the large chemical manufacturers, who seemed best placed to provide alternatives to CFCs that they manufactured and were the subject of proposed bans. Chlorofluorocarbons are most commonly used as refrigerants and were developed in 1930 by Thomas Midgley, the man who also gave the world lead-in-petrol and DDT.

PARA.TAB: The Montreal protocol is an agreement in which the heavily industrialised world, which emits most of the chemicals that destroy the ozone layer, committed itself to phasing out these gases by the end of 1995. Less industrialised nations have longer, that is, until the year 2005. The parties contributed to a multilateral fund to assist conversion in developing nations to alternatives to ozone depleting substances. This fund has been mainly administered by the World Bank.

The World Bank has mainly given support for the development and conversion to HCFCs and HFCs. But HCFCs are ozone depleting substances, though not as bad as CFCs, and both HCFCs and HFCs are greenhouse gases with global warming potentials several thousand times those of carbon dioxide.

As well as the direct greenhouse impact of HFCs, there is an indirect impact. The HFCs have a poor coefficient of performance or COP, a measure of efficiency, and must use at least 10 per cent more energy to attain similar cooling—so we are losing on one and gaining on another. Since cooling and refrigeration is a major user of electricity, and electricity production accounts for about one third of all energy demand, changes in efficiency of this magnitude will have major impacts on efforts to combat global warming.

In addition, there are significant environmental risks involved in production of halogenated carbon compounds and especially fluorocarbons. A typical hydrofluorocarbon plant, for example, consumes 7.6 million litres of hydrofluoric acid per year—or 19,000 litres per day—in manufacture. Hydrofluoric acid is capable of acting even on glass, and a US test showed that a 1,000 US gallon or 3,800 litre spill would form a dense ground-hugging cloud that could prove lethal as far as five miles downwind. The potential for a Bhopal-style disaster is significant.

There are alternatives. Together with Greenpeace, European manufacturers have developed the green freeze technologies. These mainly use hydrocarbons, HCs, which can be made by petrochemical companies like Calor or Elgas. They are cheaper and safer to manufacture, and generally safer to use from an industrial safety perspective. They are not ozone depleting substances and have a global warming potential about the same as carbon dioxide—so we are not losing out on the energy aspect. They have a coefficient of performance or efficiency about the same as or better than commonly used CFCs. They do not require the use of toxic PAG oils in refrigeration systems and can be used for most foam blowing and refrigerant applications, as well as use in aerosol cans. This accounts for the majority of current CFC applications.

But the majority of emphasis by the World Bank has been for HFC and even HCFC technologies. This is absolutely inappropriate where funding is for projects in the less industrialised world. We are supporting transfers of technology that should already be superseded. We are talking about transfers to nations such as China, India and Brazil, with substantial populations that will soon be demanding large numbers of refrigeration equipment.

People often say, `Would you deny technology of Australia to other countries?' when we talk about things like global warming. We would say, `Why are we exporting our level of pollution when we could be doing better here?' If we have any real concern about the environment or social justice, then we should be encouraged to develop production capability based on hydrocarbon, not fluorocarbon, technology. The only real reason for such emphasis is that decisions were made to support the large chemical companies, such as ICI and Dupont, that previously made CFCs. So the whole deal was based on making them happy. The proponents of fluorocarbons consistently point to the flammability of hydrocarbons, often resorting to scare tactics and misinformation to make their point.

Hydrocarbons are flammable, although hydrocarbons used for refrigerants today are generally formulated to reduce flammability. HFCs, on the other hand, are only combustible. A major industrial accident in Germany on 18 March 1994, in which an HFC storage tank exploded, led the environment ministry to shut down the plant, and Hoechst, the producer, to shut down a sister plant in Brazil. Notes to those installing HFCs in refrigeration and airconditioning systems warn that the common practice of purging or testing lines with compressed air is dangerous and should never be attempted.

HFC companies rightly claim that, while HFCs can ignite under pressure or under conditions of exposure to high pressure air, this condition will never be met under normal use conditions. It is an industrial hazard, not a consumer hazard. I note that this week there is a union campaign on industrial safety and chemical hazards, which cause more deaths in Australia each year than automobile accidents. Hydrocarbons can ignite at atmospheric pressure. The question is whether hydrocarbons, under normal conditions of use and at normally found concentrations, represent any significant risk to the consumer.

The European nations have found that, in relation to refrigerators, HCs pose no significant risk. Foams can easily be blown with hydrocarbons and the systems charged with hydrocarbon refrigerants. Only if a complete leaking occurs into a sealed compartment and there is a naked flame from a candle or cigarette lighter in the compartment—that is, if you are standing inside the refrigerator—is the hydrocarbon gas likely to ignite. Such an occurrence is extremely unlikely. I do not know about you, but there is not a lot of room in my refrigerator.

There may be additional problems in some older fridges if CFCs are simply replaced with hydrocarbons. In some old fridges, thermostats or other electrical devices may potentially create enough of a spark to ignite a large hydrocarbon leak. Fridges designed for hydrocarbon use, on the other hand, present no significant risk. Many older fridges may be retrofitted to allow them to safely use hydrocarbons.

This imposes an extra cost, but HFCs are not a simple drop-in replacement either. They are a smaller molecule, so are more subject to leak than CFCs. They are very drying for oils; so can cause breakdown and cracking in seals. The recommended procedure is to replace all seals and replace the oil that hydrofluorocarbons are dissolved in. Hydrofluorocarbons, unlike hydrocarbons, require highly toxic PAG oils. The oil change is very expensive, and some manufacturers recommend changing the compressor to deal with the reduced efficiency of the hydrofluorocarbon refrigerants. These changes all cost quite a lot of money, and this cost must be weighed against the cost of retrofitting for hydrocarbon use.

The most contentious area of use today is for automotive airconditioning. A complete and sudden draining of hydrocarbon refrigerants into the passenger compartment could ignite, blow out windows and cause superficial burns. The question is whether this is likely to occur. Proponents of hydrofluorocarbons show dramatic pictures of windows being blown out. Proponents of hydrocarbons play hydrocarbons over all the switches, the exhaust manifold and even the distributor of a running car to show how difficult hydrocarbons are to ignite. Refrigeration engineers point out that a complete venting of all the airconditioning fluid—that is, 300 grams—into the passenger compartment is extremely unlikely, and that a slow leak would never build to flammable concentrations under normally designed ventilation conditions. Some research indicates that a sudden and total leak would dissipate to a non-flammable level in a normal car in under one minute. Meanwhile, little extensive safety testing has been done.

Cars use petroleum, which is far more flammable than hydrocarbons, and use it in far greater quantities. Petrol tanks are often separated from passenger compartments by only a sheet of cardboard. Likewise, LPG is explosive, and tanks are often located behind or beneath passenger compartments. The dangers can be seen in a film of the Ford Pinto which would explode in a ball of flame after a minor rear impact; yet no-one suggests restricting these substances.

It is seen as sufficient to design vehicles to use the substances safely; although this cannot eliminate all risks, especially during accidents. But safety measures are generally effective and cars in accidents rarely explode in balls of flames, except in the movies. If tens of litres of petrol and LPG can be used safely in cars, it seems inconsistent to suggest that a few hundred grams of refrigerant represents an insurmountable danger.

No-one suggests that hydrocarbons should be used in ways where they are shown to be unsafe. But it is hard to imagine that they cannot be used safely. Certainly, for most refrigeration and stationary airconditioning applications, hydrocarbons can be used safely now and are being used safely in Europe. Given the high cost of retrofitting required for automotive use of hydrofluorocarbons—that is, between $320 and $800—it is hard to imagine cars could not be made safe for hydrocarbon use, probably at less cost.

I have heard verbal reports from Elgas on tests in the US conducted in relation to the safety of hydrocarbons in automotive airconditioning that were concluded last month by Arthur B. Little, one of the foremost experts on automotive safety. These reports are very positive about the safety of these applications.

1995 is the last year for importation or manufacture of CFCs. Industries and businesses will need to convert now and will already be making choices about what route to go. The technologies of HFCs and HCs are different and, once committed, businesses will not want to change again in the near future. We are seeing choices made now that will affect our environment and our energy use, as well as costs to industry and consumers for many years to come. The choices will have major financial impacts on the chemical giants which are committed to making hydrofluorocarbons, on the companies that make hydrocarbons and on those companies who design and manufacture vehicles and appliances.

The Greens WA believe that HFCs can be a poor technological choice. They are greenhouse gases, demand increased energy use for the same result and present industrial, public and environmental safety issues from production. There are far better alternatives commercially available. It is not appropriate for the World Bank, the USEPA, or other agencies to support HFC technology in place of HCs. There may be areas where hydrocarbons cannot be used safely and other alternatives should then be found, but the onus is on the regulators to note problems and promote the development of the safe use for most applications. Clearly this is possible and clearly hydrocarbons are already safely in use in many applications.

Assistance to the developing world should involve the best technology—and this is not HCFCs or HFCs. Potential dangers of HCs in some applications should not be used as an excuse to limit their access to markets at a commercially critical time, as the state of Queensland is threatening. If there are potential dangers, there is no excuse to delay determining whether they are real dangers and whether there are modifications which will reduce dangers to an acceptable level.

We will always support consumer protection and a precautionary approach. But we cannot support the failure to develop safe technology as an excuse to continue environmentally destructive practice. Hydrocarbons appear to be safe for most applications or to be able to be made safe with a minimum of effort. We support European calls to phase out HCFCs and HFCs. We already know that virtually all foam blowing can and should be done without HCFCs or HFCs. Domestic refrigerators are already being produced without them, including use as refrigerants. I understand that National Railways is trialling HCs in its airconditioning system.

There are already many applications where HCFCs or HFCs are not necessary, or not in use. There are others where there are clear alternatives—often cheaper and environmentally far better alternatives. In these cases, the Greens believe HCFCs and HFCs should not be used. It is extremely expensive for industry to convert, especially where it means changing compressors or, in the case of manufacturers, changing technologies, designs and equipment to accommodate a different type of gas.

What we would like to avoid is a situation where double conversion is likely to be imposed. It is imperative to let industry know what options for CFC replacements will not be acceptable over the long term. This is the case for most applications of HFCS. In most applications, HCFCs are already not acceptable and, as the government has indicated through its phase out policy, will be available only as short-term transition substances. In such cases, I think we should ensure that where there are commercially available alternatives, especially where new cost or conversion cost is the same or less than for HFCs, industry does not take up HFCs. I don't think we should specify the alternatives; these are rapidly developing, but we should not let industry generate large sunk costs in technologies that are already superseded on environmental grounds, and often on economic and efficiency grounds.

The amendments Senator Chamarette will put before you are mainly designed to ensure that, in addressing one environmental woe, we do not make another problem worse. This is certainly consistent with the Vienna convention included as schedule 2 of the existing act. To a lesser extent, our amendments are designed to ensure that, in this period of conversion away from CFCs, industry should adopt the most sustainable technology available.
