TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1995 is a bill that the coalition will support. This bill does make amendments relating to the funding for the Aboriginal education strategic initiatives program. That funding is provided through the program to organisations and institutions to supplement the cost of delivering educational services to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. The main amendment proposes to increase the appropriation for the funding period 1 January 1996 to 30 June 1997 from $250,000 to $83.63 million.

PARA.TAB: The proposals contained in the training or funding program are uncontroversial, but there is one aspect of Aboriginal education that I do want to draw some attention to. On 26 September last, Minister Crean announced a $200 million funding package for Aboriginal education over the next four years. That was a follow-up from a meeting of the Ministerial Council on Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs at which state and territory ministers had agreed to endeavour to increase their financial effort over the period of the 1997-99 triennium. The Commonwealth agreed to provide additional strategic funding support in return for the states increasing their funding.

Despite the fact that Victoria strongly supported that proposal, the minister sought to criticise the Victorian government in articles in the Australian and Age newspapers. Victoria does have a very impressive track record in terms of funding for Aboriginal education and, indeed, was more than happy to continue to provide an increase. It is a matter of some concern—or it should be—to all senators that Minister Crean's office or the Department of Employment, Education and Training sought to approach various other state offices indicating that Victoria was the only state that had not responded to the Commonwealth's request for additional funding. That was demonstrably untrue and, as it transpired, other states had received similar calls making the same allegation.

Therefore, I think it is worth while looking at what the Commonwealth has actually been trying to do. It is a classic example of playing politics to the hilt. There is an awareness on the part of this government in its last days that Queensland and New South Wales are very weak electorally for it and, as a result, the Commonwealth was proposing to change the rules for base Commonwealth funding in a way that would advantage Queensland and New South Wales and disadvantage the other states and territories. Indeed, it was also proposing to provide the states from 1997 with only 80 per cent of the 1995 funding levels.

As a result of even the government realising that this was just too much to bear, that original proposal, as I understand it, has now been modified. But it just shows the treachery of the federal government in encouraging the states in good faith to agree to endeavour to increase their financial effort over the period on one set of rules, but then suddenly turning around and making a completely different set of proposals to the various states, which would disadvantage most of them. Of course, they then have the hide to publicly criticise those states for not going along with the Commonwealth government's blatantly political objectives. I am sure that the electorate will be aware of this government's appalling track record in terms of distorting the facts wherever possible, using all sorts of forums to criticise any Liberal government around the country and once again misusing funding for electoral purposes.

Aboriginal education is a critically important area. It ought to be an area in which there is a substantial degree of bipartisanship. It ought to be possible to honour agreements reached in good faith at ministerial council meetings, but that is virtually impossible when you have the Commonwealth government simply trying to rat on those deals and play politics to the hilt and, almost in the sports rorts manner, spread the money around to those areas where it feels it is electorally weakest. Given the shameful performance of this government in so many areas of Aboriginal improvement, it is a great shame that it has not been prepared to play this down the line to ensure that the states were prepared to, and are able to, work cooperatively with the Commonwealth. So I will leave the matter there, and I just hope that in due course the Commonwealth gets the rebuff that it deserves.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1995 will continue to allow grants of financial assistance to the states and territories of Australia and other educational bodies to continue to further the cause of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander education in this country. As we have been told, it allows for $83,636,000 to be the level of funding for the 1996 calendar year.

PARA.TAB: It is a decrease on last year's amount by $0.27 million, but I understand this is supposed to be an adjustment of the half-yearly effect of the transfer of funds from 1 July 1995. It allows for $0.54 million to go to the Department of Communications and the Arts for the 1995-96 year, which is a commitment from the Creative Nation statement. The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) said this at the time:

SPEECH.PARA: Indigenous Art forms must be protected and allowed to flourish. They need specific support from the Government which cannot be provided through the national training institutions.

Despite this strong statement and despite this significant amount of money, I take this opportunity to point out that indigenous art forms don't just happen in the sort of institution that the government is funding with this latest amount. Indigenous art centres in some places in Australia are in chaos, and I have received representations from some organisations that are on the point of collapse. I know that the government, the opposition and the Greens in this chamber would all acknowledge the important role that such organisations play in remote and urban centres, but this year some of those groups have had their funding category changed because they are now considered to be income generating exercises.

PARA.TAB: The trouble is that in this new scheme, the community economic initiatives scheme, they had their processes changed this year and they would not approve money without further assessment in some cases. This means that no money went to the centre while the red tape was being sorted out, which meant conditions for workers were stressful and, in one case that we know of, they were unpaid. While we support the National Institute for Indigenous Performing Arts Training, we would ask the Prime Minister to take a look at the other forms of support to indigenous art, as he mentioned in his statement, and ensure that those things are running smoothly.

Notwithstanding that, the Australian Democrats agree with this bill. We believe that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have a unique place in our society which must be recognised. Indigenous peoples face many challenges in our society, not the least of which is dealing with the education system. As far as they are concerned, the retention rates are a scandal, and the latest figures show that participation levels are improving but there is still a wide gap between indigenous and non-indigenous Australians. I would like to include a short extract from Social justice for indigenous Australians 1994-95 to illustrate this point. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Between 1985 and 1992, the retention rate to year 12 of Indigenous students rose from 14 per cent to 25%. Rates for other students in the same period, however, rose from 58% to 78%. In the 1991 Census 1 in 2 Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander 15-19 year olds stated they had left school at 16 or younger compared with 1 in 4 non indigenous people in this age group . . . The 1991 Census showed that among 20-24 year olds the proportion of indigenous people attending educational institutions was about one third of the non-indigenous rate.

In agreeing with this bill, the Australian Democrats are warning the government to use this significant amount of money to get it right for the future—to ensure that the retention rates go up to levels which the indigenous community finds acceptable and which give their community the reassurance that the Australian education system is as beneficial and accessible to them as it is to the rest of Australians.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to ask the government to take note that the Young Australian Democrats Convention just recently had two resolutions with respect to indigenous education issues. Firstly, they called on the government and the people of Australia to recognise concepts of land and place as integral to indigenous identity and spirituality and to respond appropriately to ensure the future of indigenous people. Secondly, they called for informed and constructive inclusion in any civics education program—such as the $24 million one the federal government is presently funding—of a program of Aboriginal and Islander history. These are both worthwhile objectives, and I would commend them to the government for inclusion in its policy formulation and implementation.

I have one suggested amendment to this bill. It is an important amendment, and it occurs actually on the very first page; that is, to change the title of the act from Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1995 to the Indigenous Education Supplementary Assistance Bill 1995. This follows a changing trend whereby there is a recognition of the difference of Torres Strait Islander people and an overt need for this recognition.

The government previously recognised this when they accepted the name change for the Indigenous Corporation (Land Fund) Act. Also, what is presently known as the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act will probably get a name change after the review to the Indigenous Councils and Associations Act. People such as the Prime Minister and Mr Mick Dodson use the term `indigenous' when discussing policy issues, so we believe this amendment has consistency with current perspectives. I would urge the other parties in the Senate to support this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Clause 1, page 1, short title, line 3, omit "Aboriginal, substitute "Indigenous".
2.Schedule, page 2, before item 1, insert the following items:

SPEECH.PARA: I referred to these amendments in my brief speech in the second reading debate. They need little explanation. I gave a description of the effect of them. I also gave justification for doing so. They are consistent with the sort of terminology now adopted by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and are consistent with other legislation. They substitute the word `indigenous'. I think they need no further explanation. They are self-explanatory. Those who maintain some sort of consistency in this should appreciate the need for them.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will accept the amendments.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: 1.Schedule, page 2, before item 1, insert the following item:

SPEECH.PARA: "1E. After section 4:

TAB.TAB: Insert:

TAB.EMPHASIS: Convention gives rise to legitimate expectations

PARA.TAB: "4A.(1) Unless and until this section is expressly repealed, the fact that Australia is a party to the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Racial Discrimination gives rise to a legitimate expectation, on the part of any person, that, to any extent that this Act does anything less than implement the requirements of the Convention:

TAB.TAB: (a)an administrative decision will be made in conformity with the requirements of the Convention; or

(b)if the decision were to be made contrary to any of those requirements, any person affected by the decision would be given notice and an adequate opportunity to present a case against the taking of such a course.

SPEECH.PARA: "(2) In this section:
`administrative decision' means:

TAB.TAB: (a)a decision by or on behalf of the Commonwealth under this Act; or
(b)a decision by or on behalf of an authority of, or office holder of, the Commonwealth under this Act;

SPEECH.PARA: that is a decision of an administrative character and includes such a decision reviewing, or determining an appeal in respect of, a decision made before the commencement of this Act.'.''.

It would not be necessary to be moving this amendment if I had been able to put and have agreed the suspension of standing orders and the subsequent debate yesterday on a motion that the Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill 1995 be discharged from the Notice Paper. Because that bill still remains on the Notice Paper, is likely to come before this Senate chamber and is likely to pass because of the indication by the coalition and the government that they are prepared to work together to support its passage, we will be removing from this bill that is now under consideration in the committee stage any implications that a reasonable person might have that this bill will be in accordance with the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination.

PARA.TAB: Let me make it clear why we will be moving similar amendments to all relevant legislation. The government, in passing this bill, and the opposition, in supporting it, are perpetrating a sham on the parliament, the Australian people and the international community. The government is treading the world stage and pretending to be a good world citizen by signing and ratifying international treaties. But back at home there is no obligation to do anything about the commitments that those international treaties entail.

For those of you who are unfamiliar with what has occurred, the Teoh High Court decision was a landmark decision that allowed the international treaties which have been ratified and to which Australia is a signatory to have the normal expectation of anybody; that is, there would be a reasonable expectation when administrative decisions are made that the people making those decisions will take into consideration any obligations that were there under our international treaty obligations. They do not have to agree with them; they simply have to take them into consideration. If they do not take those matters into consideration, it provides a procedural right, not a substantive right, to an Australian citizen to challenge that administrative decision because it has failed to conform with Australia's known and recognised international treaty obligations.

There are implications for every piece of legislation that has been passed in this place and every piece of government decision making that may occur afterwards. I believe that some members of both the major parties are unaware of what we have done, which is create unintended consequences. Substantially, we have given governments a licence to sign and ratify treaties on behalf of Australia with no intention in the world of creating any obligation back home. Until those treaties are enforced in domestic law, they are to have no obligations. If they are to have no obligations on administrators, why are we signing and ratifying them?

It is a disgrace and it will show us up in the world community to be frauds. We are pretending to have high standards. We are using the international treaty system in a manipulative way to try to improve other nations' standards. We are opting out from any obligation within our country to abide by that until such time as the lowest common denominator can be introduced in the parliament.

The particular treaty that is related to the Aboriginal Education (Supplementary Assistance) Amendment Bill 1995, which we are considering today, is the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. Australia is a party to that convention. This gives rise to a legitimate expectation on the part of anyone in Australia that, to the extent that this act does anything less than implement the requirements of that convention, it will be able to be procedurally addressed.

The amendment I have moved simply puts in place the position that upholds the High Court decision in Teoh. It is a slightly more conservative version of that decision, but one that upholds a legitimate expectation that our governments will be responsible and accountable for the international treaties and covenants to which they have become a party. It requires that they allow that convention to be honoured in the administrative decision making that occurs. If that does not occur explicitly, at least there will be protection so that a citizen who feels something has been done contrary to any of the requirements of the convention can at least be given an adequate opportunity to present a case against taking such a course.

Again, they do not necessarily win on the basis of this amendment or the announced Teoh case position. They simply have a procedural right. We are removing that procedural right. We are giving unbridled power to bureaucrats and administrators to not be accountable to governments that have signed and ratified international conventions.

A very disturbing aspect of the last month is that, through the committee stage, where the government's legislative response to the Teoh case has been given committee consideration, this matter has received no publicity whatsoever. There are people in the community who would not know that we are promoting a most retrograde and draconian step for Australian government and parliament. So that is why, on each occasion when the rights of people within Australia are being undermined by the potential of that anti-Teoh legislation, the Greens will be proposing amendments that simply maintain the status quo; that is, a legitimate procedural right of an individual to challenge a decision where it is not in conformity with the international conventions with which it should be in conformity.

The High Court is affirming a long-held principle that a person has a legitimate expectation that their government will comply with the provisions of, in this case, the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. The High Court has reaffirmed that procedural right. The person who is affected by a decision which does not comply with the treaty will be notified and have the opportunity to respond. If the effect of the Administrative Decisions (Effect of International Instruments) Bill 1995, if it passes in the Senate, will be to negate our international treaty obligations as they relate to CERD—that is, the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination—and where these provisions in the amendment that I am putting are not enacted, we will have a very undesirable situation altogether.

That is what this amendment means. It is a simple amendment which puts in place a protection to ensure that Aboriginal people enjoy equality with other Australians in their access to education, in section 5; to ensure equity of participation by Aboriginals in education, in section 6; and to ensure equitable and appropriate educational outcomes for Aboriginal people, in section 7. We must consider the Convention for the Elimination of Racial Discrimination in relation to decisions made under this bill. Support for this bill is one way of doing that, thus preventing the erosion of our rights which are so vital.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will oppose the amendment, for two reasons. Firstly, as Senator Chamarette said earlier, she has a right to move amendments in the chamber, but the government believes that, if a senator wants support on an issue, the amendments should be given some circulation so that we have notice.

PARA.TAB: The second reason is of more substance. Senator Chamarette has given notice that she intends to move this amendment to a variety of legislation. As I understand it, many of the central objectives Senator Chamarette seeks to accomplish are outlined in section 4, `objectives', of the act. Senator Chamarette goes further in that the effect of her amendment would be to cut across what may be or what are agreements between, for example, state and federal governments that are political in nature, and to provide possible grounds for courts to become involved in those agreements. We see that as undesirable and, for that reason, as a matter of principle—as well as the practical matter of lack of notice—the government will oppose the amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like clarification from the parliamentary secretary. He is saying that this amendment cuts across agreements between state and federal governments. That seems to me to mean that the federal government is putting itself below state governments in relation to its constitutional capacity and right to be involved in international treaties. To me, that is outrageous. If the government is about to desert its federal and Commonwealth responsibilities and place them at a lower level than the states, we ought to be reconsidering the impact of federation.

PARA.TAB: I would like the parliamentary secretary to clarify exactly what agreements are cut across by this amendment which would allow the federal government not to exercise its legitimate capacity to sign and ratify international covenants, and which would prevent the administrators within the country of Australia from honouring the kinds of obligations that have been made.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chamarette, I just do not agree with your interpretation.
—Would you explain what yours is?
—I do not intend to speak at length in this debate. I have kept my remarks to the points that are relevant. The government does not propose to accept Senator Chamarette's amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment moved by Senator Chamarette has a lot of unforeseen consequences and, whilst nobody doubts the earnestness with which Senator Chamarette is pursuing this matter, I think it is important that the Senate examines the consequences of it and, more importantly, that the Senate examines the implications for constitutional law if Senator Chamarette's amendment is accepted. Senator Chamarette begins her argument on the premise that the executive is signing treaties and that, without this amendment, the Commonwealth of Australia is an international fraud because the executive signs treaties which do not have the force or effect of law or do not give rise to procedural rights within Australia itself.

PARA.TAB: That in itself may well be a compelling argument in metaphysics, but the problem is that it is not a compelling argument in constitutional law. Let me explain why. It follows from what Senator Chamarette says that her amendment would give effect not merely to treaties which have been signed and ratified as at this date and at this point in time, but would also give affect to treaties which are signed after this point in time. This is very important because, theoretically, one could have cognisance of all of the treaties to which the Commonwealth of Australia is a signatory—I think it would be very difficult to have cognisance of all those treaties because I understand there are about 2,000.

Theoretically, it is possible for this Senate chamber to have cognisance of all those treaties at this point in time. But if this amendment is accepted, we must also accept that treaties signed after this date will give rise to procedural rights in favour of individuals merely by virtue of their having been signed and ratified by the Governor-General. If this was a bill that created a right for a minister to change the rights of individuals merely by regulation—in other words, a Henry VIII clause—I am sure that Senator Chamarette would be horrified by such a suggestion. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee would be horrified by the suggestion that here we were going to create a Henry VIII clause, giving ministers wide-ranging powers to alter or affect the rights of individuals merely by regulation. Of course, a regulation is a disallowable instrument and has to come before the Senate and the House of Representatives and can be disallowed.

Senator Chamarette through her amendment is creating a right in favour of the executive to alter or affect the rights of individuals by signing a treaty, yet that treaty is not even so much as a disallowable instrument, because neither house of parliament has the right to disallow the treaty. In other words, this amendment gives cart blanche to the executive to do whatever they want. We should always be wary of giving the executive cart blanche.

Senator Chamarette in moving this amendment is no doubt motivated by a belief that it improves the rights of individuals. But in many cases treaties, because they create restrictions and obligations, can impair the rights of individuals. It would be wholly inappropriate for this parliament to support this amendment and create the possibility that a minister could sign a treaty, the Executive Council could recommend to the Governor-General that that treaty be ratified, and the rights of individuals could be impaired.

This is a precedent that Senator Chamarette wishes to create. Senator Chamarette has told the chamber, in fact, that this is one of a number of amendments that she wishes to move to other items of government legislation as well to give effect to this broad principle. I say that this broad principle is wrong. It is wrong because of the unintended consequences it will have. But more important to honourable senators, this amendment is wrong in principle because it over-reaches the powers set out for the Commonwealth in section 51 of the constitution.

The basis on which the executive accedes to treaties has always been that it comes within the scope of the executive to deal with matters of external affairs. Senator Chamarette's amendment will import, at least into administrative law, the principles of international treaties without bringing legislation to the parliament. I must remind Senator Chamarette that the preamble to section 51 of the constitution reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The Parliament shall, subject to this Constitution, have power to make laws for the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth with respect to—

and it then itemises points (i) to (xxxix), and item (xxix) is external affairs. In other words, the parliament has the power to make laws with respect to the peace, order and good government of the Commonwealth in relation to external affairs.

PARA.TAB: But there is no power of the parliament to abrogate its rights to the executive to make laws which bind individuals and which are not subject to legislation, and this is what it would do. For that reason, Senator Chamarette's amendment would have thoroughly unintended and thoroughly unsatisfactory constitutional consequences in this nation. We would not know what we are importing into our domestic law if we voted for Senator Chamarette's amendment and we could never know what we imported into domestic law because it would be subject to whatever treaties a minister or the executive decided to sign and ratify, and that should be a cause for concern.

Finally, in so far as base politics is concerned, can I say to the minor parties in this place that every time they accede to an increase in the power of the executive, to the ability of the executive to rule citizens without bringing legislation before this parliament, they weaken their own power and they weaken their own bargaining position. That, I think, from the point of view of Realpolitik, is a foolish thing to do.

I indicate that I have the gravest concerns and the greatest difficulty in supporting Senator Chamarette's amendment which she has brought before this place. I also accept the fact that Senator Sherry has made some very good points—I hate to say it, Senator Sherry—in relation to how these treaties could cut across the relationships between state and federal governments, because the federal government could impair the rights of states to legislate and could impair the operation of agreements which have been made between the state and federal governments to give effect to funding and other arrangements.

It is fine if we have a unitary system of government with no states to say that maybe we will have self-executing treaties, but I think the wiser heads in government, such as Senator Jones, recognise that whilst we have states they have legitimate powers, they have to be respected and, obviously, international treaties which override not just the states but their relationships with the federal government are unsatisfactory. That is another reason why I find grave difficulty accepting the proposition that Senator Chamarette has put.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee has ranged far and wide, and has sounded extremely erudite about the constitution, conjuring up a spectre of shaping an executive government into a dictatorship in a democracy. Fortunately, I can assure senators that Senator O'Chee is wrong.

PARA.TAB: This amendment, in a very disciplined way, repeats the judgment of the High Court in Teoh's case. The High Court in Teoh's case did not address itself to the substance of the treaty that was the subject of the Teoh case—that was, the Convention on the Rights of the Child—but simply to the process that the decision maker had to follow in dealing with an application which related in its subject matter to what was being dealt with by the Convention on the Rights of the Child.
Indeed, this amendment under subsection (a) very clearly says `an administrative decision'. Therefore, the decision maker is confined to considering the process in making a decision in the case.

The amendment goes a step further and the amendment preserves the power of parliament by saying, `Unless and until any legislation is passed by parliament which contradicts the terms of this amendment.' So it is quite clear that the power of the executive is not enlarged to anything like the frightening spectre that Senator O'Chee has tried to conjure up. In fact, it is not enlarged at all, because we have had that practice for decades. There are many treaties and conventions entered into by executive government which never come before a parliament, but which are followed through executive action and direction.

We are dealing here with a very limited approach which simply says that, if the executive government on behalf of Australia enters into a treaty and says to the whole world, `This is what we oblige ourselves to do on behalf of Australians', then to a very limited extent administrative decision makers need to at least consider what this treaty says when they are dealing with an application before them—and that is all. I think it is something we should follow and implement unless we want to have Australia stand before the world saying, `We will make treaties, but we will then disregard them.' This is hardly the two-faced approach and two-faced image that we would like Australia to have fixed with.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too would like to respond to Senator O'Chee's comments. I can assure him that he has either not read the amendment or he is totally out of his depth, legally and constitutionally. In case he accuses me of being so, I will not even have pretensions to it. I am guided by Elizabeth Evatt, Justice Kirby and all the people who made submissions to the Legal and Constitutional Committee and with whom the committee members disagreed, in the face of all the community response and evidence that could be presented to them. I am not proclaiming my legal superiority over Senator O'Chee's; I am just relying on those of the experts who gave testimony to the Legal and Constitutional Committee and I am quite confident that the amendment I have put up does not have any of the unforeseen consequences that Senator O'Chee, in his dire and gloomy way, has predicted.

PARA.TAB: For a start—and I thank Senator Spindler for that—it is a very specific amendment that relates only to one convention: the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination. It does not create some kind of magical right on every treaty—not just every treaty that has already been signed and ratified by the government but every treaty that might ever be. It does not all. It simply relates it to one convention.

Further to that, it says, `Unless and until this section is expressly repealed;' that is, it provides to this parliament and this place the capacity to check whether that specific international treaty should give rise to any legitimate expectations. So it is a very conservative and constricted response to what the Teoh High Court decision established as an already existing principle, that is, that if we have governments signing and ratifying international treaties, it is a legitimate and reasonable expectation on the part of any citizen of Australia, when they hear about that, that administrative decisions will be in conformity with the convention that has been ratified by the executive.

As for the argument that this gives the executive government undue and open carte blanche in terms of treaties and creates a right for governments, I urge my opposition colleagues to be a little more sophisticated in their analysis of what the anti-Teoh legislation does, which is to do precisely that—to give executive government carte blanche, because the real motive of the anti-Teoh legislation is to codify what has been until now obviously unwritten government policy, that is, to cloak themselves in the mantle of international saintliness on human rights and on environmental issues by signing these treaties in the secure knowledge that nothing need be done about them back home. With a law that says there are no ramifications in Australia, the government may well see this as licence to sign. The coalition, who were concerned about the erosion of Australia's sovereignty under international treaties, should be extremely fearful of granting the government such a licence by supporting the anti-Teoh legislation.

I am the first one to say—and I would agree with Senator O'Chee on this one point—that this is not a complete and obvious response to the problem that has been raised by the support of the Labor and Liberal coalition of the administrative bill that is going to be passed. We would much prefer a comprehensive approach to the implementation of our international obligations. It is long overdue. To try to alter that by the anti-Teoh legislation is a piecemeal, knee-jerk reaction to a very modest decision by the High Court, and what we are doing here with our small and simple amendment is simply protecting this one piece of legislation from the erosion that the bill will provide to it once that bill is passed.

This simply states the status quo. It makes explicit what the current state of the law is in this country until such time as this Senate to its shame passes the anti-Teoh legislation, which will then undermine every other piece of legislation that has any relationship to an international treaty to which we are a party, except this one, because this has in it a slight provision to protect the people who are going to be using this act with the guarantee that it will not be able to be used in a discriminatory way against them. So I urge my colleagues, if they can't do it at the moment, and as Senator Sherry said, he would love to—

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I note that today the Commonwealth government has tabled some 24 treaties and in document 25 has a list which sets out a number of treaties. This document No. 1 deals with a bilateral treaty relating to air services with Bahrain—on the surface of it, a very technical treaty and one which would not attract much comment. However, when you look at this matter more thoroughly, you see that there are a number of treaties further on in the list, and also in that list at document 25, which deal with such matters as racial and sexual discrimination, climate change, nuclear energy, control of hazardous waste, industrial relations and the setting up of a United Nations criminal court, just to name a few.

PARA.TAB: Not only do we have these 24 treaties listed on this paper, but at document 25 we have a list which sets out some 39 international instruments which are currently the subject of negotiation or review, a further 26 international treaties which have been finalised but which are also under review, and as well as that some 30 ILO conventions. All of this was tabled today in the Senate with some 16 other annual reports, and all I have timewise to speak today is some five minutes. That demonstrates just how deficient this system is of tabling treaties and affording some parliamentary scrutiny.

I notice that in October 1994, the government says, it introduced further initiatives with a view to improving the flow of information about treaties to parliament and that the government had made a commitment to the early tabling of treaties in advance of Australia becoming a party to them. If this is what it calls `further initiatives', I think it is thoroughly inappropriate, it is a disgraceful state of affairs, and does not afford us, as representatives of the Australian people, any opportunity to go through these treaties and have any chance to be apprised of their content.

I notice that Senator Gareth Evans said that officials from the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade would be available to brief senators on this, but we have hardly had much notice when today we receive these treaties tabled in such a fashion—some 24 plus 70 others. I believe there are in excess of 90 international instruments which have been tabled today, plus 16 other annual reports.

The government might say, `Senator Ellison, you can adjourn your comments and come back tomorrow during general business and debate the issue then.' But then we only get another hour, and if I was to talk about this in the adjournment debate or if I was to talk about this during an MPI, I would have great difficulty because, quite understandably, other senators would be raising matters of public interest. So what would happen is that any useful discussion of these treaties or these international instruments would be lost in the wash and there would not be ample opportunity for any useful debate to take place.

This is the problem that the wider Australian community is finding with this government. This government has signed up to some 920 treaties, it says, and there has been scant regard had to any parliamentary scrutiny.

I am saying to the Australian people that we have tabled here today treaties dealing with such important measures as I have outlined, but we do not have the ability to debate them. We do not have the ability to go through them. In the forthcoming four or five sitting weeks that remain, even if you debated one of these a day you would still have insufficient time to give them due regard. It is a thoroughly unsatisfactory state of affairs and one on which the government stands condemned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I point out in taking note of these treaties that there really is not any point taking note of them at all. Far from the point that Senator Ellison has just made—that we have not got the opportunity to debate them at any length because of the anti-Teoh legislation that the coalition is planning to support—we do not even have to worry about them because they will have no implications whatsoever. That is the exact point that people need to take into consideration.

PARA.TAB: Having these treaties without any obligation being given that we will have to make administrative decisions in accord with them or allow procedural rights when that does not occur means that they are utterly meaningless; they are parading in the international arena on false pretences. Anyway, I have already given my opinion to the Senate and I will not continue to belabour the point. It is the same point, however, and I urge my colleagues to take it to heart.

Senator Margetts and I would like to take note of a number of these treaties and continue our remarks later. We wondered if we could nominate the ones that we would like to see retained there to save the Senate's time.

—To assist honourable senators in this matter I suggest that the most appropriate procedure would be to leave your proposition to seek leave to consider all of these treaties together to the end of the debate on treaty No. 1 and then seek leave in relation to combining the rest.

—Senator Chamarette's comments show remarkably well our real dilemma. The senator wants to debate a number of treaties. She is quite entitled to debate a number of treaties, treaties which she feels are important to her and to her constituents. I would strongly support that position. But the reality is, as my colleague Senator Ellison has demonstrated to the chamber, you are not going to have that chance or opportunity because the standing orders limit this debate to half an hour. Each of us has five minutes. A number on this side of the parliament wish to jump. Senator Bell is in the chamber. He may wish to have a few remarks on some issues. So in regard to your right, Senator, to debate these important treaties, whereas one may say in theory that we can continue to put this on the Notice Paper, the reality is that the opportunity will not be available.

PARA.TAB: This debate on the role of parliament and treaties has gone on for a number of years. I have detected on all sides of the chamber a consensus that something has to be done. The people who stand out from this process are essentially Senator Evans and his colleagues, who believe that the current processes are appropriate for this parliament. My view is that Senator Evans has comprehensively lost that debate. If the department believes that the current arrangements, where there is such a limited time for the parliament to play a role in this debate, should remain in force in the coming years I believe that is wrong. As I have talked around it, the Democrats wish to ensure through a private member's bill that parliament has a chance to veto the treaty. The Greens may not have moved that far but believe that there should be a greater role for parliament in the scrutiny of treaties. We have put down a number of important policies which we believe would increase the role of parliament to scrutinise treaties and to more effectively involve our people and the people of Australia in the treaty making process.

All governments will sign treaties across a whole range of areas, but there is a consensus emerging that we should more effectively involve the parliament. Some people would involve the parliament to the extent that required legislative approval or veto of a treaty which did not have the support of the parliament. Most have not moved that far but everyone, with some exceptions in the Labor Party, believes that there should be a more effective way to scrutinise contentious treaties so that the parliament and, through the parliament, the people of Australia can be more effectively involved.

The department, in discussions with them over quite a long period, have not grasped the nettle on this important issue. They seem to think that Australia, unlike most other countries, should not have an effective role for the parliament in the treaty making process. A number of studies have been done which show that most countries, most democracies, more effectively involve their parliaments in some way in the treaty making processes.

In the debate today the issue of treaties came up and the importance of an international treaty. In a society where the rule of law is writ large like our own there is no question that an international treaty is an important instrument and can have important domestic effects. It is extraordinary that this government continues to resist any real attempt to involve the parliament and, through the parliament, the Australian people more effectively in the treaty making process.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: The 1994-95 report of the Australian Federal Police is grossly inadequate. The way in which this report has whitewashed the sections of the Australian Federal Police which have been thoroughly discredited for their own whitewashing of criminal investigations is a disgrace. In particular, I refer to those within the AFP who are responsible for program one which, according to page 11 of the report, is the investigations department; operations, policy and support division, northern region, eastern region, southern region, central region and western region.

PARA.TAB: I looked in vain through chapter two of this document, which relates to program one, for any reference to Operation Gallon, the Federal Police's grossly inadequate response to the evidence presented by the Queensland Criminal Justice Commission and the Queensland police in their Operation Wallah report. I looked under the section `Fraud', which would have been relevant to this investigation. There was no mention of this matter. I looked under the section `Organised Crime'. There was no mention of it there. I looked under the section `Special References'. There was no mention there. I looked under the section `International Liaison'. Again, there was no reference to it. As I say, I looked in vain right through this document. There was no reference to this investigation.
I did find several comments that I thought were worthy of quoting.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are they?
—I will tell you. Firstly, at page 3 we find the statement:

SPEECH.PARA: Accordingly, the AFP continues to build on cooperative relationships with other Commonwealth bodies which have law enforcement responsibilities, in particular the Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board . . . the NCA, and with State police agencies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you saying it shouldn't be doing that?
—It should be doing that. The point is that it is not. On page 4 it states:

PARA.TAB: The AFP is examining how it . . . can create better working relationships with our State and Territory colleagues and other key partners and clients . . .

SPEECH.PARA: It certainly needs to give that some very close consideration because it is not doing that either. At page 19, under `Organised Crime', which did not mention anything about Operation Wallah, I find:

PARA.TAB: A strengthened alliance, including operational integration with the NCA and improved cooperative arrangements with other agencies, resulted in an increased targeting of identified organised criminal networks.

SPEECH.PARA: They failed to identify anything as far as investigating Operation Wallah is concerned.

PARA.TAB: Those three claims in this report are absolutely laughable in light of the comments by the heads of the CJC, Messrs O'Regan and Wyvill, earlier this year and are even more laughable in light of the evidence presented to the Hanson inquiry in Queensland with regard to the shortcomings of the AFP in these investigations. The AFP has clearly failed in its responsibilities to properly investigate the evidence carefully gleaned by the CJC investigations.

It is no wonder that sometime earlier this year Minister Kerr attempted to whitewash those subject to these investigations under Operation Wallah. His statements when releasing a summary of the AFP Gallon report, which was the AFP's response to the Operation Wallah evidence presented by the CJC, were heavily qualified by statements like `available evidence' and the like. Of course there was insufficient available evidence found by the AFP because they failed to look where the evidence could be found.

You have to ask the very serious question as to whether they were incompetent or whether there was political interference in these matters. The evidence of the Hanson inquiry has made clear the AFP's shortcomings in relation to this investigation. It makes a mockery of the claims in this report about `cooperative endeavours with state law enforcement bodies'. In that regard, it makes a mockery of this annual report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just take the opportunity to reiterate what Senator Chapman has said about the performance of the AFP. Senator Chapman and I sat next to each other when officers from the AFP appeared before the estimates committee earlier this year. The sort of information we received from them was quite surprising. For example, we were told that one particular suspect in the Operation Wallah inquiry had been interviewed. It transpired that, instead of this particular suspect being brought in and being made to undergo a proper interview, because of this person's particular links, I assume to the government, it was thought appropriate that an officer telephone this suspect's lawyer to ask whether the lawyer believed that the suspect was guilty of an offence. Surprise, surprise! The answer was that the lawyer did not believe that was the case.
—Former Senator Richardson.

—This is former Senator Richardson. That is exactly the way in which the AFP dealt with these matters. Is it any surprise that Mr Wyvill and Mr O'Regan thought the AFP's conduct had been less than satisfactory? Now we find at the inquiry in New South Wales there is evidence that many officers of the AFP have been involved in corrupt practices. I am not saying the two are linked, but I am saying that the conduct of the AFP has been something less than what one would expect from the federal law enforcement body. Now we find the government is intending to restructure the AFP to make it something akin to the FBI. Heaven help us because they have a long way to go.
—They didn't want to help the FBI.

—Senator Chapman interjects that they did not want to help the FBI. That is perfectly correct. They did not want to help the FBI when the FBI wanted to look at the international criminal links that arose out of Operation Wallah. All this sordid conduct that was engaged in, they did not want to help there. But now the government wants to turn them into something akin to the FBI. I note Senator Baume wishes to speak to this document.

—I share Senator Chapman's concerns about this annual report. One would struggle to find anywhere in it any suggestion that the AFP was other than squeaky clean. Although, I do say, on page 54 there is the revelation that 47 allegations against members of the force were substantiated, 59 allegations against members were not substantiated, 39 criminal charges were recommended against members of the force, five disciplinary charges were recommended, four recommendations were made that fixed term appointments either not be renewed or terminated, and there were seven other administrative actions. Two of these references resulted in the delaying of serious criminal charges against two AFP investigators—and you thumb to page 54 to find this out.

PARA.TAB: The fact is that the AFP is in turmoil. I acknowledge the point made by the commissioner recently that the restructuring in the AFP has had no relationship to the extraordinarily unfortunate volume of corruption that has become evident in the ICAC inquiries in New South Wales and that these are merely coincidental. The fact remains that this report does not give any kind of impression of the sorts of problems the Australian Federal Police is going through.

The worst feature of this is that the great bulk of AFP officers are honest, hard working, effective and competent. It is unfortunate that there does seem to have been a politicising of an element of the AFP and the corrupting of another element of the AFP. The politicising is evidenced from the complaints that Senator Chapman has made where there was a clear and disgraceful attempt, successful attempt so far—

TALK.START.PARA: —They won't succeed in the end.

—They will not succeed in the end, Senator Chapman says. There was an attempt to provide protection to a political figure for political purposes and there was corruption in the way that has been evidenced by the New South Wales inquiry into police corruption.

PARA.TAB: I note this report was sent by Mr Palmer, the police commissioner, on 17 October. There were a whole lot of examples before that date. For example, the Premier of New South Wales said the state government would be prepared to approach the federal government to extend the commission's powers at the behest of the commissioner to look into corruption within the AFP.

On 10 October, there was a large article in the Australian talking about confessions in which officers serving as informants stole drug money, were given cash payments for leaking vital pieces of information and framing suspected criminals. Those who have come clean so far include high ranking officers, one posted overseas. The AFP says all of these confessors, code named to protect their lives, have tended their resignations and some of them have been given indemnity from prosecution. When did all this happen? Where is it reported? That is the sort of thing that concerns me immensely about this report.
