TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to speak on a matter that is of great concern out in the community—that is, the way in which the roll out of the information superhighway and the communications revolution that is sweeping this country has some rather unfortunate side effects. The particular side effect I want to refer to tonight is the way in which mobile communication towers are springing up across the landscape with very little regulation from government. The whole matter goes back to the way in which this government, yet again, has mucked up the legislative and regulatory environment for this new development in our community.

PARA.TAB: Things that are happening and causing great concern to the community include a child-care centre in the seat of Warringah in Sydney where they decided to put the tower up right next to a child-care centre. The radiation from these towers is a matter of great concern. Also in the same area of Sydney there were people who bought a home, spent a lot of money buying the home, then spent a lot of money renovating the home; now one of the communication carriers has built a huge tower right next door to them.

I ask the Senate to consider what the effects of that would be on the property value of that particular home and other homes nearby. What recourse do these people have in law? What possible negotiation rights do they have with the communication carriers? Under the law, the way this federal Labor government has set it up, they have no rights at all. It just continues a pattern we have seen with this government over many areas of legislation in the communications area in the last five years.

We have as Minister for Communications and the Arts, the Rip Van Winkle, Michael Lee, who on this issue, along with a number of others, has just left things to happen without a proper environment that protects the interests of the community. We had, for example, that terrible case last year with the anti-siphoning list on pay TV where it looked like people would not be able to watch the West Indies cricket tour because the minister did not get the list right.

We have the case with the Spectrum Management Agency, which is controlling the distribution of licences for community broadcasting, leaving a whole range of community broadcasters out in the cold with nowhere to go because it will take them several years to set up and hold the inquiry in their area. We have pay television developing very rapidly into a duopoly in this country. We have the ABC cut out of it. Why? Again, because the regulatory framework was not set up properly by this government. They just did not think ahead.

Now we have the burgeoning mobile telephone market and the unfortunate consequences of visual pollution across the landscape of our big cities and out into country areas. This problem is going to become an increasing problem in our society unless the government does something about it. At this time, we have over two million mobile telephone subscribers—one in 10 Australians use a mobile telephone. That increase, particularly as we move from analog to digital, is going to be at an even more rapid rate.

Those of you who use mobiles realise that they quite frequently drop out. That is because there are not enough centres to pick up the signals. So the urgency is always on for the communication carriers to throw up more and more towers. There is a need for more towers. The communications structure of this nation makes the need for this very great. But that national need has to be balanced off against the individual need in local communities where they do not want these ugly towers just thrown up without any regard to what the local communities think.

The problem goes back to the way in which the government originally set up this legislation. What they did under the communications act in 1992 was exempt carriers from the normal local and state government environmental regulations. There was only a requirement that they consult in the local area and that was not clearly set out.

The minister indicated that this problem would be solved when they got to the point of laying out the code of practice under which the regulations were to operate. When that code came down, what we had was more or less a toothless tiger. We had communities coming to us as long as two years ago telling us about this problem and how the consultation process and code was not working.

What was happening in places like Waterfall, which is on the south side of Sydney, was that they were putting up very ugly towers close to residential areas. The local residents complained to Telstra when it had a community meeting, the local council complained to Telstra and then Telstra went ahead and did what it wanted to do. It can do that because it has this exemption. Because the government has not given a body such as Austel the power to act as an honest broker in this matter we find our communication companies can do what they like.

What we suggest should happen is that the government give a body like Austel greater teeth to act as the regulator to balance the national interest versus the interests of the local community and to work out some orderly process whereby the community could feed into the decision making process. It is not happening now. The interests of families and residents have been totally ignored. There are a lot of very upset people as a result of these towers that are going up everywhere. We need to develop a code with real teeth so that communities can have a say on what happens in their areas.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the part of my speech that I was unable to deliver earlier today.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I wish to raise an extraordinary situation, which was reported in the media, relating to the repayment by the Australian Workers Union—the largest union affiliated with the ALP—of donations totalling $150,000 to five organisations that made those donations in August this year. The repayment, which is no doubt extraordinary, is even more extraordinary when you consider the people to whom these repayments of donations were made. For example, more than $100,000 of the $150,000 in donations was from the legal firm Phillips Fox and the construction company John Holland.

PARA.TAB: Phillips Fox received back its $58,000 donation to the AWU and John Holland, which is under the control of Mrs Holmes a Court, received back its $43,000 donation. I am intrigued about the Phillips Fox payment because Mick Young, a former minister in a Labor government, is a consultant to Phillips Fox and is described as a very effective communicator with the government. They say that they have a team of experts who know the correct path to follow in order to achieve optimum results for their clients. They say that they work well with Australia's political decision makers, ministers, their policy advisers and the appropriate bureaucrats at all levels. That raises an interesting question about the purpose of their $58,000 donation to the AWU.

I suppose you could say the same about John Holland Construction. I do not think it is unreasonable to say that Mrs Holmes a Court is not held at a distance by the leadership of the Labor Party. There are other people who made smaller donations. The fact is that the companies initially paid the money to AWU national construction branch officials who created a slush fund to campaign, according to a media report, for re-election in union ballots.

The big question in my mind is whether this was the real destination for this money. It seems extraordinary that these funds would go to supporting a factional fight within the AWU, although it is noteworthy that the factional fights within the AWU are fairly exciting. One would be surprised if companies of the status of John Holland and Phillips Fox would contribute $100,000 between them to support a particular faction within the AWU, although the bitterness in this dispute was severe.

For example, in the propaganda put during the last AWU election one of the sides said, `We have had enough of the political interference in our union, enough of union officials who sit at their desks awaiting the ultimate superannuation and retirement fund—a seat in the Senate.' I do not know what Senator Forshaw, a former official of the AWU, thinks about that. He may have a different view altogether. There is no doubt that there is severe bitterness involved in the AWU.

As I said, it would be extraordinary if these donations were for internal campaign purposes within the AWU, particularly as Mr Mick Young was selected as the person to inquire into and report on Labor's disastrous showing in the recent Queensland state election. Obviously one would assume that members of the other factions would not have been too cheerful about that if he had been involved in donations to a particular faction of the AWU.

This raises the serious question of whether this money was a donation to the Australian Labor Party, made via the AWU, its biggest single union member, to circumvent the disclosure provisions of the Electoral Act. Because there is no explanation given for these repayments, I wonder whether it is a recognition that the disclosure provisions would have got them in the end if these repayments were not made. There is no doubt that there is a clear need for this matter to be cleared up.

For whom was Phillips Fox's $58,000 donation intended? For whom was John Holland's $43,000 donation intended? One wonders whether any of these bodies have matters before the AWU or the federal or Queensland parliaments where they are representing someone or seeking to gain contracts. This kind of donation would not have come to light through the normal reporting process of the Electoral Act and that is a concern.

If people want any details of it, the questions relate to a company called Chamber Consulting Services Pty Ltd, which is the major shareholder in PSI Superannuation Management Pty Ltd which administers the AWU superannuation fund.

It is evident that Chamber Consulting had been paid $6,400 from the Victorian AWU account on 18 August this year. This account and other AWU accounts in Victoria have been under investigation by police since Mr Cambridge lodged complaints with the National Crime Authority. The NCA referred the matter to the Victorian police after AWU's senior officials had been able to account for about $150,000.

A bank document leaked to the media some time ago suggests much of the money could have been returned to a number of large companies; but the document alone does not explain the relationship between signatories to the account and the companies involved. The companies initially paid the money to AWU national construction branch officials who created a slush fund to campaign for re-election in union ballots.

Companies paid money from the AWU members welfare association No. 1 account on 18 August were: Chamber Consulting, $6,400; John Holland, $43,000; Thiess Brothers, $9,400; Phillips Fox, $58,000; and Fluor Daniel, $29,000. It would be interesting to know what that is all about.

The conflict within the AWU is very severe. In one document I have from one of the AWU factions, there is an attack on Mr Bob Smith, who it is alleged appears to have been incompetent or worse; the financial reserves of the union were exhausted in an extravagant spending spree; for no good reason the union shifted its Melbourne office one block and took the vehicle builders' office off their hands; a massive mortgage is still `hanging over our heads'; in May 1992, Smith ordered wide-scale sackings and cutbacks but branch president, Fred Phillips, resisted and went to the Victorian police; fraud and corruption investigations began against Smith and, not unnaturally, Smith disappeared on paid leave.

Federal president, Bill Ludwig, and federal secretary, Mike Forshaw, put the situation under wraps. The executive council placed the finances of the Victorian branch under Forshaw's control. With some heavy-handed persuasion, the branch executive was persuaded to invite Western Australian branch secretary Bruce Wilson across as acting secretary. There then followed an enormous attack on Bruce Wilson. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ALSTON
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in the adjournment debate on matters arising out of a particularly silly speech made by Mr Michael Lee in the House of Representatives last night when he rushed breathlessly into the chamber and extended the debate after 8.00 to respond to some remarks by my colleague Tony Abbott, the member for Warringah.

PARA.TAB: Mr Abbott's concerns were principally twofold: the erection of mobile digital telephone towers relating to telephony; and the stringing of cables overground but beneath power cables in respect of pay television and broadband services, fibre-optic cable. They are both quite separate issues; both of them, however, do have significant environmental and town planning implications.

Mr Abbott was quite rightly drawing the concern of the House of Representatives to the appalling neglect of this government via Mr Lee's callous indifference to the rights of citizens by his refusal to upgrade the telecommunications code, which has now been in place for many months and which he was forced to review only as a result of a deal he brokered with the Australian Democrats to avoid a disallowance of the code by the opposition in the Senate to tighten it up and to ensure much greater power was handed back to the local communities.

Indeed, Mr Lee is still vigorously resisting any suggestion that the locals ought to have a greater control over events in their own areas. As a result, the Senate has now required the minister representing him in this chamber to make a statement tomorrow morning explaining why there has been such inordinate delay in conducting the government's own review, which started on 1 July, and to inform the Senate of the government's intentions in this regard.

These are all matters of proper community concern. There is a balance to be struck. Clearly, it is necessary for the mobile phone network to be seamless, not to have black holes and blackouts. But, at the same time, you cannot simply impose it on the citizenry. You cannot simply put it up irrespective of the consequences both aesthetic and environmental. Yet this government seems to have no understanding of those sensitivities.

Mr Lee's speech revealed not a skerrick of insight into those concerns, but simply got the issues fundamentally wrong. For example, he seems to not even understand the difference between conduits and cables. He rabbited on at some length about how the Telecommunications Act allows Optus to get access to the cables. But Mr Abbott's point, as I understand it, was to inquire why it was not possible for the conduits to be shared so that underground you had simply the one duct but two separate sets of fibre-optic cables.

Mr Lee does not even seem to understand that that is the area of concern, let alone try to address it. Telstra argues that, indeed, there is insufficient room in a 30-centimetre diameter conduit and, therefore, it is not possible to accommodate the Optus cable. Therefore, there is a requirement for Optus to lay its own and because it is significantly cheaper and faster, and indeed because the licence is granted to the carriers requiring them to roll out the cable as quickly as possible, understandably, they have taken another course. Indeed, there are certainly suggestions that Telstra has the same proposals in mind.

Yet Mr Lee seems to be utterly oblivious to the distinction, or else simply utterly unconcerned about residents' anxieties. That is what I find so distressing. I know he is out of his depth and I know that in many respects he simply has to take his orders from his master's voice. But you would have thought that he would at least understand that he does not need to use the term `Telecom' anymore because there is no such entity. You would have thought he would realise that Bob Mansfield is no longer the executive director of Optus Communications. But here he is still using outdated terminology.

I even understand he was so childish and petty as to go down to the National Library this morning following on someone who had introduced Brendan Smyth and then to refer to him as `Mr Smythe'. I do not know whether that is done deliberately. It sounds like the tactics of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to try to denigrate, humiliate and embarrass all those who do not belong to his party. But I would have thought that is childish behaviour.

When I saw a press release put out tonight by Mr Lee, which suggests that somehow Mr Abbott had been in the House of Representatives last night proposing a break-up of Telstra, it immediately dawned on me why he had put this release out. It was to disguise the fact that he himself had fundamentally misunderstood these points of concern—that, in fact, the government itself is the party that has constantly proposed the break-up of Telstra. Mr Lee moved amendments at the national conference to preserve only the core activities to deliberately allow the possibility of selling off so-called non-core assets.

It was Mr Beddall who went to the Telstra board when he was the Minister for Communications and the Arts proposing that they sell off non-core assets. It was the Prime Minister who put up the proposition to Mr Frank Blunt only a matter of months ago that the Yellow Pages be sold off and then, of course, forced Mr Blunt to buy his way out of the blackmail by surrendering a huge and totally unwarranted dividend payment to the government, which treats Telstra as a cash cow and not as a means of providing high quality telecommunications services to all Australians.

That is why it is quite clear that if Mr Lee is going to have any contribution to make in this debate, he has to come to terms with the concepts involved. He ought to start by going back into the chamber in the adjournment debate and apologising to Mr Abbott, because Mr Abbott said nothing more than, `Perhaps we need to go further. Perhaps we need to break up Telstra', et cetera. In other words, using hypothetical propositions to indicate his personal view, in no shape or form ever diverged from the coalition's oft-stated policy of privatisation on a going concern basis.

It is the Labor Party that has been interested in asset stripping. That is precisely what Mr Lee is trying to distract attention from. That is why it is so disappointing when you get him saying things like, `It was the coalition which helped to vote to ensure that the telephone companies were exempted from the state planning laws.' The fact is that we supported legislation which gave the minister a discretion—which we expected him to exercise properly—to bring in a code that would have struck a proper balance, not simply allowed for a notification to councils but no obligation to go any further and to allow towers to be erected overnight, without proper consultation, quite often in unsatisfactory locations and without any attempt to pursue proper collocation options. That has come about as a result of pressure applied by the coalition.

We still argue vehemently that that code is inadequate. We have made it perfectly clear that we think there ought to be much more consultation. There has been deafening silence on the part of the government. It is quite clear that not only has Mr Lee ratted on the clear obligation imposed upon him as minister to come up with a code that would provide a proper balance and that would ensure that residents' concerns were taken into conduct, instead we get all this silly nonsense like:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I do not know if your constituents would be happy if they missed out on the lower prices that flow, especially for local calls.
No-one is talking about preventing the roll out. The issue is the terms upon which the carriers and their associates can exercise their rights to roll out cable.

PARA.TAB: Mr Lee does not even seem to understand the issue in terms of duplication. Mr Abbott was pointing to the fact that this government had a number of options when it first confronted the issues of rolling out the cable for pay television and broadband interactive services. They could have actually had exclusive regional franchises requiring only one carrier to roll out a cable in a particular area, but on a common carrier basis so that they had to give access to others. They could also have allowed the duplicate roll out but, at the same time, required them to be common carriers so that they would have access to each other's services.

They could have had a utility arrangement and drawn that distinction between carriage and content, which other countries have done, but we let the whole game go by default. Mr Lee came up with a model which is unique. As a result, we will see some $3 billion to $4 billion of unnecessary duplication in this country. He seems to be utterly oblivious to all these concerns. You can have duplication and you can have parallel cables inside the same conduit. But he seems to think there is no difference between cables and conduits. If that is the level of his ignorance, I very much hope that he will go away and do his homework before he comes back into the House of Representatives and apologises for all that silly nonsense of last night.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week I attended the release of the Dorset municipality's draft sustainable development strategy. For the information of honourable senators, the municipality of Dorset is situated in north-eastern Tasmania. I know Senator Watson knows well where it is but, for the information of other senators, the municipality of Dorset comprises 3,196 square kilometres; it has a permanent population of 7,690 people; and it encompasses the townships of Bridport, Branxholm, Derby, Gladstone, Legerwood, Nabowla, Musselroe Bay, Pioneer, Ringarooma, Scottsdale, Tomahawk and Winnaleah.

PARA.TAB: I do not wish to claim any credit for the content of the draft sustainable development strategy. I was invited to that release because I had sponsored a forum on sustainable development which provided input to the council's strategy development. The forum that I sponsored was designed to encourage the community to approach resource problems from the perspective that the Dorset municipality could be viewed as a totality with resource usage linked to many activities.

It was problems associated with resource management which sparked the need to encourage a wider perspective to issues. Tasmanian senators will, I am sure, remember a pyrethrum manufacturer who was responsible for a spill of pyrethrum into the Great Forester River near Scottsdale about 18 months ago. Following that episode, Atrazine was detected in creek water in the district. This was of particular concern to local hop growers and milk producers who were economically dependent on access to pure water. It was found that the contamination of water supplies resulted from the application of Atrazine to retard weed growth in Tasmanian Forestry Corporation plantations. Neither was this problem confined to north-east Tasmania; it was also an issue at Wynyard, Lorinna and other places in Tasmania.

Although the Dorset Council called for a moratorium on the use of Atrazine, it was clear that a long-term strategy on resource usage was required because, as well as the chemical issue, there was considerable concern about the adequacy of road funding in the municipality as a result of wear and tear from log trucks. I presented petitions and encouraged people to nominate Atrazine as a chemical to be reviewed by the National Registration Authority. As a result, the National Registration Authority came to Launceston and held its largest public consultation meeting of the review process. Eventually, Atrazine was selected as one of the 10 chemicals to be reviewed.

I also initiated the preparation of a community forum in order to broaden perspectives about resource usage in the municipality. The forum was held in December 1994 and included speakers on ecological sustainable development, alternative agriculture, ecological forestry, wine producing and pyrethrum manufacturing. The forum ended with a dinner with Professor Ben Sellinger as the guest speaker. The event was well attended and produced a report which was submitted to the Dorset Council's own strategy development meetings. I am pleased to note that many of the issues raised at that forum are incorporated into the council's final report.

The report identifies seven major issues, of which water quality and resource, and land use head the list. With National Water Week being held next week, it is timely to acknowledge that water is becoming an increasingly scarce resource. Australia's—and Tasmania's—rivers, lakes, streams and underground supplies are under massive threat from the effects of sewerage, industrial waste, siltation from bare paddocks, fertiliser and chemical run-off from agriculture, forestry and mining. In Tasmania, the Dorset municipality is now leading the way in recognising the need for integrated catchment management, measuring and monitoring water quality and identifying the sources of pollution.

It is also pleasing to see that, under the heading of land use, the report identified a desire to facilitate and support the introduction of alternative agricultural practices. It also identified the need to prepare a Dorset sustainable forest industry plan and to initiate a study of the costs and benefits of the forest industry to the community, including the costs of road maintenance. These are important issues which reflect the concerns of the municipality.

More importantly, the report recognises the integrated nature of the issues, and the need to be developing strategies for the region which integrate economic considerations and environmental and social consequences. I believe that this is a real step forward. The municipality now has the opportunity to work at implementing measures which could address significant problems in a manner that minimises the adverse or unforeseen consequences.

Without intending to dictate the direction the municipality should adopt, I note the opportunity to embrace alternative sustainable agricultural systems. There is a strong body of opinion which regards Tasmania's north-east as ideally suited for organic farming. The report provides a golden opportunity to adopt such a strategy. I would encourage those involved in organic or biological farming to take the opportunity provided by the implementation process to seriously encourage the community to investigate the scope and extent of the commercial opportunities available.
Finally, I would like to congratulate the Dorset Council on the draft strategy produced. I look forward to its implementation in the period ahead.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to use this adjournment debate to put you, Mr President, and also the Senate on notice of the enforcement of order 34 of the Senate. Order 34 of the Senate entitled `Taxation bills—retrospectivity' reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That, where the Government has announced, by press release, its intention to introduce a Bill to amend taxation law, and that Bill has not been introduced into the Parliament or made available by way of publication of a draft Bill within 6 calendar months after the date of that announcement, the Senate shall, subject to any further resolution, amend the Bill to provide that the commencement date of the Bill shall be a date that is no earlier than either the date of introduction of the Bill into the Parliament or the date of publication of the draft Bill.

In the budget announcement on 9 May, the Treasurer (Mr Willis) announced, as part of the budget, the decision to change the taxation treatment applicable to a debtor who is released from the liability to repay a commercial debt. Budget paper No. 1 states:

Where a commercial debt is forgiven after 7.30 pm EST 9 May 1995, the amount forgiven will reduce the debtor's future tax deductions by reducing in order the following amounts: prior revenue losses, prior net capital losses, undeducted balances of capital expenditures, and cost bases of capital assets. This measure will protect the revenue base by ensuring that where a debtors economic loss is transferred to the creditor through debt forgiveness, the associated future tax deductions are denied to the debtor. Creditors will continue to have access to the existing provisions relating to deductions for bad debts and capital losses.

I remind the Senate that, at present, no bill for this proposed measure has actually been introduced into the parliament, nor has a draft bill even been published. So, I suppose, essentially the matter is in the hands of the Senate and, being in the hands of the Senate, it is also in your hands, Mr President. If, after 9 November 1995, a bill for the measure is introduced into the parliament or an appropriate draft bill is published, I believe there is an obligation on you and the Senate under this taxation bills retrospectivity order—resolutions expressing opinions of continuing effect—that was brought in on 8 November 1988, that that should be enforced.

PARA.TAB: So the purpose of my contribution tonight is to put you on notice, Mr President, that you need to consider how you and the Senate propose to deal with a delinquent government and its failure to bring forward bills at the appropriate time and before the six months has expired. I thank the Senate. Mr President, you might be able to respond in the interim.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was distracted at the last minute. I will apply that order. It is not a matter for me; it is a matter for the Senate. It is not like a standing order; it is a resolution expressing opinions of continuing effect.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs on 9 June 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Yangennanock Corporation (the Hamilton headquarters of the Kerrup Jmara Corporation):
(1) What were the conclusions of the 1994 probe into the Yangennanock Corporation by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission.
(2) Are the conclusions publicly available.
(3) Did the probe uncover any financial irregularities.
(4) Has a further `cheque by cheque' probe been authorised; if so, when will the results of the second audit be publicly available.
(5) When will the Hamilton business people who are owed money by the Yangennanock Corporation have their debts settled.
(6)(a) Why are the Yangennanock Corporation offices permanently closed despite the substantial investment by taxpayers in the facility; and
(b) are any of its functions being carried out elsewhere.
(7) Why is the Aboriginal Community Justice Panel still suspended, and why have the Hamilton Police disassociated themselves from panel management.
(8) Are the financial records of the Darlot River Housing Co-operative available for public scrutiny.
(9) Why was `Glenisla' bought and what benefit(s) does its ownership provide for local Aboriginals by way of, for example, employment opportunities, housing et cetera, or the wider community.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has provided the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs with the following information in response to the honourable Senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) In March 1994 an initial investigation was undertaken by Ernst and Young, Chartered Accountants, into Community Development Employment Projects (CDEP) funding. The investigation revealed a number of problems with internal controls and administrative systems in the Yangennanock Aboriginal Corporation (YAC).
(2) The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC) regards the report itself, including its detailed findings, as an internal document and it is therefore not publicly available.
(3) Yes.

(4) The cheques and deposit slips audit concluded in May 1995 found that monies had been dispersed to various payees as cash cheques and it is impossible to trace whether the amounts have been paid in accordance with ATSIC funding guidelines.

(5) Liquidation proceedings of the Yangennanock Aboriginal Corporation are being pursued by the Australian Government Solicitor. Creditors should lodge their claims for debts owing with the liquidator, when appointed.
(6)(a) The Corporation's office is not presently operating owing to the Corporation's financial difficulties. The building was purchased for the community by the Victorian State Government.
(b) ATSIC is unaware of general community functions being undertaken at alternative premises.

(7) The Hamilton Aboriginal Community Justice Panel (HACJP) was suspended due to financial accountability problems regarding operating funds released to it by the Victoria Police. Hamilton Police have continued to obtain Aboriginal community input through Aboriginal community groups and individuals in the area.

Inquiries made by ATSIC's Victorian Office have confirmed that the Victoria Police remain committed to the Aboriginal Community Justice Panel concept. Alternatives to the Hamilton Panel have been examined, and a revamped Panel is to be commenced soon based in the Heywood/Portland area. It is intended that this Panel will service Hamilton as well. This new Panel has the support of the Victoria Police and the State wide Aboriginal Community Justice Panels Chairpersons' group.

(8) The Darlot River Housing Co-op is not known to ATSIC. However, the Darlots Creek (Saunders Family) Aboriginal Corporation is registered under the Aboriginal Councils and Associations Act 1976. The Corporation was first registered in 1985. It is in the process of being deregistered by the Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations due to non compliance with its statutory responsibilities under the Act.
The financial records of the Corporation are available for public scrutiny. Neither ATSIC or its predecessors has provided any financial assistance to the Corporation.

(9) The Nigretta Road property `Glenisla' was purchased with the intention of establishing a cultural/tourism facility on it. Regrettably, because of the problems concerning the management of Yangennanock, the potential of the property in terms of providing employment opportunities, housing and other benefits for the wider community has not yet been realised.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 19 July 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Do Ministers in the department have Internet accounts; if so, what is the mail address of each such account.
(2) (a) What was the installation cost of providing ministerial access to the Internet; (b) who paid these costs; and (c) what is the estimated annual cost of operating this Internet account.

(3) (a) Are Ministers in the department physically able to operate accounts from either their Parliament House or any other offices; if so, who was responsible for installing the necessary links; and (b) what were the costs entailed and who paid these costs.
(4) What plans are there to provide Ministerial access to the Internet and when is it estimated that such access will be available.
(5) Does the department use, or has it used, the Internet for on-line publishing; if so, can the addresses for any such Internet sites be provided.
(6) Can a list of all items published since 1 May 1995 be provided.
(7) (a) Is there a code of practice governing the content of departmental material that can be published on the Internet; and (b) can a copy of any such code of practice be provided.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Department has not provided the Minister with a separate account. The Department has established an alias of a departmental account called: Minister.SocialSecurity@dss.gov.au. This is monitored by departmental staff and appropriate E:mail is brought to the Minister's attention.
(2) (a) The cost of providing the alias was negligible.
(b) The Commonwealth of Australia paid this cost.
(c) The estimated annual cost of providing the alias is negligible.
(3) (a)&(b) See (1). The Minister does not have a departmental provided account.
(4) The Department has no specific plans to provide ministerial access to the Internet.

(5) The Department has published information on the CIN (Community Information Network) World Wide Web site located on the Internet. The Universal Resource Locator (URL) for CIN is http://www.cin.gov.au. Other publishing for the Department has been undertaken by the National Library. The URL for the National Library Commonwealth Government Home Page is http://www.nla.gov.au/oz/gov/federal.html.

(6) The information published by the Department on the CIN consists of information about the CIN project and information regarding Departmental benefits and services. The Department has also developed a "home page" which provides pointers to community, and other information, including other World Wide Web sites. Some of the community information has been made available on the CIN server for the purposes of the project. The list has been provided to the honourable senator.

(7) (a)There is no formal code of practice across the APS governing the content of departmental material being published on the Internet. The issue is being addressed by a Commonwealth/States Internet working party which was established in September 1994 and which is tasked with developing a common approach to making non-confidential government information available on the Internet and other public networks.
The Department of Finance is playing a significant role in the project and is chairing the working party with active participation from a large number of agencies.
A code of conduct has been developed for the purposes of the CIN project, which covers general community usage. A copy has been provided to the honourable senator.

(b) Policy covering a code of practice governing the content of departmental material which can be published on the Internet is being constructed by the Department's Internet Reference Group (IRG). The code of practice will be forwarded to the honourable senator when it has been completed.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Transport, upon notice, on 1 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the scoping study for the sale of the Federal airports been completed.

(2) Will a copy be tabled for parliamentary consideration before legislation authorising the sale of the Federal airports is introduced into the Senate; if not, does the Minister consider it appropriate to sell taxpayer-funded assets without disclosing to taxpayers' parliamentary representatives some idea of the value of those assets and how those values may depend more or less on the degree of monopoly pricing power to be allowed to the purchaser of those assets.

(3) Given that the Bureau of Industry Economics has pointed out that governments have been under increasing pressure to use essential infrastructure, such as airports, for monopoly revenue raising, what studies have been undertaken as to the implications of different airport price regulation formulae for the economy of Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The scoping study on the sale of the Federal airports was completed prior to the 1995 Budget.

(2) In line with established practice, the Government will not table the scoping study or estimates of the value of the airport assets for parliamentary consideration as such information may influence the outcome of the sales process.

(3) The Federal Government has reviewed a range of options in its consideration of the most appropriate form of price regulation across all Federal airports. As a result of this examination, the Government concluded that the PSA should monitor aeronautical charges at Launceston and Hobart airports. The Government will retain the option of declaring these airports for formal surveillance should monitoring highlight any concerns over the adequacy of initial price oversight arrangements.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction, upon notice, on 25 September 1995:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answers to question on notice number 2382:

(1) With reference to the second paragraph of the answer to question (1) which states that diesel fuel purchased for use to extract or crush limestone as an ore with a view to recovering from it particular mineral or particular minerals will continue to be rebatable, can a further definition be provided of what this means.

(2) Given that limestone is a substance which is used for a number of different purposes, including: (a) production of cement; (b) industrial lime and quick lime; (c) flux; (d) soil and water acidification treatment; (e) construction and aggregate; and others; is it a fact that except in the case of limestone used for category (e), the other uses for limestone are for their chemical and mineral qualities.

(3) Is it a fact that if limestone is used for any of these uses, apart from construction and aggregate use, it comes within the definition which would enable the diesel fuel purchased for use to extract or crush limestone to be fully rebatable; if not, on what basis is the extraction and crushing of limestone in fact within the definition of a mineral which is entitled to a full rebate of diesel fuel excise.

(4) Where limestone is used after crushing entirely for the purposes of soil and water acidification treatment, can confirmation be provided that it is classed as a mineral entitled to the full rebate; if not, what criteria is used to assess whether or not the limestone is to be regarded as such a mineral.
(5) Can details be provided of the quantity of limestone used for deacidification of soil and water in Australia in the last available statistical year.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Subsection 164(7) of the Customs Act 1901 defines "mining operations" as, among other things, "mining for minerals". Under the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Act 1995, "minerals" is in turn defined to mean "minerals in any form, whether solid, liquid or gaseous and whether organic or inorganic, except sand, sandstone, soil, slate, clay (other than bentonite or kaolin), basalt, granite, gravel, limestone or water".

The word "for" in the expression "mining for minerals" requires that a purposive test be applied in that a claimant needs to demonstrate that the purpose of his or her activities is to obtain a particular mineral or minerals intermixed or embedded in the ore body that is extracted. As limestone is specifically excluded from the definition, a claimant is unable to enjoy the benefit of diesel fuel rebate if the activities carried out are characterised merely as the extraction of limestone.
However, if the purpose of the activity is to recover from an ore a particular mineral or minerals that conform to and are not excluded by the definition, rebate will continue to be payable.

(2) The eligibility test in the legislation is not whether the limestone is used for its chemical and mineral qualities, as limestone per se is not recognised as a mineral. Rather, eligibility for rebate is dependent on passing the purposive test referred to in (1) above.
(3) Please refer to (1) and (2) above. The use of the limestone is irrelevant as it is excluded from the definition of minerals.
(4) As pointed out above, under the existing statutory definition, limestone is not recognised as

ANSWER.PARA: a mineral. Regardless of whether the limestone is used in the deacidification of soil and water, in road making, construction or other purposes, if it is limestone, then it is excluded from the definition of "minerals" for the purposes of the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

PARA.TAB: (5) The Australian Customs Service does not keep statistics of this nature. However, according to the Land and Water Resources Research and Development Corporation, around 500,000 tonnes was applied to agricultural areas in Australia during 1989-90.
